The meal wouldn't have been complete without the outrageous amounts of chimmichuri (an oil and herb combo packed with flavor).  In true family style fashion, my coworker Breanna, and I went half died between the chicken with lemon sauce (served with buttery spinach mashed potatoes) and the filet which ended up coming our more like two full sized filets. Both were delicious;however, the chicken took the cake for me.  In foolproof terms, go here if you fall into one of the following categories: 1.) you love meat 2.) you're hoping to get some action/impress a date for circa 50 bucks 3.) often find yourself turned on by heavy bass

On a date with someone from the show True Blood? You're guaranteed some steamy hot vampire love after a night here.  The lighting is low, the music is hip, they serve Sur-real portions of rare filet for about $25, and it's BYOB. If these things alone don't get you some serious suck face then you probably smell like a werewolf.   Everything on the menu is under about $30 including filets, strips, and skirts. The vibe is cool but intimate at the same time and the staff all speak with an accent that you'd imagine out of a cheesy romance novel.  If you want a wallet watching way to impress a person whether human, vampire, werewolf, or whatever Tango Sur is your spot!

I don't like calling myself a vegetarian because I eat fish.  I don't like calling myself a pescatarian because it sounds like a made-up-ass word. ...also because I'd totally eat human and I don't think there's a word for that yet. Webster's: Keep me posted on any developments.  This place... it's for the meat eaters. Like, Fred Flintstone-style meat eaters. Our table must've had at least a wooly mammoth's worth of meat on the table. Glorious.  Ok, not so much for me, but I can still appreciate a plate of two juicy, fist-sized filets and a side of pesto mashed potatoes for $25 at BYOB place. It was absolutely enough to induce meat sweats on at least two people per plate.  For me, I'd say the spinach and cheese empanadas with that chimichurri sauce. Soooo good and I heard the meety ones were good as well... or at least not a crumb was left.  I'd originally wanted the tortilla/egg/pepper dish on their tapas menu but our server said it would take 45 minutes and I was there with a big group so I opted not to make everyone wait. My next choice was the grilled octopus dish but the server noted that it was just a cold appetizer and didn't recommend it for a meal, so then I went with my third choice (really narrowing the menu down for me) which was their salmon entree special, but they were out of that completely. Bummer. I guess I'll just take the spinach ravioli. Womp womp. But I also tacked on that grilled octopus salad to treat myself. Boom. Both were great but the meat dishes are the absolute stunners here. Perfect meat sweat date spot.  Also, there's a menu item called a 'Flap Meat'... super gross sounding, but I gotta give credit for originality.

This is my favorite restaurant in Chicago, great ambiance, great food and great service once you are seated. The only problem that prevents me from giving it a 5 star rating is the wait time right before you get seated. I have been to that place twice and in both times we had to wait for more than half an hour although we made reservations.

I was totally under-whelmed by this place.  I decided to have my birthday dinner here after hearing such great things about it.  I made a reservation a week ahead and asked if I needed to call and confirm later and they said no.  The day of they called me and said "feel free to call us if you have any questions about your reservation for tonight."   I didn't have any questions and did not call.  Later, about an hour and a half before my reservation, they called again and said if I did not call them back and confirm my reservation they would give the table to someone else.  I immediately called back and confirmed.   We had a group of 11 and waited outside for 15 minutes past our 9 o'clock reservation.  We were starting to ask how long we were going to wait and they said the table would be ready for us shortly and then said we could go inside and open our bottles of wine while they got the table ready.  They didn't give us the table that was open and then also didn't bring us glasses until we asked for them at least three times.   When we asked what the hold up was - they said it was my fault for not confirming and we would have a table shortly.  We finally got seated at 10.  After waiting an hour we were given free appetizers.  The food was all pretty good, minus the salad which was laughable.  I don't think anyone was blown away by their meals, but good portions for a price.  The service after we were seated was decent.  Not the best, not the worst.  Maybe I will try Tango Sur again...maybe.  I would not count on them to be prepared for your reservation ever.  If they are going to make me wait an hour past my reservation time - they can at least provide stellar service in the meantime.

I hope there is less than 1 star so I can give it to them. I agree that the food taste good but before you go to eat there just go to next grocery store (Elmarcado) which is connected to restaurant by the back door and see in your own eyes how dirty the meat there, the place is dirty and they sell the same meat which they cook in the restaurant in the grocery store, the tall guy with mustache who sell the meat is very dirty and rood, I will never go there again, I am sure if the city health department inspect this place it will never reopen again. The empenada which they sell is frozen for many months and they deep fry it, many times you fill it is still frozen inside.

I think I sat in the coldest seat in the house!  Went saturday night and we had a reservation for a party of 6 at 7pm.  we were walked in around 7:30 just to wait some more in the back room...15 minutes and finding someone's set of keys later (which we turned into the restaurant)...we were sat...45 mins after our reservation.  Not sure why they even have a reservation system if they don't stick to it...annoying.  What if we had somewhere to be afterwards, like a show, I would recommend that you allow yourself plenty of time to get somewhere cause you are going to wait.  My girlfriend sat across from me quickly to realize that the vent was directly below her and being that it was freezing, I changed seats with her.  Normally I can handle the cold and actually prefer it but this was meat locker cold...my leg felt like it was frost bitten after sitting there for an hour and a half...couldn't even stick it out through dessert. Awful experience trying to eat a meal while half frozen.  the appetizers were delicious...we ordered 6 empanadas and 2 tortilla de papas and they were so good.  Then we went on to our entrees...I order the platter for two and my girl and I split that, after a few bites (maybe the cold was too much for us) but we thought that we should have ordered something else.  The meat was too fatty for my liking or hers and that platter of meat didn't have anything to help cut the grease (unless you count Sausage and black sausage to be vegetables, which doesn't sound too bad of idea).  after the meat sweats that couldn't materialize cause I was half frozen, I notice the table next to us left quickly (sat after us/left before us) because they couldn't handle the cold and I watched another group come in and sit down at that table next to us and complain how cold it was, too.  I am happy to report that my leg has finally thawed out - two days later.    If I ever go back - I'll bring a book to read (for the long wait) and a blanket (to keep from being half frozen) or I'll just find myself at Las Tablas without the book or blanket.

First time I went... I loved it!! 2nd time the meat was almost raw not medium and they didnt get it right when I sent it back. Due to my first experience here I still give it 4 stars. Next time ill mention they need to make sure they cook the meat medium and explain my last experience. Ill be back  . The service is still fantastic and I love the byob
The atmosphere is amazing, bring a bottle of wine and enjoy a great steak! The wait was about an hour but the are several nearby bars to pass the time.  The dessert is to die for as well!

For 7 people is was 15$/person for large apps! Everything was great. We sat outside on front patio. Busy streets but not too busy on a Friday night.  We didn't have a res so had to wait. Went to another bar for a drink while we waited. They called our cell when they were ready! Super nice!!

This place is great!! Excellent service and amazing music on Tuesday nights. The steak was some of the best that I have had and to top it all off it was fresh and it's BYOB. It is a definite must as far as steakhouses and Argentinian restauraunts go. It is also in a quaint quiet neighborhood which makes it very pleasant to sit outside!

Tango sur was recommended by a friend as her and her finance's favorite restaurant in chicago and though it may not be my favorite.. It was definitely pleasing!  My boyfriend and I started with the provoleta based on popularity in other reviews and it was delicious. I mean,who doesn't love an ooey gooey plate of cheese?!  On to our entree... we split one of the chefs specials, the lomo relleno. Ideal for two, this slab of filet comes out juicy and filled with flavor. The best part-we were sent home with an entire serving which isn't usual with my boyfriends very large appetite! This could definitely be a meal for three or four with the addition of some al a carte side dishes. The atmosphere of tango sur, matched with the delicious food and BYOB option makes this the perfect place for a date or to get together with friends! All in all, we will definitely be going back.

I don't normally go out for steak (because it's so easy to make a juicy tasty one at home), but what the hell, I wanted to give Tango Sur a shot. Plus, a steak house with a BYOB policy is a big plus. Well, I was really disappointed, starting with the appetizers. Ordered the chicken and the spinach/cheese empanadas. Epic fail on the chicken: they came out COLD inside, almost still frozen. Hey I kinda figured the empanadas would be frozen then deep-fried, but this was totally unacceptable (my waiter was surprised and agreed). On to the steak: The filet was reasonably flavorfully and cooked, but nothing amazing. On a good note, I got a free "sorry for the frozen empanadas" flan caramel dessert that was AMAZING. I'd come back to Tango Sur just for that.

Why the 4 stars eludes me. But possible I did not get the right dishes. Firstly parking was a nightmare. I will not be able to go back because they don't have valet and there is simply nowhere to park - except a pharmacy a couple of hundred yards away where one literally has to wait stealthily for someone to leave. they pack the restaurant to the brim. the inside of the restaurant is extremely dark and extremely loud.  Had the empanadas. So, so.  The melons with proscuitto. There was no need for this dish. Three slivers of melon with the rind with 3 proscuittos draped over it. $10. No effort made to prettify the dish. Vesuvio potatoes were dull. They were the oiliest wedges doused in flavorless spice. No heat or flavor - just oily. We had the fish which was unmemorable.
Very good. The filet is tender and flavorful... They give you two. Definitely enough to share. Also byob.  Extremely slow service and extremely busy. The food is worth the wait though,

The food is still delicious and the BYOB policy makes this a great place for group dinners. However, service has definitely gone down hill. Just went a week or so ago and I had to beg for my water to be refilled because for some reason they had the windows open and no a/c on when it was in the 90's. Also, all the waiters are all beautiful men that ALL LOOK ALIKE! So it's really hard to figure out who you should be asking for what. And I always feel rushed. I get it. It's a popular place and people tend to linger over BYOB, but it's still a little tacky. Save room for dessert! They are worth it! Especially the cookies with the dulce de leche (that's caramel for all you white people).

Amazing. Go. So much meat. The Filet Is $28 and you get two oversized, delicious filets. My gf and I typically over-order, but we split this and couldn't have been more full. The empanadas were fantastic, as well. Plus it's BYOB. Go early though. Wait can be long.

I make it a point to visit this place every so often - the food here is generally too rich to visit this spot too often without worrying about what all that delicious red meat may be doing to your insides... That being said, this place is well worth any artery clogging that may temporarily ensue.  The food is always delicious, from steaks to filets the food here is well done and fantastic.   This place is BYOB, darkly lit, and perfect for anything from a date to a celebration (provided the group is cool with a lot of candles...).  I recommend this place wholeheartedly, go there with an appetitte.

BYOB  Not sure what else I can add to the 1281 reviews before me. I must be the last person in Chicago to have come here. For some reason it never made the priority list until we were invited by another couple last month.  Service was great, portions were generous enough that each couple split a filet (you get 2) and salad with out feeling hungry afterwards.  Good stuff and worth the wait on a busy night. With plenty of bars to visit on the street or a comfortable chair in the small waiting room one should not feel put out by the wait.  BYOB

This vegetarian approves of Tango Sur! We started with a bunch of appetizers so I basically took my entree (a spinach-stuffed pasta with marinara sauce) to go.  I enjoyed the Spinach Emapana. It was delicately crispy and piping hot.  The provoleta was a pipping hot plate of provolone cheese that you just stab with your fork and shove it into your mouth. YUM!  We also tried the Berenjena En Escabeche (eggplant and tomato dish that reminded me of lasagna.) Definitely recommended. The one drawback is the dinner salad. It was literally lettuce, slices of tomamtoes, and onions.  We came here after a Cubs game (note that the kitchen closes at 10:30p on a weekday, and it's BYOB), so hurry on here after a cubs game, and stop by 7-11 or Jewel to grab a bottle of wine on your way over. Overall, I'll be back here for sure! It's great with a big group too, as it's not incredibly expensive for what you get! The carnivores in our group loved it! #vegetarian review

Great quality food ... Inefficient service. My group of 8 went to Tango Sur after a Cubs game, tired and hungry, and we left with a food coma. In all, it was a 4 of 5 exprience, very intimate.  I ordered the MEDIO POLLO AL JAMON (half chicken), it was season and cooked to perfection, enough for 2. My wife ordered the CHURRASCO (12oz. steak) medium, it had an extremely charred exterior and rare on the inside. It was sent back for additional grill time (I grill a good steak, so I wasn't impressed). BYOB keeps the bill to a reasonable amount, $18-20/person. Although there's much WAITING in this place (with plenty of employees), the food is delicious.  Also, like most places around Wrigleyville, parking is an issue, but it's not the fault of this Argentinian steak house, just be prepared if you have reservations.

Great steak and Byob place. Be sure to bring red wine as the menu is mostly steak. We ordered the melted cheese appetizer but it really wasn't necessary. All you really need to get is the special flank steak for two. It comes with salad and potatoes and the tastiest chimichurri sauce. Highly recommended.  The atmosphere is daty. Low lights small tables and music. Came a second time and only ordered for myself. Had the flank steak again and it only added to my love of the place. The single serving was big enough for two meals. I can't wait to go back!

This is a great Argentinian steak house that definitely gives you plenty of bang for buck. Love the BYOB policy (the Jewel-Osco that is two blocks away has a good selection of wine.) Parrillada was great appetizer to share. Tried the filet mignon (comes with spinach mashed potato) and their rib eyes. Both were decent. They also have the best flan I have ever had.  Overall, Tango Sur is a very solid place. But if I can change two things about the place, I would probably suggest better lightening inside the restaurant (it is extremely dimly lit) and for them to carry better mustard than the just regular hot dog yellow mustard.
Noqui was dish, beef a little chewy. Overall atmosphere was great. Candlelight, romantic setting. Love that it's byob!

I'll keep it brief. The food is mediocre and overpriced. Nothing special about this place despite all the hype--as far as food is concerned. That said, service was fine and the restaurant is located in an amazing spot.
One of the best spots in Chicago but plan on a long wait on weekend evenings. Go early on a weekday and enjoy!

Mediocre food. Terrible service. First the food:  We ordered the antipasta. It wasn't bad, but at $9 for a small, uninteresting deli tray, I would not order it again. When we asked where the mortadella was, the server shrugged and said that he guessed they must be out. Good news: your $20 steak comes with a salad of lettuce, two rings of onion, and a big mealy tomato! My girlfriend and I both got steaks. My strip steak was good, but then it's probably harder to mess up a steak than make a decent one. One way you might do that would be to leave the membrane on my girlfriend's skirt steak. The provided knife was not wholly up to the task of cutting through it, but we managed to peel it off ourselves. The sides of Vesuvio potatoes were soggy. 20 minutes after our table was bussed and we finished our wine, we got our check.  Unfortunately, I messed up and forgot my card at the table. My fault. MAKE SURE YOU DO NOT MAKE THIS MISTAKE. I tried calling during the day the following Monday to make sure they had the card, but couldn't get anyone to answer the phone. I figured I'd just stop by, since it's not far out of my way home from work. I was kind of disappointed after I'd walked 6 blocks from the train station to the restaurant only to find out that even though it was 6:30 (they'd been open for an hour and a half), the manager "had stepped out, and would be back in 35-45 minutes". Well, these things happen, right? I didn't have time to wait around, but on Tuesday I made sure that I called and told them I was going to be there in 45 minutes to pick up the card, and wanted to make sure the manager would be there. "Oh sure. Come pick up your card." You can probably guess where this is going, right? He had just stepped out for 35-45 minutes. Now normally, this wouldn't be a huge deal for me, but both times I was left standing in the sun, outside for 10-15 minutes while some guy disappears inside. Their attitude was completely indifferent. Nearly every interaction I've had with them makes it clear they couldn't care less about their customers. Unfortunately, with 1200 reviews, this negative review won't pull their average down much, but I feel a bit better.

Tango sur is one of those great city restaurants someone has to tell you about.   They have no liquor license so BYOB with no corkage fee.  There is a great wine shop a block south and on  the opposite side of the street. Two of you can have an appetizer, dinner and desert and easily get out with a 60 dollar bill.   I would highly recommend the appetizer with cheese, herbs and red pepper.  Can't remember the name but you can figure it out. They have steaks, chicken and pasta.   Never tried any of the fish dishes. They do not take reservations for less than eight folks.  They will take your cell phone and call you when ready.   Nice Irish bar just south for a drink while you are waiting. Plan on 45 minutes on Friday and Saturday. Great spot

gave me an awful cut of steak and then tried blaming me for wanting it medium well. I explained that medium well doesn't account for tendons in a filet mignon, so he said it was my fault for not telling him when he never came by after the food came. they didn't offer anything as an apology for bad food (not even a recook).just awful...

Being a Yelper, of course I scoped out reviews for the people's favorite steakhouse in Chicago and came across Tango Sur. I thought I deserve the best for my first visit o Chicago and made my reservation a month in advance for this place for 2 people at 7:30pm. When we arrive at this quaint sidewalk steakhouse, the person up front told us that they were running an hour behind. So me and my friend went to walk down the block to a supermarket to get a bottle of wine and then went to a neighborhood bar to have a drink. When we came back, we were told that we would need to wait another 30 minutes. I wasn't happy but I already invested in a bottle of wine and an hour, and we were hungry, so what's another 30 minutes, right? Wrong. It started to rain... hard! The outdoor patrons were moved indoors one by one, and the wait turned into another hour and a half. So we waited for about a little more than 3 hours. The horror. It's not just the wait though, it's the attitude emitted by the very smug maitre'd who couldn't care less if you leave because they will always have business. It's the rain dropped into water containers and then poured into glass of customers, it's the paisan who jumps the line without a single word. It's the total lack of empathy towards customers.  Once we got inside past 10:30pm, we had bread to help with the long sufered hunger. I ordered the Parrillada Para Uno and my friend had the El Filet. The Parrillada was good other than the chewy and tough skirt steak and the overly soft blood sausage. El Filet is pretty soft and scrumptious. It's really good value for the price. I would be recommend this place if it wasn't for the horrible wait, but I just can't right now. 2.5 Stars.

This is a sad review. It's sad because I was so excited to eat the amazing food that 1200 other yelpers convinced me I would find here at Tango Sur. And I was severely let down.  It's become a pretty well known fact that I hate going into the city. The older I get, the further I want to be from the hustle and bustle and the weird smells and the non existent parking. But alas, one of my very dear friends was celebrating his birthday and chose to host his party here. The things I do for love. I spent an hour and a half in the car, then spent $16 to park in a lot because there was no street parking to be found. Dinner was a set price of $38 per person including 10% tip, so make it $45 per person because I'm not an a-hole. There were some appetizers. Meaning I had half an empanada. And there was a salad. But I was totally confused because the salad looked like what you get on the plate with a lox platter. Lettuce, two slices of tomato, and some raw white onion. Uhhh... Kay.  For my entree I ordered the bone-in ribeye. I ordered it rare because there were like 20 of us and I figured my food would sit under a heat lamp. So it came out and I took my first bite and it was dry and tough. Second bite was no better. It was really dark in there, possibly to make it difficult to see an overcooked steak. But I didn't need to see it to know it was cooked to at least medium well. I consulted with the people around me and all of their steaks were overcooked too, with the exception of the girl who had the filet. That filet looked amazing. So I definitely ordered the wrong steak.  The mashed potatoes were unforgivably bad. They tasted like they were 25% real potato, 75% boxed potato flakes. Mashed potatoes are like my favorite thing on the planet, but not when they come from a box.  Dessert was flan. I had a bite and I didn't care for it but flan is definitely an acquired taste.  2 stars because the service was excellent. Was my dinner worth the money? No. Was the company worth the effort? Absolutely. Will I come back? Probably not.

While not sure what I can add to the numerous reviews, I've ate here a few times over the years and have always enjoyed this place. The meat quality is decent, the prices are very reasonable, and of course its BYOB. We recently brought some out of town guests - they loved it. I got there first and added our names, so by the time the rest of our group came, the wait was not quite as bad, but still bad. The main downside is the massive waits. Oh my massive waits.

AVOID THIS PLACE IF YOU DON'T WANT TO WAIT INTERMINABLY. As a New Yorker, I am neither shocked nor immediately turned off by absurdly long waits. In fact, if I'm told that there's a 2-hour wait, I usually think of it as a testament to the restaurant's popularity & potential quality, and not as a nuisance. (If I've done my homework right, I also usually know to expect it.) What I absolutely CANNOT stand, however, is an obnoxiously cavalier attitude about wasting my time. Yes, I get that your restaurant has lots of people who would really like to be seated. But no, that doesn't give you the right to give us APPALLINGLY INACCURATE wait estimates. As always, rants can get long, so I'll summarize all you need to know before the jump: Food: 3 stars - average. The cheeses were bland, sauces were pools of oil mixed with chimichurri, and the meat was nothing to write home about (though there was a lot of it). Severely disappointing, given how good Argentinian-served meat can be ... and how hungry we were (don't people normally think everything tastes good, if they've been waiting 2.5 hours to eat?). Service/Seating: gets NEGATIVE stars, because: 1. the system is SO disorganized - the guy scribbles onto a pad, but there's little order (he just flips back and forth, to whatever he feels like), Even better, apparently THERE ARE MULTIPLE PADS - and you may be in one book, but not the other. Example that I witnessed: Maitre D.: "Ma'am, I can't find your name in this book..." The lady looks pissed and is about to start speaking Maitre D.: "but that doesn't mean you're not on the list! Don't worry. You're probably just in his book, another book which is over there. Don't worry.." [Hmm, if there are two separate books, and they're kept in two entirely different locations, how is coordination possible? (Here's a hint: it isn't.)] 2. This terrible, terrible seating system results in ridiculously inaccurate wait times. Now, I have enough friends who have been wait staff and etc., and I understand that not everything is in their control. But to be told it's a 1 hour to 1.5 hour wait, and then only to be seated 2.5 hours later (which is a 1-1.5 hour underestimation - basically a 100% margin of error) is simply unacceptable. ----------- The details - aka why I'm so angry that I'm using capslock: 3:00pm - I call as soon as they open on Saturday, to get a reservation and avoid the reportedly long wait. I am told that they are not accepting reservations, and that the wait for a party of four arriving at 7pm shouldn't be bad, about 45 minutes. 7:10pm - My friends and I arrive at the restaurant, we're told it'll be an hour to an hour and a half wait. Nevermind that it's about double of the 40 min estimate I heard on the phone, and nevermind that this other girl just says "we have a reservation!" and gets seated - I'm trying to be understanding, and just "put my name down," which was essentially watching as the dude messily scribble in a small 3x5 notepad (aka that 50 cent Staples pad). We head to Dairy Queen to kill time. 8:30pm - An hour and a half later, my friends and I go back to Tango Sur. The dude haphazardly flips between pages, occasionally ripping them out (and losing them to the wind) before locating mine. "We're running behind today," he says. What does that mean? "It'll be 45 more minutes." ... uhhh, whoa. My friends look annoyed (which always stresses me out, especially since I chose the place) but when we've already waited 90 minutes, what's another 45, am I right? My friends are starving, so we order drinks & appetizers at another place. 9:15pm - We still have not gotten a call from the restaurant, and it's been the full 45 minutes. Frustrated, I call the restaurant to inquire about how much longer. The guy tells me to come over. 9:17pm - We arrive at the restaurant, and the dude (.. same one it's been all night) tells us we can (FINALLY) go in ... to the waiting room. Can we order food? No. But we wll get the privilege of waiting inside! Oh my god, after TWO FULL HOURS OF WAITING, I actually get to wait in the heat?! It's our big break! By now I'm SUPER pissed, because this waiting game is getting really old, really fast. I tell him that waiting inside is pretty much the same as waiting outside, and we came over here under the impression that we were going to be seated soon. He gives me sass: "sometimes customers take longer - what do you want us to do, kick them out?" (uh, no - but you could certainly try proactive management?) By the time we're finally seated, it is 9:40pm. That is a full TWO AND A HALF HOURS that we spent waiting, basically DOUBLE the time he initially quoted us. If we had known from the start, we definitely could've explored an entire neighborhood and come back, as opposed to seeking shelter in the DQ ... ... aaand, that's the character limit (wow, anger really can be motivating ...)

This is probably my favorite place in Chicago. Tango Sur is a BYOB Argentinian Steakhouse on the Southport strip. I know it's probably been said many times, but there really isn't a better place to take a girl on a date if you are a guy: it's classy, it's meaty, and it's BYOB.  (Side note on BYOB, is there anything better if you are a guy trying to impress a girl? It looks swanky, you can pretend you have wine "knowledge", and it's cheap as s***)  Anyways, there is always a pretty long wait for this place (hour on weekdays, 2-3 hours on weekends), although I always seem to get in quicker than what they tell me. There are no reservations, but they'll take down your number to call you when a table is available, so you can go to any of the bars around to pass the time.  My girlfriend actually doesn't eat red meat, but she's a trooper and will still go along for the ride. She had the Gnoqui pasta one time we went, and had some kind of eggplant appetizer dish for her entree, which was actually pretty good, and I'm not an eggplant fan. My go to dish is the Bife Angosto, or the strip steak, with spinach mashed potatoes on the side. It is always a huge portion, and always amazing.  Also, be sure to get some of the empanadas to start, they come in a variety of options and are really good. If your date eats red meat, there is some kind of huge tray of meat you can get for two. I've never had it, but it looks like something one could only dream about. This is definitely a must go to place in this city!

This quaint little roadside diner serves up some seriously southern-sized portions. (Its name literally translates to "I have South!") If classic country cookin' and old time hospitality is your thing, look no further south than Southport and Grace . But if you're looking for something more than plantation sized steaks and generous helpings of mashed potatoes you might need to keep exploring.  *disclaimer: I am a bit pretentious when it comes to steaks.

One of the best steaks I have ever had! We had two Beef Empanadas as the appetizer  and one Lomo (Argentinian beef tenderloin). They were both awesome!  Lomo was big enough to share, with a flavor and tenderness you will not find anywhere else! Flan with dulce de leche and doble con crema (double espresso with foam) for desert. Waiting time is long (when we arrived around 6:45PM we were told the seating inside will be around 9:30).  Luckily,  we decided to stay outside and we got seated in 5 minutes. Seating inside is pretty cramped, but outside is perfect.  For chilly evenings, they even have gas heaters. This is a BYOB Restaurant, making life even nicer!

Tango Sur used to be a 5+ stars.  I don't like steak, but I crave a good one at Tango Sur, BYOB and their empanadas are delicious too! Never had bad food or service from the wait staff. Sadly they will NEVER get my business AGAIN. This is a long review, but I am shocked by their door hosts. 7:03 We showed up on a Saturday night expecting to wait an hour or more. We put a name for a party of 4 on the "list" (a tiny, unorganized notebook full of names and phone numbers... and scribbles). We were quoted an expected 1 hour to 1 hour and 30 minutes, first available. Fine. We had arrived about 45 minutes ahead of our friends for that reason. My husband and I go get drinks down the street, they will call when the table is ready. 7:45 Our friends show up at the bar. We ordered a round. 8:00 Another group (obviously from Argentina themselves) who put their names in just before us got their call and left. WE must be close! 8:25 No phone call yet, but we decided to walk back to the restaurant; our time was almost up! We asked the host politely how much longer. The host flips thorough pages and pages of names and tells us. "Uh, there are about 3 tables ahead of you, so 20 more minutes." He stated, "There have been a lot of pay and stays tonight."   I have been a hostess and I have experienced slow downs on busy nights. I am understanding.  9:00 Ask again, how much longer. Host "I don't have your name in my book anymore, so the other guys have it. Very soon, very soon." We have seen the "other guys" call people, but strangely, they seem to get the numbers straight from the head host. Hmmm... 9:15 It's 60 in July, and we have discovered that there is a waiting area inside, we must look miserable because we have been told "You're the next table.... inside." Us: "Could we just wait inside then in the waiting area (that is empty we have discovered)?" Host: " Someone will have to escort you in, we can't just let people inside."  Really? What club did we show up to tonight? 9:30 WE get called, this must be it, right? We were next.... 2 and a half hours?  No, wrong. We were finally escorted inside to WAIT, meanwhile there is almost no one waiting outside anymore, we have watched tables be seated and phone numbers called.  Quote "I feel like I have to be someone's cousin, or speak in Spanish with the host to get a table tonight." (This actually may be true....) We open one of our bottles of wine inside in the waiting area. We finish a bottle of wine. We go get another bottle of wine, two left to get four of us through dinner? Nope. Not after tonight. 9:45 While half our party goes to get wine, it appears that we will get called. Nope, that was the group of six that came in to wait AFTER us.  Then, the one of the hosts comes to get us.  Host: "2 for inside?" Us: "No, 4, but we've been waiting almost 3 hours, we will sit anywhere. They just went to get wine."  The host turns and practically runs away. Did we have a table or not? It seems that everyone else is getting one! 9:55 A group that has just arrived since the last is pulled to be sat. Desperately, I ask the last guy out of the room (they have a small party). "Excuse me, how long have you been waiting?" Guy: " Do you REALLY want to know? (Nodding yes.) 5 minutes... but we had a reservation." Us: "Really, for 3?" (They don't take reservations... read the other reviews.)  Guy "Yeah... how long have YOU been waiting." Us: 3 hours..." Guy: "What!?! 3 HOURS? Hold on..." The guy walks away, one minute later, he comes back and says," That table is yours, right there." Us: "What?" (Completely dumbfounded.) Guy: "Yeah, right there." He points and sure enough a table is being frantically set and  in the background, the host who so rudely walked away from us earlier is snapping his fingers at us from across the room (so RUDE!) and pointing to the table. 3 HOURS WAITING... Magically seated by a guy who got a reservation for 3 on a Saturday night at a place that doesn't take them? If not for this guy, who knows if we would have waited longer. WE have HIM to thank, whoever he is was. Does he work there? Is he related to someone who does?  Who knows, but HE was the reason we got our table.  Why did you wait that long?  That's stupid. Agreed, but the promising "you're next" and "very soon" comments kept us waiting. If I had been given an honest time in the beginning or if there was a system that didn't just seat those from Argentina or other hispanohablantes (there were many groups) first maybe it would not have been so long, maybe we would have gone elsewhere, but now I will never return. The food is amazing and the only thing positive in the night, if you go, go early on a weeknight, then you will not have to deal with that DISASTER of a rude and unorganized hosting staff. Unfortunately they probably receive a portion of the hardworking and friendly wait staff's tips.

So for years my friends talked about Tango but I had not gotten the chance to make it there. So finally decided to do an early dinner to beat the mad rushes that people talk about. I called when they opened to make reservations which they do not take same day. However they assured me I would be seated with no problem (8 of us in total). I got there and the host was standoff - ish and asked if I had called and left my name? I explained that I did call and did finally get seated but annoyed by his attitude. The server was super nice so that offset the host. We had churrasco which was good. I don't eat steak often but this one did not blow me away. The empanadas where great, we had a variety brought to the table and we enjoyed them all. The bread was super yummy and we closed our early dinner with complimentary flan. The flan was delicious. Nice close to our dinner... Overall good food but way too much hype when there is so many options in Chicago.

I went to Tango Sur with a few of my best friends for my birthday, on July 16th. My favorite appetizer were the empanadas (chicken and spinach with cheese). The entrees themselves looked and smelled delicious. I had the churrasco and the steak was pretty big. I wish I had ordered it medium, instead of medium well. It was a little tough to cut through, but it was still good. The servers were pretty attentive to our needs. So much so, I drank a gallon a water that night. My glass never got empty of water lol. I had the caramel flan for dessert and it was good, but a little too sweet and rich for me. Otherwise, the experience there was quite lovely. Tips And/Or Downsides: - Make sure to make a reservation. They won't sit you unless you're with your group. They gave me a bit of a hard time, but they were nice enough to let me sit with one of my friends at a table while I waited for the rest of my group. - Street parking might be a little hard. It might take you a while to find a parking spot, unless you pay for parking at a lot or do valet service. - Make sure to tip your server really well, especially if they've given you great service. You don't want them to be offended. - One restroom for the Ladies, from what I saw so far. I was able to hold it until after my dessert lol. - The lighting is really low (meant for a romantic and intimate atmosphere). If you have terrible eyesight, you may want to use the candle for lighting and/or have someone read the menu for you.

One of the best Argentinian restaurants I had already been in. We had el filet, empanadas and lengua (tongue) and all were great, specially the tongue - which surprised me a lot. Good service and cozy atmosphere. Highly recommended!

Very good service and food at a very affordable price. Both the warm interior and awesome patio offer a great atmosphere in a pretty cool area of the Southport corridor . It's BYOB, and the menu in general is great to pair with wine. The salad looks like hamburger toppings, but that's more of a funny observation than a complaint.

You get what you pay for.  It's cheap steak, and therefore, not high quality...at all.  I've been here multiple times, and each time, myself and others received tough pieces of meat.  If you don't care about the quality of your steak, like to order it well-done, and just want gigantic portions at low prices, this is the place for you.  Most folks who eat here are frat bro's just out of college trying to impress a girl.  Nothing wrong with any of that, but it doesn't fit the profile of legit, good steakhouse.   If you actually care about how your steak tastes and don't want to wait forever before you eat, you should go somewhere else.

Seriously One Of The Best Steaks I've had in Chicago!! Must try the El Filet.. It comes with two pieces of Prime Filets so tender and juicy.mmm always has me coming back for more. The prices are also Very reasonable and there's no corkage fee?? In the city this is unheard of lol. Great date spot or nice steak house to go with a couple of friends. Highly Recommend This place

I have been coming to this place for years, Its a BYOB steak restaurant. Great food, specially the meat. The only drawback is that is crowded and the wait can be over an hour on busy night. Once you are seated the service is good and the food is original from Argentina.  Prices are reasonable with ambiance being loud and the place is dark but if you are a meat eater this is the place to eat.

Excellent Argentinian food at a very reasonable price. Tango Sur is a Chicago institution and a visit will show you why. Dark, romantic ambiance, outdoor seating on the patio on Southport, and no fee BYOB all help make this place a winner. The wait for a table can be long, but they have a room where you can get a head start on whatever bottle you brought with you. Service during a recent visit was competent, but not great with some difficulty communicating about wait times. However, the highlight of the evening was the food. We ordered 2 empanadas (beef and corn, $2 each!), El Fillet, and the salmon (sadly, my friend is a pescatarian). The salad that came with the entrees was nothing special, but the bread was good: crunchy on the outside, soft and warm on the inside. The empanadas were delicious. The biggest surprise was the entrees, they were huge! The El Fillet came was two sizable pieces of tender, well-seasoned, delicious filet mignon accompanied by a mound of spinach mashed potatoes. The steak was probably 1.5 to 2x the size of the filet mignon at other steakhouses. The salmon was similarly massive and while it didn't rise to the level of the magnificent steak, my friend thought it was excellent. Though we were both hungry, we were left with almost half of the filet and more than half the salmon to take home. For the money ($27 for El Fillet, $25 for the salmon with many other entrees in the high teens or low twenties), it's hard to think of a better deal in Chicago.

Atmosphere :  Dark and intimate, try get an inside window facing seat.  If you don't you will be rubbing shoulders with randoms.  BYOB BYOB :)...  Service : GREAT SERVICE.     Above average.. on time , great recomendations Food:  HUGE portions.. I have been here 5+ times, I only rate places I have been to 4-5+ times....   First time I was stung, order their best cut of meat ( Filet) 2 large pieces came out, had to eat one and take the other home.   You can easily order a few appetisers and then split a filet between 2 people... Deserts are SPOT ON.    Highlight:  Filet is one of the best I have had, take it medium/ medium well.   Meat does not always have to be cooked medium rare, if it is fatty cooking it more helps the taste as it melts the fat away into the meat, for those meat professionals they will get what I mean.    get the filet and for desert the Flan is amazing.  And did I forget to mention BYOB, so get a nice bottle of wine and enjoy.

This place really impressed me. From the atmosphere to the service to the food Tango Sur was the best meal this weekend. I ordered El Filet, and couldn't have been happier with my choice. It was cooked to a perfect medium rare, tender enough to melt in your mouth. That was the first time I had spinach mashed potatoes, and now I wonder why I ever ate regular mashed potatoes! Around our table everyone seemed to agree that this place was top notch, you can't go wrong with great food and BYOB. Definitely a great place to bring a date as well.

Valentine's Day: My date and I decided Tango Sur was the place to go. Bad decision.  I understand that this Hallmark Holiday turns a bustling city full of restaurants into a madhouse. There's a difference between a restaurant being busy; and a doorman that can't be honest with you. This review will not be about the food. This is dedicated to the staff, and level of service. First of all, I had no trouble with my waiter. The rest of the staff that was directing traffic was overwhelmed and clearly not prepared to handle the kind of customer flow in the restaurant. I am an office manager. Part of handling busy crowds is learning when you're about to bite off more than you can chew. You don't want to turn customers away; but you have to put your foot down at some point and recognize when you're compromising quality of service, and over promising on wait times. These yahoos had no idea how to run a business. First of all, it's almost like a club when you walk in. Instead of a cultural experience, you feel like you're watching a bunch of dudes pretend to be F.O.B. Eastern European when clearly they're not. I felt like every person working, who wasn't serving food, or involved with the kitchen; had an attitude like their job was beneath them. I don't normally criticize people in the customer service industry, as I work in it myself. You have to put up a front while you're working; and you need to show some compassion for the customers that are willing to wait. My date dropped me off to put our names down for a table while he hunted for street parking. I walked in the door and the look I got from the door guy came across like, "I don't see your name on the guest list." Strike 1. I ask him for a table. Before I can even finish my sentence, he cuts me off and speaks condescendingly to me. "We have a wait. It's going to be an hour." I respond, "That's fine. Do you think it's possible that the wait could be longer than an hour because I don't want to wait longer." I didn't get a straight answer, just lots of arm gesturing, and stumbling over sentences. It was a simple question. The man is dressed like he's been working in a corporate office, with the slight flare that says, "It's Friday and I am hitting happy hour after work." Pretend pretend pretend... The door guy couldn't promise me anything. I invite him to be frank, yet he still chooses to stick to his YOLO attitude, and he refuses to take accountability for any time. "I'm sure it will be an hour, but if it runs over an hour I refuse to take blame for it." What the heck is that? I decide to leave my number on a list for the door guy to call me when the table is ready. I know my companion loves this restaurant so I opt to try and tolerate the staff attitude. My date and I decide to grab a drink at a bar across the street. An hour and 15 minutes go by. No phone call. So we call them. Still the same run around. By this time I am starving.  We gave it 10 more minutes and walk over. We get up to the door, and their faces automatically frown when their same lackadaisical attitude isn't tolerated from me for the third time. I am understanding. If you've made me wait an hour and a half and I have not gotten a table, then you should have been able to tell me that the wait was going to be longer than an hour when I first walked up. I expressed my distaste with whom I believe was the manager on duty. He had long hair pulled in a pony-tail. The man looks at me like his feelings are hurt. Really? Your doorman can't be realistic with me and you have the nerve to look at me like I should be keeping my mouth shut at this point? Seriously, I would have been ok with taking my business elsewhere instead of these heathens giving me the runaround, wasting my time.    The manager's resolution to the matter is to shove my date and I into a tiny room, serving as a waiting area, already filled to the brim with unhappy couples. It was ridiculous. I wish my date would have suggested for us to leave before even going to the restaurant. After waiting in the room, the manager starts addressing me as "senorita," thinking that is going to charm me into submission. I promptly responded to his dismissive attitude with what little Spanish I know; basically letting him know I am not impressed. This manager obviously thinks his appearance will compensate for his lack of experience. My date and I finally got a table.  If you go, expect to dine to techno music. I really think the staff wants to be in the Nightlife industry. Not foodservice. Even then, they would be inept if they had to run a club. They'd be too busy checking their faces in the bathroom mirror. What a narcissistic staff all around.  The food is just meat and potatoes, nothing special. My parents can cook the same way so I grew up on this kind of food. If possible, order it to go.

If you don't have somewhere to be later in the evening, this place is a MUST try. The atmosphere is romantic for a couple and fun for a group. I've been to this restaurant 4 times now and every time I've loved the food, service and atmosphere.  My fiance and I typically start off with a couple empanadas and then split the lomo. Its definitely enough food for the two of us and we always leave happy. Also, the back waiting room is nice, but be sure to bring an extra bottle of vino as its BYOB while you're waiting.

Excellent restaurant, if your a meat eater, and still good if your not I'm guessing.  Been here a few times and just thought to write a review. I'm sure of the multitude of reviews people have already indicated the known's... 1. NO reservations taken. can be a long wait. 2. very busy, tight waiting area. find a neighborhood bar to wait. But that doesn't deter me from going, I've just adjusted my expectations and times when I go. I can eat dinner around 6 to beat the crowd, on any given day. lol the staff is always helpful, the ambiance is that of an uptempo restaurant.  Here's an interesting plus the last time I was there.. A patron that was sitting next to me offered me and my date each a glass of a wine they had brought cause it paired well with the bone in ribeye. nice bonus, good selection. later found out it was a $50 bottle.  anyway. Tango sur is great except for the wait if you get there to late, but it's worth it for the great food. Enjoy
There is a reason why this place is a staple for Chicago dining. Great portions at a great price. Very good service staff. Bring a bottle of wine as it is BYOB. The dining area can get loud FYI.

BYOB at a steakhouse, enough said right? The food is great and the quantity they give you is enormous. Follow everyones suggestion to be a little patient since they do get extremely busy on the weekends but rest assured the experience will be worth it. Try the sweetbreads and then the bone-in ribeye.

This review is solely for the arrogant owner who would not even attempt to accomodate my food allergies. I called to make a reservation and to see if I would be able to dine there with gluten, soy and sulfite allergies. He refused to tell me how they marinate their meat or simply confirm these ingredients are present or absent in the specific menu item I asked about. He said it's a SECRET.  Bud, I don't need to know how many tablespoons of minced garlic you use. You turned away a viable new customer and the opportunity for other guests. Foo'.

BYOB! Awesome place! Careful with the empanadas and chimichurri! You can fill up on this pretty quicly! My suggestion is getting a bunch of empanadas and splitting a steak a dinner! Bring some beer and wine. Staff is super friendly and accommodating. Great for a date night.

Loved the food as usual.  Huge menu, a literal meat-heaven. Super loud this evening, a Wednesday night.  It started loud and ended louder as people had to shout just to be heard.   I'm on a Keto diet.  I skipped the potatoes and added veggies, but had to pay extra.  Would be nice if we were able to replace them for the potatoes.  I love the garlic mash, but just can't eat them now. I will continue to dine here, I can get over all those other things.

Food was good but the lighting is TERRIBLE! It's loud, and can accommodate larger parties. Make sure you get the complimentary bread with chimichurri... I swear that sauce pairs well with everything on the menu.
Best steakhouse for the price in Chicago.  You can easily split the filets and split an appetizer for a great date.  Plus you can sit outside and enjoy Southport.

I had read reviews that this place can get really crowded, even on a Tuesday so I called Tango Sur around 4:30 (they open at 5) and they had a ton of spots open for dinner time so I easily made a reservation for 6:00. When we got there, there were only a few occupied tables. By the time we left, around 7:30, it got pretty rowdy. To start, the place was REALLY dark inside. I understand "classy" places like to do that but it was too dark for my taste. We started off with drinks. My fiance got the cream soda ($2) and I got the fruit soda ($2). We both enjoyed our drinks very much. For our appetizer, we got the spinach and cheese empanadas ($2 each). They were pretty good. The crust was a bit too crunchy for me and I've had better at the Randolph Street Market. I got the Berenjena (oven-baked eggplant layered with spinach, provolone, parmesan, ricotta and a tomato cream sauce $10). It was really good! My fiance got the El Filet (Filet Mignon $27) that came with spinach mashed potatoes. He was not a fan of his dish. He said it was average and nothing special. We were pretty disappointed since we read how popular the El Filet was. I think one of the reasons this place is so popular is because you get steak with a BYOB policy.

The search for a great steakhouse continues.  Yelp has led me astray yet again.  Maybe it's that I'm from Oklahoma and we have steaks that were probably mooing yesterday, but this place was just ok.  Had a long wait despite a reservation, and was unimpressed with the food and sides.

I used to love this place but I ate there last week and the food quality has went downhill.  For steak being a specialty here it certainly didn't seem that way.  My friend and I both ordered the same cut medium rare and both came out charred.  Not only was it overcooked, more than half of the steak was gristle.  Anyway, I won't be back here for a while...they need to get their act back together.

If you haven't been here you need to give it a try. Given the number of reviews ahead of me this will only serve as white noise but I'll run you through what we ordered anyway. For starters the Spinach and Cheese Empanadas were pretty amazing. The filling had a nice blend of both and it was delicate and smooth while the empanada dough itself was tender, a little buttery and also delicate. These are a must try for sure. For a second app for our table we tried the Provoleta....Argentine provolone cheese grilled in a skillet with olive oil and mild roasted peppers. I don't recall if it was served with a bread of sorts but it should be, if you want to scoop this up even faster...though it was fantastic alone or laid over the empanada. For my entrée, I tried the Bife Vesuvio....a prime steak stuffed with spinach and mar del plata cheese, a garlic white wine sauce over that and then served alongside an Argentine style wedge potato. All I can say is, this dish is decadent on so many levels it's a little ridiculous...my only complaint was that the potatoes weren't cooked enough for my tastes giving them a little more bite than al dente. My entrée came with a simple salad that was a nice beginning to the end of the meal. The food aside, the ambiance is dim and a little romantic but maybe a little boisterous making it nice for groups. Given it is BYOB, and as Lucy G. noted...no corking fee, a group can have a pretty tremendous night here especially if you want to stay awhile and enjoy your evening with friends over some good wine and great conversation.  It can be a little noisy as mentioned and the space is a bit cramped too but settle in and order what piques your tastes...you'll likely love this place and need to return again for more.

I've lived around the Southport Corridor for almost a year now, but I never felt like I could lay claim to the area until I tried Tango Sur. I finally belong in the neighborhood! I'm not a fan of steak or hunks of meat in general, which explains my initial disinterest in Tango Sur. But over time, after seeing crowds surging at the restaurant, I decided I wanted in on the hype. And besides, I couldn't read through the appetizer section of the menu without my mouth watering. My friend and I ordered the addictive Provoleta Argentina, provolone cheese cooked on the grill with olive oil and roasted red pepper, almost as soon as we sat down. Melted cheese is my version of ambrosia, y'all. I do wish the provolone were served with something to dip besides the crusty, just-okay dinner rolls that come complementary at the table. For my main dish, I went with the Berenjena, oven-baked eggplant layered with spinach, provolone, parmesan, ricotta and a tomato cream sauce I'd gladly drink with a straw. Given the option of an inexpensive eggplant dish so divine, I can't imagine even wanting to order a steak at Tango Sur. (Seriously, that tomato cream sauce!)

Steak was good. I like the fact that many Chicago restaurant participate in BYOB. Wish more restaurants in LA had that option. This place reminded me of few places I've been to in LA. Waiters were attentive, fast and friendly. I can see why this place popular.  Just be prepared to wait, even with a reservation.
AMAZING!!! Great romantic atmosphere, excellent service, amazing steaks!! Plus its BYOB! What more can you ask for!

Excellent.  Went last night - group of 3.  Took 10 minutes to be seated.  Its byob so make sure to bring in a bottle of wine. No corkage fee!   We started off with the antipasto and a trio of empenadas.  The empenadas were flame!  For my main dish I got the El Filet which also was so good!  The other 2 got steaks as well and enjoyed em.  Our total bill was $105 for the three of us which is not bad at all for such a good restaurant.  Will def be back!

I have heard really good things about this place and have wanted to try it for a while so I took my boyfriend here for his birthday this year because he loves steak and it's a BYOB (no corkage fee!)...perfect match! Because it was his birthday, I did make a reservation (just the night before) even though it was a Monday. However, my friend said she waited for an hour and a half on a Tuesday, so I played it safe. They also told me I could bring in my own dessert for a small fee. I've been told and read it is one of the best spots for an intimate date, but it was nice outside so we took advantage of that instead. Service was a little slow at first (took at least 5 minutes for the waiter to come over). We started with some empanadas (beef, chicken, and spinach). They were very good and pretty large. I ordered MILANESA A CABALLO with a side of vesuvio potatoes and my boyfriend ordered the T.Bone. Mine was good, but the flavor of the T. Bone was delicious and it was very juicy. I think if I got back I will order the El Fliet. We ended up saving the dessert I brought for home because we were stuffed. All in all, it was a good experience! The bill only ended up being about $50 which was awesome (I bought a 750ml bottle of craft beer at Binnys). BYOBs are great for cheap meals while still being able to enjoy alcohol

BEWARE... TANGO SUR IS NOT WHAT IT ONCE WAS.  For a special occasion, my husband and I got a reservation at Tango Sur.  My husband had been there before, months ago, and loved it - RAVED about it, as many of these other Yelpers have.   Our dinner salads were un-inspired, but I was willing to let this go, looking forward to the main event.   I ordered salmon, but they were out, so instead I got the chicken (it was, again, uninspired).  My husband ordered a steak - cooked MEDIUM.   Pretty much everyone, we think, universally agrees that medium means there is some pink in the middle?  Well, the steak that came was completely grey, inside!  It was DONE to WELL DONE, no medium in sight.   We both looked at it, a few times, and agreed it really should go back.  It was just plain over-cooked.   My husband asked the waiter to come over, showed him the steak, explained that he'd asked for it medium, and politely requested a new steak - something he rarely, if ever, does.  Two seconds later, one of the higher-ups (we're not sure if it was a chef, or the manager) came over, and attempted to argue that the steak was cooked correctly; "for this cut of meat, this is medium".   My husband and I were horrified - who doesn't know what MEDIUM looks like?  Worse, who would argue with a customer, out in front of everyone?  The higher-up would not hear any arguments; according to him, we were wrong, and the steak was cooked properly, end of story.  In the end, he sent the steak back and asked for them to take it off our bill (which, at least, they did).  Any establishment that A) doesn't understand "medium" includes some pink, and B) would argue with a customer, over ANYTHING, really... doesn't deserve to stay open.  We were as nice as can be about it - we really were shocked and dismayed.   So - really think twice before dining here.  If you're looking for a great steak, or amiable service - go elsewhere.  Something has gone horribly, horribly wrong at Tango Sur.  It is no longer the establishment it once was.

Went over to Tango Sur because my dad was in town and wanted some meat. My dad walks is and told the host we had a party of four. He was about to be seated at a 4 top when I walked in with a stroller. All of the sudden, the table was not available. The host was very condescending and told us the table was not available because they have reservations. Being a resident of the neighborhood and having been to the restaurant a number of times, I know they don't take a reservation for 4. It was quite clear they didn't want the baby in the restaurant, even though it was 6pm on a Sunday. I could almost understand if they just said that they don't accommodate babies. But they were rude, condescending, and flat out lied to us. We were happy to take our business to Crosby's, where we had a delicious meal.

I loved Tango! I am not much of a meat-eater, but everything I had was delicious. I highly recommend the chicken empanadas. We also got the provoleta, which was fantastic, but far too much cheese for two people. Our appetizers were spaced out, which was nice, but by the time the main courses came we were pretty full. The atmosphere was romantic and casual, and we sat outside, which was perfect, and was certainly a little less noisy and crowded than inside. BYOB with no corkage fee. We were pleasantly surprised when I got the check-- the food was very affordable. We got so many left-overs and the food was all incredible.  My only complaint was that the service was a little slow. The main course took over an hour to come to the table, and we felt slightly forgotten. However, it's hard to complain too much because the food was great and we enjoyed the appetizers and atmosphere while we waited.  We will certainly go back!

i last came here on a date in march (but before that, it had been years and i wanna say they were closer to addison). it was packed, as usual, but the wait wasn't too terrible. the ambience is great-- dark with candlelight. the tables are a bit close together, but still not too noisy. the service was pretty good. we brought wine, which is a plus to the whole BYOB concept. we had the spinach and ricotta empanadas and the lomo relleno-- absolutely delicious! my date is from south america and he was impressed, so i was happy that he enjoyed it. definitely check it out if you have the time. tango sur is good for groups, too.

It's always a treat to eat at Tango Sur! I have been there several times over the last few years, I have yet to have a steak that wasn't yummy!  The fact that it's BYOB makes this place affordable.   It can get crowded, but I like going early on a Saturday and have always been seated right away.   Oh did I mention that they have outdoor seating?

I want to marry the man that brought me here on a date, then divorce him for not bringing me here sooner. This place is amazing. And romantic. And soooooo delicious. So we get there, put our name down, and the wait was probably close to an hour and a half. Luckily my date is a great conversationalist and it went by pretty fast. We were called, so we headed back and were seated immediately. Yes, I get that this place gets a little crowded but we got an adorable corner table by the window and quite frankly, the tables were close but not close enough that I could hear other conversations. It was very intimate. However, it is ridiculously dark -- I had to practically feel my way to the ladies' room at the end of the evening. But ambiance, whatever. We ordered empanadas for appetizers, and then steaks. The salad that comes with it was just whatever. Basic romaine, onions, tomatoes, with two vinegars. But good God -- my filet was honestly probably one of the best steaks I've ever had. Cooked perfectly, drowning in its own delicious juices. The spinach mashed potatoes were good too, but the chimichurri sauce was to die for. I'm drooling just thinking about it... ready to go back again. Anyways, fantastic service. Attentive staff. Plus it's BYOB (yes!) Really great place for a nice date, highly recommend!

This was a pretty cool little restaurant but I'm not sure what to do with it. I took the girlfriend out for a date night to plow through some beef. The wait was pretty substantial (Toons down the street is a great place to wait it out) but that was clear when I put my name on the list. The dining room was super dark and mostly candle lit which is nice for a date night but it was also way too crowded and loud which isn't ideal for the same purpose. The empenadas were a little dry but still flavorful. The real issue comes in with the steak I got. I don't remember what kind of cut I got but what does stick in my mind is how gristly it was. This really ruins a meat driven meal even though the sauces, sides and meat temperature were fantastic. I will definitely come back (probably with a more boisterous crowd) in hopes this steak was just a fluke.

Burt thinks this place is OVERRATED, OVERRATED, and SUCKS Burt read all the good reviews and was expecting a great dinner.  NOT.   The place is crowded.  Thats a good sign.  So Burt had a reso.  The reso is just to get you in the door and if your lucky they usher you to a small closet space in the back to wait, and wait and wait.  Burt tipped the door guy !!!!   Still waiting.  Just when Burt were about to leave they call us.   So we get to the dinner.  Empanadas for an app.  Bad !   We get our steaks.  A filet which is large, but not a good cut of meat.  Veiny with cartilage and tough.  I repeat, tough filet,  NOT GOOD.   The other steaks were not enjoyed either.   The coffee sucks. The only 2 good things Burt can say about this Shi!hole is the dessert and the wine was good.  Oh yeah, its BYOB, the wine came from The Wheelhouse, down the block.  If you suffer through a dinner here, at least order a the flan for dessert.    Burt says skip the joint.

Quite disappointed with this restaurant. I ordered the sirloin steak, and it was incredibly grisly and tough, so bad that I debated sending it back (which is something that usually never crosses my mind). My girlfriend had the grass fed sirloin which was significantly better, but still very over priced. The salad was a joke, a few pieces of lettuce with an under ripe tomato, onion, and oil and vinegar as the only dressing option. The potatoes that came with the steaks were bland and dry. On a positive note, I really liked the ambiance of the restaurant, and the chimichurri dipping sauce for the steaks was very good.

Tango Sur is a great place to dine when craving steak.  Mmmm steak...  I recommend coming here for a date or small group.  They really pack you in here, but that's part of the fun.  The steak here is really good, not the best I've had, but for the price you can't beat it.   They don't take reservations here, unless you have a party of 6+, and this place is always packed so expect to wait.  However you can leave your name and number and they'll call you when your table is ready so you can walk to a few different bars right around there for a drink while you wait.  It's BYOB here which is awesome so make sure to stop by the liquor store if you plan on getting your drink on. The staff here can come off as rude, but they're always crazy busy and they do their best to get you seated and your food out to you without a long wait so I can put up with it.  The ambiance here is cool - dark, intimate, good music.  Overall this is a great place and will be one of the cheaper steak dinners you'll have in Chicago that doesn't sacrifice quality.

I've been dying to try this restaurant. Its a really small restaurant, not a lot of seating. I had the El Filet and it loved up to all the rave review. Tender and well seasoned. I like the spinach mashed potato's just added a little salt. It's byob. There's a jewel and cvs down the  street just in case you need to stop and by some wine.

Tango Sur is our favorite steak-date place in the city. The filet is honestly the best I've ever had (you get two!), the spinach mashed potatoes and chimichurri are fabulous and plentiful and the service has always been top-notch. I honestly can't say enough good stuff about this place. We usually put our name in, then scoot down the street for a drink while we wait. Normally we get the call that our table is ready before we finish our first drink. Last summer when we were there, the table next to us (of 8) played CCR for the tab - hilarious and awesome.

First of all, the waiter said there are no substitutions so be prepared for that. The "Salad" consists of a half-plate of bits of romaine, two slices of tomato, and three circles of white onion. Not a great start to the meal. The portion size of my steak was small for the price. The other three members of my party received very generous portion sizes (including two petite filets for the party member that ordered their filet mignon). The food was pretty good and was prepared well.  The service was top notch; rare was my glass empty. They also don't have an uncorking fee for your BYOB. I also wanted to share that it was too loud for conversation less than shouting. I've heard this place can have a bit of a wait but we arrived early enough to avoid any wait ourselves. The place is pretty cozy so it doesn't take much to fill it up quickly.

I read a lot of good reviews on yelp for this restaurant so my boyfriend and I decided to try it out. From other reviews I saw that they didn't take reservations and the wait is long, which was true. We got there around 6:30 on Saturday night and waited for an hour and a half. There isn't really a waiting area and they didn't seem to like us standing around so we walked to pick up our wine and grabbed a drink a bar next door. Even at 9 we saw people coming and having to wait a while. The restaurant has a fun and lively atmosphere. I'd have to say the wait was worth it. The food was amazing and you will have plenty of leftovers. We got the fried provolone cheese as an appetizer which was awesome would definitely suggest getting that. I got the half chicken limon-delicious and he got the El Filet-got two huge pieces. Overall I'd highly suggest going to this restaurant even with the long wait it was totally worth it, affordable, and PLENTY of leftovers. Plus it is BYOB :)

I really struggled between 4 and 5 stars. The ambience was great-- granted we went on a Monday night when it was quasi-chilly so we were the only outside table. We got the provoleto or something like that--- it was a giant bowl of provolone cheese with roasted red peppers, way too big for two people... Four people it would've been PERFECT.  It is a BYOB restaurant so we brought two bottles of wine and they graciously corked them for us. We opted to share the Lomo Relleno between the two of us. it was more than enough meat. We initially asked for it to be cooked medium-rare but it was recommended that we go with medium. When we got it, it was obvious that it was still cooking at the grill that was out our table. We wish we would've gone with medium-rare as medium was a bit more than what we desired. The very innards were will pinkish red; however not much beyond that was pink. There was just more flavor in the very center. I recommend that you ask for more chimmichuri as it is DELICIOUS. Service was good. Food was good. We'd go back.... Maybe with a party of four. There was just too much food for two people. We have leftovers in our fridge. :)

Excellent place. Ordered a beef and a spinacn empanada and the filet with spinach mashed potatoes. It was awesome! BYOB makes this place affordable. Waiter was attentive and efficient. Definitley want to go back.
Sooo yummy!   Pros:  amazing food, Byob, friendly staff Cons: very busy, no reservation
Pork chop was okay. Veal tbone medium was delicious. Normally do nott eat medium but this was good. Really Good.

My husbands favorite place in town! He always gets el filet. I'm not a huge red meat eater, but I've tried about 6 different meats. They are all good, just don't ask for it well done unless you want it charred. We've been with large groups many times, or groups of 4. It's a great group place since it's BYOB. I highly recommend the hot appetizer of veggies topped with tomato cream sauce. Kind of heavy, so we usually share between 4 of us, but it's so good every calorie is worth it!  Not a place to be rushed. Last time we went we were there 4 hours...

3.5 I was looking for a meat-tastic place to take my man for his birthday - Tango Sur topped the list in my steak search and I was anxious to try a smaller, more intimate place. I made a reservation for two, but I don't think it mattered because we showed up shortly before the place maxed out so there were plenty of empty tables.  We enjoyed our byo-wine at our little table complete with lit candlestick and started out with some empanadas.  The empanadas (spinach and cheese; chicken) were the highlight of the meal for me...   Birthday boy ordered some side sausages + a big steak that came with a heaping pile of mashed potatoes.  They were completely out of all fish options for the night (what??) so I went with lemon chicken and potato spears.  I thought the chicken was over-seasoned / too salty, and it was swimming in an oily sauce - I didn't end up eating much of it.  Before entrees were served, we had a very simple salad of greens, onions and tomatoes.  Because of the birthday, we were presented with a cute little flan before getting the check.  This was very rich and tasty - a nice end to the meal.  Verdict: Loved the interior - small, cozy, candlesticks everywhere.  Service was attentive and prices fair.  Wasn't that impressed with food (with the exception of the awesome empanadas) - steak was pretty fatty / not a great cut.  I would go back, but would order a different entree.

This place reminded me of places I've been to in Europe and South America, the candles on the table and the simple, shareable dishes. We had tried to go here one other time at around 7pm on a Saturday and there was a 2 hour wait so we came early (around 4pm) and was seated immediately. They had Inca Kola from Peru which I begged my bf to try (it's like a Mountain Dew but better). For apps we got empanadas, the spinach and cheese was a favorite and the chicken was tasty. We also got the cheese appetizer which was greasy and literaly a bowl of melted cheese. I had no idea how to eat it so I put it on the bread, and still got it everywhere. We got an assortment of meats to share that came with a salad (lettuce, tomato, onion, oil and vinegar-- no frills and pretty disappointing). The meats came out on this grill thing that was cool looking and had 5 kinds of meat. The chicken was alright, the steaks (there were two different kinds) were both really tasty, especially with the oil and parsley sauce that came with it, the chorizo was good, but the blood sausage was not, it exploded when my bf cut it open and when I took a bite it was a mouthful of fat....sooooo gross. Minus that, really can't complain we left very satisfied and had leftovers in tow.  A nice date spot, but not for vegetarians or the vegan folk.

I had a lot of expectations going into this visit as everyone I know raves about this place, it totally lived up to the hype. We ate outside on a beautiful day, I'm glad we were able to sit outside because the only negative thing I can say about this place is the inside is pretty small. The service was outstanding, we brought a bottle of wine since its BYOB. I had bread beef, top with baked ham and mozzarella. The baked cheese was also a good appetizer. Both came in big portions.  Perfect place to bring a date. Cannot wait to come back.

For some reason, I've never wanted to go to Tango Sur.  I'm not sure why - probably mostly because I don't often go out for steak and I like places where I can get smaller portions (if I want...obviously there are those days where you want LOTS OF FOOD!). However, a friend wanted to go here and I agreed.  I wish I would have known it was BYO because I have plenty of wine at home, but Jewel is just down the block, so it's not really an issue.  Also, having a 30 min or so wait allows for drinks at the bar next door or a trip to buy wine at Jewel (or both!). We shared a few things at the restaurant and I had never been there and was pretty hungry, so I opted to let the waiter give suggestions.  We shared 2 empanadas, the hearts of palm with prosciutto and then shared a (massive) traditional steak.  We ordered the steak off of the 'special' menu and I thought it was delicious.  The potatoes were also lovely.   All in all, it was a great spot.  I noticed that most everyone in there was on a date or else with a large group of friends.  It's dark and dim and very boisterous and fun.  Definitely a good spot for a friend's dinner, date or group spot. Service - 5 (spot on with the wait time, too!  Also awesome since I think we were gone longer than we were told the wait was and they didn't give away our table). Food - 5 Bathrooms - 4 Value - 5 (yay byo!) Atmosphere - 5

Never been to an Argentinian steakhouse before so I didn't know what to expect. This restaurant is very small but in a good way, it gives it a more cozy feel! The staff were friendly and attentive.  We didn't make a reservation but I heard its highly recommended especially for bigger groups cause the wait can be long. We went around 9pm and got seated in 30min. It was a BYOB place so you can buy whatever drinks you want, bring it to the restaurant and drink it while you wait!  We ordered provoleta for our appetizer. It is Argentinian provolone cheese cooked on a grill and it just melted in your mouth. Also had the tortilla de papa- so good! These two made a good combo. Put the melted cheese on top of the tortilla, amazing!! I had the El Filet which was the filet mignon special. It was so good.
