Tango Sur has been reviewed to death already So, I'm just going to keep this brief. Great food. Good value for money. BYOB. Sorta random but, really gracious service. Gets quite busy because of all these things. Plan accordingly. Bring your patient hat. Leave your damn pram at home. Totally enjoyable. Give them your money, you won't be disappointed unless you're a total jackass that is impossible to please. **AND, please go read Colleen C's "BYOB etiquette" commentary before going to Tango Sur**

We went here for a friend's bday dinner and the place is a little quirky.  First of all it is not a huge place, but they were able to squeeze us in at 5pm, which was nice.  It is byob and they have no corking fee which is another plus.  They did however make up for this by charging $20 for allowing us to bring in a cake.   My meal consisted of a spinach empanada, the berenjena, and the papas vesuvias.  The empanada was good and the chimichurri sauce complimented the spinach and cheese filling nicely.  The berenjena was excellent.  It was baked eggplant with spinach and a few different cheeses topped with a tomato sauce.  It was almost like an eggplant parm, without a lot of the unhealthy parts like the breading of the eggplant.  My friend who frequents this place, and actually orders the steak said the eggplant was the best thing on the menu.  The potatoes I could have done without.  They were just ok and really I just used them to soak up the extra tomato sauce from the berenjena.   The service is a little off here.  At the start of the meal I felt like it was just bad.  The waiter just seemed to give a 3 minute monologue without taking a breath on the menu and specials and then just left.  When I ordered a meal without steak, I got an incredulous look and he asked me twice if I was eating eggplant as my meal.  At the end of the day, it wasn't too big of a deal.   The steaks seems to come out rarer than were ordered.  Most of our party of 12 had this happen, so I guess order accordingly.

I've been meaning to go here for YEARS, but for some reason it would just never work out. We finally made it for an anniversary dinner. Appetizers: Chicken Empanada was awesome - crispy, flaky, well spiced and all around perfect, but the prosciutto and hearts of palm fell a bit flat. More than anything, the prosciutto was fairly bland. We also ordered a side of the Chorizo sausage. Order this. Seriously. I nearly fell out of my chair it was so good. My wife and I shared the Vacio, which is a large portion of meat (flap meat? Not familiar with that cut, but..) that's highly seasoned and very tasty. There are some fatty/gristly parts, but it wasn't too bad in that regard. We ordered it medium, and it was more of a solid medium rare, which pleased me but not my wife.  The pesto-like sauce they give you is excellent, and as a hint, try it with the bread!  I think it was a bit disappointing to eat on a brown sheet of paper in a place like this. I understand the food can be a bit oily & greasy, but... It was dark, but overall seemed clean. The bathrooms were well maintained.  Service was forgettable - slow and inattentive, especially for a fairly uncrowded Monday night. We sat for long periods of time with empty water glasses. It took 15+ minutes after we ate to get our server back to order dessert. Dessert was served on a table full of food & bread scraps (my wife is the slob!) and nobody made an effort to clean them up at all. I sat with my credit card hanging out of my check for probably close to 10 min, and it wasn't picked up until the host saw me looking annoyed.  Price - very reasonable! Especially since it's BYOB w/o a corkage fee I'll be back - even if it's just to get more of that chorizo sausage
I went here recently for a friends birthday.  The food was good, but the service was a little slow.

It's my birthday week, so I had the urge to go celebrate with a LOT of wine, and had hopes of consuming some good prime steak. Kind of like ex-Bull Dennis Rodman, I celebrate my birthday week not just the day itself. We started by walking up to the much hyped Tango Sur at 9:45 on a Saturday night. The pompous host-not a maître d', took our name, cell # and promised to call within the hour. While patiently waiting down the street at Cullens, for well over an hour, we walked back to Tango Sur.  When we walked up to the host stand, pompous host himself looks at us, asks what we need.  Wife: {scowl on face}  Me: Welllll, I'm " Scott B." and you said that you'd call "within the hour?"  Pompous Host: Oh, Scott, I tried calling you.  Me: I pulled my phone out of pocket, and showed him that there were no missed calls.  Pompous Host: Uhhhh, oh, maybe I called someone else.  Me: Uhhh, yeah, maybe that's the case.  The pompous prick of a host, walked in "to check" if a table was available. About five minutes later, he, from a distance, waives us inside. I guess he skipped the manners class as a child?  With so much hype and extreme demand for a table, I was expecting to see Hugo Chavez and Sean Penn sharing a bottle of wine. Fortunately, this was not the case, but the place was buzzing.  After finally being seated, I opened my mind, and was looking forward to Tango Sur living up to their Yelp-a-tation. About 10 minutes later a server came by with some wine glasses, and opened our bottle of wine. (No corkage fee) Both wifey & I did notice that the prices seemed quite low for the entrees. The server took our order, and both of us opted for the "El Filet" at a very reasonable price of $24. As discussed, the server took our order, but not without asking on 3 separate occasions if we wanted an appetizer. I wasn't aware that after 38 years, I just picked up a speech impediment?  About 30 minutes later (getting hungry), the "El Filets" were delivered to our table. Jesus! What a lot of meat! The "El Filet" is actually 2 filets, that are probably at least 10 ounces each. Of course I was thinking, how the hell could they sell "prime" beef at these prices.  The "El Filets" were accompanied with spinach mashed potatoes. Now, these were some damn good mashed potatoes. The filets though were average, at best. Granted, they were prepared at a perfect medium rare, but this "grass fed" crap was hardly prime beef, in my opinion.  What I do credit Tango Sur on is the brilliant marketing team that successfully presents this sham as a first class place for steaks. Brilliant, absolutely brilliant! Just place a trendy restaurant in the affluent Southport corridor, and they'll come!  Won't return. I'll gladly pay $42 for a true prime steak at Kinzie, Keefers, or Ruth's, where I'm treated like a majority shareholder, and the quality of the steaks are second to none.

I oh so badly want to give them 3.5 stars but alas, I'll settle for the higher end of the spectrum since I'm such a nice gal. The food here is absolutely amazing. Well, except for the salad which looked more like a side platter with burger fixings (big leaf lettuce, tomato slices, and onion slices). Everyone who had a meat dish (except for three boys at our table) ate less than half of what was on their plate. YOU SHOULD SHARE. SHARING IS CARING. Plus, it makes this already inexpensive dinner (woot woot BYOB no corkage fee!) even less pricey. And be sure to try the spinach/cheese empanada. The sauce they serve with it is full of garlic but it's worth-avoiding-making-out-with-a-stranger-at-the-bar amazing. I could literally go there just to order empanadas. But be prepared for the worst, rudest, slowest service ever. And make your reservations!

Tango Sur is definitely one of those restaurant experiences that make me miss Chicago. (And eating meat!) I had a great, crowded time with three friends. I remember feeling cramped but not caring much because the food was all delicious. It has a dark interior, but its lively patrons brighten up the room. The prices are high, and the wait is long, but Tango Sur is worth at least one visit if you're in the mood for amazing meat.

Love, love love! This BYOB restaurant was one of my favorites when I lived in Chicago.    The food is a-maz-ing and priced extremely well. I recommend the Vacio, which is a large cut of meat that comes out on a platter designed to serve two.  The meat was beautifully seasoned and cooked just right.  The Vacio comes complete with mashed potatoes and 2 simple salads all for $35!  The empanadas are some of the best I have ever had, and are only $1.75 each!  I'm not sure what the garlic sauce served on the side is (maybe some sort of chimichurri?) but it was wonderful!  I wish I could buy a bottle of it to take home.  The two things keeping Tango Sur from 5 stars is #1, they don't take reservations for smaller tables and #2, the restaurant is small and the seating is very close together.  My boyfriend is a taller man with broad shoulders, and the poor guy kept getting bumped by each server and diner  that passed by our table.

Our original plans for the evening didn't work out, so we were on the hunt for a place to eat.  I'd heard people rave about Tango Sur, and we were in the area, so it seemed like a perfect choice. We sat outside, ready to order wine.   Alas! It's a BYOB place.   We sadly agreed to stay sober and ordered our food.   Alas! My choice of entree was not available that evening. I chose another, the El Filet. Hungry, we dug in to the bread rolls.  The empanadas came, and we dug into those delicious pockets.  The pesto they served with the empanadas was also delicious. Soon after, we were served a plate of garnishes: bitter greens, large slices of tomatoes, and rings of fresh onion.  I thought that this was a prelude to the entree, that everyone got a place of fresh veggies to go with their meal.  But no...it was the pre-dinner salad.  The salad was fine (who can go wrong with fresh veggies), but the presentation was way off - since when do I have to cut up salad ingredients into bite size pieces?  Very odd. After the salad, I was full (my own fault, having eaten 2 bread rolls in addition to the empanadas) and cursing myself for having ordered a heavy meat entree.  I was sure that I'd have to ask them to wrap it up to go. A loooooooooooong time later, our entrees arrived, and the portions were huge!  Huge as in, had I not filled up on bread and empanadas, I would not have been able to fit it all into my stomach.  The meat was juicy & very good, and the spinach mashed potatoes were simply green colored garlic mashed potatoes (good, but spinach colored, not spinach flavored).   Overall, the food was good.  The empanadas were special.  The lack of alcohol was a bummer and the wait for the food (on a Tuesday night) was excessive.  I would recommend coming here for a quick & lighter meal (i.e. order the empanadas and nothing else) unless you want to spend your entire evening at dinner (and hey, sometimes that is exactly what you want to do).

HOST is ARROGANT and Unprofessional We were very excited to try this place after a local friend recommended it. The host kept telling us 45 minutes wait after an hour and a half wait. When I told him I was unhappy with his inaccurate waiting time estimates, he was so arrogant that he said "that's the way it goes... I can not do anything when people sit here all night". We decided to leave since he was so rude and we ended up having a great dinner at CoalFire. The place is pretentious and not worth dealing with such an incompetent host.

The staff was extremely attentive, they were able to accomodate us even that the reservation was messed up and there was a waiting line of 3 hours. The food is superb, the cuts are flawless, it was heaven in my mouth... BYOB is always a nice feature, but I wasn't in the mood that day.

El Filet along with the spinach mash potatoes were amazing. I came with a group of about 17 and they sat us at our 9:15 reservation, no waiting!!! I just wish they had a better AC system but I don't think any system could've kept us cool considering it was 90+ and humid outside.

Be careful what you order, because the MEAT can overwhelm you, the juices drip on your nice pants and you can happily drift off into a corn fed american beef coma with the delicious chimichurri dripping off your chin.  It's nice to be able to bring your favorite reds to a BYOB with no corkage fee.  Most folks seem to prefer the filet, a ginormous chunk of  beef and gravy, though I prefer the parillada - the mixed grill of steak, short ribs, sweetbreads, etc. and the sausage here is delightfully different.  Empanadas here are yummy too and dinner for two is very reasonably priced.

7 girls, BYOB, great food & service = an unforgetable evening! The beef dishes are extremely juicy and cooked to order, perfection! The chimichurri sauce is absolutely delicious! The spinach and cheese empandas were tasty and crispy. I love that they serve their bread fresh from the oven! If you are an eggplant lover you MUST to try their eggplant pasta! Have to be the best pasta I've ever had. We had reservations, but still had to wait about 40 minutes because it was extremely busy. Thank goodness for BYOB. The service was quick and helpful. Noise level is quite loud so not ideal for romantic dates if your partner is the quiet type.

Were were a party of 6 and decided to try Tango Sur because they're BYOB and they take reservations. I was really looking forward to it because there is always a wait outside, and I love the kind of food they serve. It was just ok. First, they ushered us into this dark cave like waiting room and left us there for about 10 minutes. I would have preferred to wait outside instead of in an airless room. Second, they give you a dining window; ours was supposed to be 7-9pm. However, they didn't seat us until 7:20 and then were trying to usher us out at 9. Throughout the meal the server was hustling, trying to get us out of there quickly. I didn't appreciate that.  The food was just ok. The biggest thing it has in its favor is that it's BYOB, but I won't be going back.

MEAT MEAT MEAT MEAT. We walked in on a Saturday night, no reservations, table for 2 immediately. NICE.  Romantic setting, candelight, and MEAT.  Our server was a little pushy in telling us to get the "specials" which for the life of me I couldn't really figure out the difference. Anyways, we settled on beef & spinach empanadas, the tortilla argentine, rib eye for me, and sirloin for her. The empanadas are super affordable ($2 each) and very tasty, served with a chimicurri sauce. We had the beef once (very good and spiced ground beef) and the spinach one (so-so). The tortilla espanola like dish was very flavorful (but lacked some punch) and a great portion size. Then came the rib eye. OMFG it was good. Cooked perfectly medium rare, aged, tender, juicy, and HUGE. This thing was like a baby, prob 15+ oz. DId i mention they cooked it perfect medium rare? So good. I had like two bites of the potatoes (which are like roasted potato wedges doused in butter), but focused on the meat. They also give you a great red wine / shallot/ garlic sauce to dip the meat in. So good. She found the sirloin to be really good as well (although I still prefer the rib eye for its tenderness).  Overall, good meat, nice setting, BYOB (no corkage fee), and also great prices (we got out under $70 with tip for a full on steak dinner). The only reason why I take a star away is the service. I found our server to be WAYY to pushy in the specials, and when i ordered he cut me off and said "i really think you need to order the specials". when i conceded to ordering the meat off the non-domestic page, he hurriedly swept my menu up and said "okay fine". LEGIT meat.

You won't exactly believe your'e in Buenos Aires, but you'll have a great meal. The empanadas were pretty good, and the steak I had was great... for corn-fed American beef. I brought the GF here for a nice date. The portions are big so we split the empanadas and the steak. It worked out perfectly. It's really nice to sit on their patio in the summer. I dont know if you can make reservations or not, but you should try because it gets really packed. Don't forget to bring a bottle or two of some good malbec.

Good portions.. but the meat could be more tender and less fat. The wait (for the food after getting a table) was long around 40-45 min... The appetizers weren't as impressive. Overall, decent food, decent atmosphere but not a "wow" experience. Helps if you're patient and have fun buddies with you when you're there... Be ready to wait, wait, and then wait some more... for the table AND be ready to do it again for the food...

Tango Sur was my first BYOB experience at a restaurant and from what I remember it was amazing. Oh yeah, the steak was slamming too. I definitely recommend coming to this restaurant but make sure you make reservations, because this place is PACKED. Oh yeah and bring some extra candles or a flashlight cause it's dark as night in this place. Overall, the food was great, it wasn't terribly expensive, and I got to drink a 40 while enjoying my meal. Boom

Unimpressed. It's a bit upsetting considering the sheer quantity of positive reviews of this place, but when it comes down to it, the atmosphere wasn't enough to get me to come back. Tango Sur, I tried you back in the fall/winter of 2009, and we ate inside. We were cramped next to an awkward first date (as your tables are so incredibly close to one another), so while it was entertaining to listed to hilariously painful first date questions, it was not what I would call private. The salads were disappointing, the steak was somewhat gristley, and the wait was almost not worth it. And then friends told me to go back and sit outside. I bought a bottle of wine from the little wine shop on Southport, and and we sat and waited for our food. And we waited a little longer. The wait for the food was pretty ridiculous, around 30 minutes for my steak and my wifes ravioli. Again, the food wasn't great, and the wait time between order and getting food was long. The wait time between finishing food and getting our bill was even longer. Long story short, I'm so over this place. You can go here for dinner if you want, but be ready to wait.

I go back time and time again for the great atmosphere, the low lighting and BYOB no corkage fee! Staff is friendly and knowledgeable and the food is amazing!!! I love the simple salads that come with dinner, just oil and vinaigrette. Very good and it never gets old!! Now that the patio is open its even better!!!

The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is because of the rude host....I get they're busy and all, but please be nicer to people waiting outside...And don't lie-if the wait is 2 hours, tell me that, and don't say 45 minutes and when I come back to check on progress you're telling me another 30 minutes....The food makes up for it...never had a bad steak here, so tender and juicy...and the prices are very reasonable.

Apparently I am Tango Sur reviewer #640.... Apart from that, I went here with a birthday party. I've read many low-rated reviews, and a lot of 5-star reviews. My experience at Tango Sur merits a big, fat 2 stars.  For starters, this place is always busy. Allow the hurried waitstaff to do their thing; they'll get to you sooner or later. The food is yuppiefied Argentinian cuisine - no question about it.  If you never had Argentinian-style meat, then you'd probably think you're having a great meal at Tango Sur. However, Argentinian steak is supposed to have a crispy exterior with a soft interior. Hard to do without a wood-burning spit, but it can be done as evidenced at other restaurants. At Tango Sur, steaks pretty much all taste like each other - all mainly gummy, thick American steaks with a bit of seasoning to be less American. I don't know why the menu lists so many variations of steaks and prices when they all appear to be the same, slightly improved versions of what you'd get at Morton's.  One member of our party brought along cupcakes for after dinner. I know this irks some restaurants, but most allow it to occur with big parties. Not at Tango Sur. Our waiter saw the container of cupcakes and threatened that he would add $1.75 on the bill for every cupcake consumed. I am not exaggerating. We then politely asked for the dessert menu. He said he'd get it. 35 minutes passed, no dessert menu arrived, and our group of 14 decided to leave. I'm usually pretty cool with the shortcomings of restaurants as it's a crazy business, but I'd never expect such a low caliber to every aspect of our dining experience from a highly-esteemed restaurant.
Great restaurant! Waiting time is terribly but when you enter you'll appreciate it!

Finally made my way to Tango Sur. After hearing about this place from a gf of mine who always took her bf here, I don't know why I never made it here soon. Especially because I love meat, and BYOB any place-- even if it were a prison...ok, bad joke. The space is a little cramped, but maybe that is because I came here for a large party. From what I can tell, the general consensus is YUM on the "El Filet" and empanadas. Almost everyone at the table(couples) split empanadas (spinach/cheese ones are great) and the Filet. It was quite the suitable dinner, accompanied by rolls, an amazing pesto sauce with just about everything AND a side salad (though not impressive). Some others got a huge chicken dish and the gnocchi which could feed you for 2 more meals. Leftovers galore! BYO plus super cheap to split, this place is def. a dating staple.

AWESOMENESS .. I always take friends there for big group get togethers or when people are visiting from out of town. Sometimes there's a wait, but I live close by so it's not bad. The customer service is good .. it's BYOB ... I love the atmosphere .. bit fan!
Been here twice now and enjoyed both visits. Steaks and chicken were cooked perfectly. The atomsphere is intimate both inside and outside. Great value for the price.

Get over it - the wait is going to be long for any good restaurant that doesn't take reservations.  If you want a reservation, go to Folklore (their sister property on Division St.).  Aside from the awesome spinach empanadas (just the right size), the chimichurri (yummmmm!) and sausage (made from scratch by Che Rodolfo, the owner's dad in the store next to the restaurant) and the meat, the FLAN is the BEST FLAN EVER!!!!!

I enjoyed this place A LOT! The food was amazing, and this place really knows how to cook meat. I got the Vacio and my date got the Filet. Both were excellent choices. For the money and the quality of food, this place is top-notch. I'll definitely come back to this place again.  But, just be prepare to wait in line. We sat on the terrace so we didn't have to wait.  Pros: Food, Price, BYOB Cons: does not take reservations for small groups and long lines

I tried Tango Sur for the first time last night with my roommate and we both absolutely loved it! The service was great, the food was delicious, and the whole experience was very satisfying. I will definitely be going back soon, and often.

AWESOME experience. Went early (530pm) on Saturday. No wait, the wait staff was super attentive. The food was amazing- huge steaks for such a reasonable price. Obviously BYOB with no corkage fee is a little slice of heaven. Absolutely no complaints. My new favorite restaurant in Chicago.

The restaurant is truly argentinian, and to some extent it is a symbol of argentinian culture in Chicago. They have a large selection of steak plates and it is quite inexpensive. The only problem is that the quality of food is not so great. The beef that they use is not the best you can find. And I would prefer if they offered baked empanadas.

Absolutely delicious steak !! We had to wait 3 hours, so be prepared if you don't have a reservation. But the food is well worth the wait. And we were a little more than tipsy by the time we got to the table. Overall, a great time and super delicious food.

So I came here with a large group of friends in the middle of the afternoon.  Now, granted, we erred and made reservations for 8, and some of my group showed up late...and with guests.  I worked in hospitality for years, and I know how aggravating a situation like this can be.  But you know what?  You vent in the kitchen.  You tell your coworkers what an asshole table you have.  But you DONT be rude to your guests.  We are your income, in the lovely state of Illinois that pays servers with tip credit.  Our server was pissed off and not hiding it.  He knew that since we were a large group, and thus the table would have gratuity added that he could phone it in and not give a damn. Uhhh....no.   What really got me angry was they have policies written and unwritten.  I am always happy to read rules on the menu and follow.  I asked for separate checks and he said bluntly, "No.  No separate checks."  Ok, not on the menu.  But fine.  When my friends tried to share some empanadas (four) he said he was going to charge them $6 (I think) dollars for a split plate charge.  For an appetizer that you can order individually and in any quantity?  Please.  When questioned why, he shoved a menu in my friend's face and told him rules are on the menu.   I could go on with these stories, but I think you get the point.  I'd give this place one star for service, and 3.5 for food.  Their flan is AMAZING.  AMAZING. I'll go back, because I don't believe in condemning a place because of one bad experience, but boy, I hope my server isn't as nasty!

Wonderful steak, the ambiance is fantastic (when I ate here, we had the typical candlelit restaurant and were sitting next to a table of priests --felt very Godfather), and you can't beat the price given that it's BYOB.

the ambiance is gorgeously candle lit and romantic at night, and helplessly encourages bouyant celebrations with food and wine. the byob feature is fantastic and is a wonderfully novel concept for a los angeleno.  it is a meat eater's paradise, so vegetarians, beware! there is a deliciously cooked salmon as an alternative, for those who wish for fish, yet will take forever to arrive with the heaps of meat.  the beautiful male dominated servers will provide a glorious eyepetizers, meant to distract you as you wait a hundred million years for your food.

My husband and I both liked this place. He doesn't care for foo foo food and this was different but not over the top. He raved about this place for days. Thanks to other reviewers we stopped for wine before we came. The restaurant is BYOB with not corking fee. The food was great and way too much. We split the filet for two meal and we had enough for a third person.   The only CON I can see is they did not take reservations for two.

After waiting for a steak for four hours, it was bound to be disappointing. I came here on a date a few months ago, planning on waiting for at least a couple of hours for a table.  I arrived shortly before 6, and put our names in right away for a table.  I was told it would be about an hour and a half to two hour wait - totally fine, given how crowded this restaurant can be.  We went across the street for drinks, and the host said he'd call us when our table was ready. About two hours later, he called me to let us know we'd have a table in ten minutes.  We headed over there, checked in with him, and waited for our table.  And waited.  And waited.  Half an hour later, my date asked the host how long it would be, and he said it would be at least another half hour.  I'm not sure what happened, but we didn't want to be horribly rude to him, so we headed back across the street for more drinks. An hour later, the same thing happened, except this time we stuck around outside of the restaurant with everyone else who was waiting.  Apparently, there was a party of about 15 people in the restaurant that wouldn't leave, even though they were clearly done eating.  I had seen the group go in when I originally arrived before 6, and then had been in there for more than 3 hours.  The restaurant is not huge, so they were taking up about a quarter of the seats. Rude. When we were finally escorted in, 4 HOURS after we had originally checked in, I was starving.  My steak (bife vesuvio, my usual) was decent, but I've had so much better at this place.  My date liked his steak, but for me, the wait time had left a bad taste in my mouth. (Why did we wait the 4 hours?  Because I insisted it would be the best steak ever.  I'm an idiot.) The party of 15 was still in the restaurant after we left - so they were there for at least 6 hours.  I really, really feel that the restaurant should institute some sort of policy on having people leave within half an hour of closing out their checks.  Because it's BYOB, people are going to stick around because they want to finish their booze, and it's not fair at all to those who are waiting for tables.  If I go back, I will likely stick to weeknights, as the weekends are way too crazy for me.
I have easily payed 2-3 times more for food that does not compare with Tango Sur plus BYOB?!?!?!.....I don't know how they do it but please keep at it.
Love this place. Best BYOB policy in chicago, great for groups.  And you won't leave hungry!

I am a vegan and I love this place. That should be all you need to go.  But for real -- it's BYOB, excellent food (I've had pasta, salad, and eggplant. and all my friends won't shut up about the steak and chicken), and a fun atmosphere that works for any situation. I've been here on a date and with a group, and either setting works perfectly. It can get irritating when you put your name in and have to wait longer than they tell you, but that's because no one wants to leave which says something. Because it gets so packed, I'd recommend dressing for some roasty temperatures.  Bring a couple bottles of wine and some good company and chances are you will leave happy and full.

I love a good steakhouse. My friend recommended Tango Sur before a cubs game. It's a byob and I had a good bottle of Malbec so, I was down. We ordered this incredible cheese and peppers dish that wouldn't end. And then, I ordered this incredible skirt steak that wouldn't end. The portions are huge and the quality of food is great. I will be back with bottles.

This is hands down the BEST deal for a delicious steak meal in the whole city. The filet comes with TWO huge steaks, which means that you buy two meals for the price of one (about $24 total, WOW!). Plus, it's BYOB, which just makes it that much better. And the outdoor seating over the summer is divine. The prosciutto with melon is a delicious appetizer, and so is the eggplant vegetarian entree.

Pros: BYOB, fabulous steak, ordered the one for two, and it can definitely feed Africa. I can eat the Chimichurri sauce with everything! and the flan, wow.....decadent! Cons: I couldnt see the steak while I was cutting it, because it is too frikken dark in there! hi, I know we are in a recession and we trying to save on electricity, but one candlelight???!!!! c'mon now, turn on some light!!!! and o yes, thankfully I wore a tank top, or else I would've lost 20 pounds of sweat just sitting in there.  Let me say, hello Tango SAuna food is awesome, despite its presentation. it looked like a big lump off poo with the lack of lighting. however, the they lose a star for the environment/atmosphere. I really would give the place a 3.5, would i go back? sure, for the flan :)
Pros  -good food -prices r reasonable -i want 1 of dose tango sur shirts -service is good -I've only been a few times and the wait wasn't bad the times I went Cons -parking sux  -

Before I tried this place I had heard nothing but excellent things about the food, the fact that its BYOB, etc.  So I went into this with an open mind.  I knew about the possible long wait times, but was promised it would be all worth it when the food was served.  Meh. The combination of the extremely cramped quarters, LOUD LOUD LOUD groups of people ( I'm talking drunk as a skunk laughing and almost fallin over each other loud ), and the HEAT made it a pretty unpleasant experience.  DAMN it was hot as hell in there.  I seriously broke a sweat just sitting at the table eating.  The candles didn't help.  It's a nice ambiance, but kick on the a/c could ya?  As for the food, the empanadas were good.  I had the spinach, chicken, and steak, and all were equally delicious.  The chimichurri sauce was excellent.  For the main course I ordered el filet, which is filet mignon with spinach mashed potatoes.  I ordered the steak medium, and wasn't very impressed at all.  Rather than the meat melting in my mouth, I had to fight my way through each bite.  And the potatoes, well they definitely had a spinach taste to them, but they were so green that I wondered if they weren't colored with food coloring to make them green.   The only reason I gave it three stars is the fact they allow BYOB, which saves a lot of money.  Otherwise, I was not impressed.  El Nandu on Fullerton had much better steak, in my opinion.

Changed to four stars.  I still love the place, but I was on a beef-induced high when rating last time....  The spotty service and long waits (along with the hassle of street parking) should, by rights, earn a demerit or two. Regardless, Tango has become one of my very favorite restaurants. Here's why.  Excellent quality steaks (although I've had the occasional run in with some unnecessary gristle at times), seasoned exceptionally well, cooked perfectly. Portions that could easily feed three people happily. A WONDERFUL BYOB policy with NO corkage fee (this includes liquor). Bustling, high-energy atmosphere. Dark wood, candle light, romantic enough for two but boisterous enough for a large party. Price cannot be beat for what you get in terms of quality and atmosphere.  Did I mention it's BYO? My recommendation - head to Trader Joe's to pick up a great bottle of red or, two... (Malbec preferably) - arrive at Tango EARLY (unless you don't mind the very long wait) - try to sit in the front dining room if at all possible (ha! as if you'll have a choice with the crowd!) - order the beef and cheese variety of empanadas (they are fried yet haven't even a trace of grease, very well prepared) - for the steak, order the Vacio for two and when the waiter asks how you'd like the steak prepared, do not ask that it be cremated.  Or perhaps just leave it to the cook to decide, as he'll know which temperature/preparation brings out the best in that particular cut of meat.   I've heard the flan is excellent, though I have yet to try it myself.  This place truly is a GEM.

I went here with my wife and another couple a few weeks ago.  First, let me get the bad news out of the way. The wait for a table is dreadful. We knew the wait was usually long going into it, but still ended up waiting for 3 hours at the Blue Bayou across the street before our table was called. That long of a wait for a table of FOUR! Ridiculous. Needless to say, the bloody marys from BB might have clouded my vision for the night.  Now for the good.The food was fantastic. The primarily focus on meals with a lot of meat in them, so if you're a vegetarian/vegan, stay home. The atmosphere was buzzing with chatter, and the lighting was dim, but comfortable. Oh, and it's a BYOB so you save a boat load if you tend to buy alcoholic drinks at dinner. A nice bottle of red goes with most of their dishes. I would definitely go here again, but next time I'd put my name in at 5pm and go home and get ready!

Went here again for a friend's birthday party.  Let's just say if you plan on coming with a large party and have minimal patience, this place is not for you.  Yes, the Argentinian steak tastes great/has great value and it's BYOB... but always expect the place to be packed and at least a 45 minute wait.  If you are just taking a date or going with afew group of friends, definitely check this place out... but if you are with a large group, expect to be there for at least 2-3 hours.

I went here for a friend's birthday dinner.  It was crazy packed so I would recommend making a reservation.  It is also ridiculously dark in there.  Be careful of where you're stepping.  The steaks are decent.  Try the meal for two which is about $30 and it will fill you up quickly with a huge variety of meats.  Also, it's BYOB with no corkage fee so you can't beat that.

Took my boo here after I won money from my fantasy basketball league. The BYOB was clutch and definitely helped made this meal affordable. I've only been to one other Argentinian steak house in frisco which was pretty tasty so I already had a pretty high benchmark.  We had the following: -empanadas: while these were good.... The fried ones that they sell for a dollar in LA were much much better. These empanadas were quite doughy and had a lot of crust that had absolutely no flavor. -Bread: while I wouldn't normally review the bread, this bread was an exception because it was rock hard. I literally took one of the mini loaves and made a knocking noise with it against the table. -El fillet: ok I have no complaints about my dish. It was a delicious filet mignon with spinach mashed potatoes that were both cooked and seasoned perfectly. -Ribeye: I love me some red meat but my boos steak whch he ordered medium rare was slightly undercooked. It tasted almost like beef sashimi. So the real winner at this place was the chimichurri sauce. Garlicy with delicious herbs (parsley I think?) I pretty much used the sauce on just about everything.

Lomo Relleno, Lomo Relleno, Lomo Relleno, Lomo Relleno, Lomo Relleno...AMAZING... 3 of us ate for $77. we bought some wine in advance and the beef empanadas were by far the best, corn is not too too far behind. but for basically $30 a person I challenge you to find a better spot.

Oh man, after the appetizers and a few glasses of BYOB wine, I really really really wanted to like this place! Then my meal came. First things first: the appetizers were great.  Melted provolone on a plate?  Yum.  Sopping up the cheese-grease with bread?  Divine!  As per other reviews, the empanadas were awesome: perfectly puffed and filled with deliciousness (I had one meat and one spinach ... my friend got a  ham-and-cheese and loved it, even though it is a little weird sounding). About the dinner.  Dum dum dum ... Maybe I should know better than to order the fish at an Argentine "steak" house??  Blech!  The Tilapia itself would have been okay if it were not smothered in this indescribably awful tangy orange syrup.  I am an adventurous eater and try to eat a few bites of everything to make sure but it was seriously gross and I was gagging by Bite Three.   My friends across the table got this big hunk of meat and mushrooms (recommended "for two"): the thing could have served the entire table of 12.  Except that no one would eat it because the meat was texturally-challenged and completely over-seasoned (read: mushy and saaaaaalty).  Strike 2! Tango Sur never actually struck out.  Again, the appetizers were great and the management/servers allowed us to bring in a cake for the birthday we were celebrating.  Service was attentive and friendly.  Overall the meal was not a complete waste (no Strike 3), but if I go back, I will only eat empanadas.

This place was so good that a week after bringing a couple of friends here, one of them brought her husband back!   First off, you must try the chicken empanadas!  Ohmagosh...melts in your mouth and not in your hands.  And for $2, you can't beat the price!  If you are a meat & potatoes kinda girl, try the Bife Vesuvio.  It's the specialty of this place...can't go wrong with the item they do best.  And don't forget to finish the meal with flan.  I seriously want to go back right now...writing this makes my mouth water! This place can be a bit of a wait, so plan for that, but we arrived a bit before six and were seated immediately.  Get there early and expect impeccable service!  In the words of Arnold Schwarzenegger, "I'll be back"

i could try to wow you all with my flowery prose, but this seems much more useful. excellent:   price   bife de chorizo   beef empanada   chimichurri    good:    authenticity   blood sausage (hard to find)   chorizo    mediocre:   provoleta (poorly prepared)   vacio (too tough, even for vacio)   chicken empanada (not standard filling, mealy) unspeakably bad:   milanesa a la napolitana   that dessert with twirly bread and layers of dulce de leche (tasted like a month old)   wait on weekend and treatment by hosts

In the land of great steaks in Chitown, Tango Sur is by far the best steakhouse in my humble opinion if you consider all the key factors in a restaurant: ambiance, $, level of service, and most importantly, quality of food. I definitely agree with the general consensus that this is the #1 date spot with it being BYOB. I've come here with my family, group of friends and dates before; and the steaks here have impressed everyone equally.  My usual dish here is the El Fillet with spinach mash potatoes. What's great about the service is if you tell the waiters that you are planning to share the dish, they would actually cut the steak into two pieces for you. And believe me, the portion is enough for two people if you are sharing appetizers and desert. In my latest visit, my date and I decided shared this chef's special appetizer, Berenjena. I've never been a fan of eggplant but somehow I enjoyed this one quite a bit. At the end of the day, my date was happy and my wallet was happy. So win win.  I also want to point out that little backroom that Tango Sur has, which essentially serves as the bar/waiting area. There are trays of glasses ready to go so people can just sit there and enjoy the wine that they brought. Very thoughtful on their behalf indeed.

Usually a 5 star review does not accompany a 2.25 hour wait. But you have to hear me out as to how to have a great time.  1.) Bring lots of booze. A bottle of wine isn't going to cut it. There is a line when they open a 5pm, and the wait times start at 1.5 hours. If you are lucky and get there early and get a table, good for you. I had 4 people with me. 2 girls, 2 guys. So we brought, a six pack of nice bottle beers, 2 18 oz crafted beers, a bottle of champagne, and a bottle of wine.  We had most of it before we sat down. Alcohol makes waiting easier. If you can't get into the little back waiting room they have, use the park bench at the Dairy Queen next door. (I cannot be responsible for open container violations if they happen to you.)  2.) Be prepared to wait. Just know your going to wait so you don't spoil it.  3.) Order the Empinada's. We had the meat ones, but I've heard the others are tasty as well. Sweet Fancy Moses! They are incredible!  4.) Flap Steak. It's a weird name for a delicious part of a cow. Many of there dishes are recommended for 2. Listen to them. Also, allow them to tell you how it should be prepared. It's a giant hunk of meat, and it cooks differently than a steak. So don't say medium or well done. Just ask.  5.) Bring a coat until May 25th. It was cold this weekend. And the back room may be full.  6.) Order the plate of cheese. Since you saw what we drank, I really don't remember the name of the cheese dish. It's just that. A giant plate of cheese. Eat it and shut up. You're welcome.  Best steak, sweet potatoes, empendads and cheese I've had in a while. I will be going back. Might try going early. Loved it. You will too. They DO NOT TAKE RESERVATIONS at this one!

I've heard rave reviews of this place prior to going, so I was really excited to try it for the first time. I went with my coworkers, only to find out that they had lost our reservation (after my coworker had confirmed it that day). We were worried because there were 6 of us, and it's a smaller place. They were able to seat us after waiting for 20 minutes. Then I ordered "El Filet" and it was amazing the night of, but the leftovers gave me food poisoning. So it's not a place that I will try again soon. I don't know if I will ever eat that much meat again.

This was my first time to Tango Sur after hearing rave reviews.  All in all, I thought it was good but not awesome. Highlights:  The empanadas were really yummy, and the chimichurri sauce is amazing.  I love to put it on everything I ate.  BYOB and the location in the cute Southport neighborhood are extra pluses. My mistake:  I ordered the Beef Vesuvio which was just ok - primarily because I like medium rare steaks and the Beef Vesuvio is thoroughly cooked with cheese inside.  Bad order choice.  The steaks (i.e. El Filet) look much better with the spinach mashed potatoes on the side (plus the opportunity to put more chimichurri sauce on).  The grill plates to share also look tasty (that's what I would try next time). The downside:  the place is totally packed with tables squeezed into every spare corner which makes it fine if you are the big group, but a little too much if you are trying to go for a 2 person meal.  I also found the candlelight lighting a bit too dark.

I would give Tango Sur 5 stars if it weren't so loud!  I swear I am not being an old women; if you have party of 5 or more, good luck hearing your friends talk! Other than that, I am in love with this place, even as a non-meat eater! Our reservation was set for 8:30 on a Friday night.  We had about 7 girls total, and waited all of 5 minutes to get seated which was VERY impressive for this place.   I know all women will agree with me on the lighting, nice and dark candlelight which is EVERY girls best friend!  We got seated right at the front which was nice seeing that it was jam packed with people in both the front and back room.  The service was FANTASTIC.  Our server was there the second we sat down, opening all 6 bottles of wine and even giving us champagne glasses for the big bottle my friends brought. :) He took our orders ASAP and we didn't wait very long for our salads to come out.  Then came the Eggplant--holy holy.  It was delicious...melted in my mouth...  Then the table next to us heard it was my bday so they ordered me a piece of cake with a candle on it--thanks boys :) It was SUCH a fun night out with the girls, the service and food could NOT have been better. The only other thing I would change is that there is only ONE bathroom in the entire place so the line of girls were 4 deep each time a friend went back there.  Time to add one more TS!

Pros: BYOB, No Corkage Fee, Reasonable prices, and...............thats about it. Cons: The service needed to step their game up just a little a bit. They tossed my steak out that I was going to take home with me and the manager told me " The next time you come in Ill take care of you. I will give you 10% off on your entire meal." So i thought about it and I said to myself " Lets see I paid about 38 dollars for the steak and I was taking about 3/4ths of the steak home.......mmmmm." All in all it just didn't add up. The steak was also bland with no type of seasoning but I guess you get what you pay for.

If you ever been to Argentina, or had a real south-american style parrillada, DON'T GO HERE. The only thing this place has going for it is that it's BYOB. You have been warned, so no bitching later... Now, if you are parrillada-curious and want to have a ROUGH idea of what this is about, go and check it out. The servers have a couple of empanadas stuffed up their butts, and it only gets worse if the place gets packed (which doesn't help).

I went back to Tango Sur last night, still FAB!  Had to wait an hour and fifteen minutes, but in the end the wait is always worth it. I love their steaks... Had El Filet and spinach mashed potatoes again, bruchetta, and some provolone cheese appetizer, simply amazing...  Had the peaches and cream dessert which isn't exactly up my alley but it was still good. The flan is amazing, BTW.  The servers are great and on top of everything.  Lots of drinks flowing, great company, and an amazing meal made for wonderful night!

This is almost certainly the best steakhouse in its price range ($16-$24 per steak) in Chicago. I don't think they age steaks for a month, like you may find downtown, but they do serve prime, and Tango Sur always presents the meat at your requested level of doneness. The seating wait will be long unless you get there early or late. It's BYOB, with no corkage fee, and if you have time to kill but no alcohol there are literally a half dozen bars on the same block, all of which also serve appetizers. The ribeye is huge and delicious with the chimichuri sauce, and the empanadas are a steal for $2 each. I could eat an entire dinner of those.

Plain and simple - I love Tango Sur.  I've been to Tango Sur a few times for dinner. It is one of my top 5 favorite places in the city to eat. Its unique, it has character and the food is excellent. True, you will wait....for a while....but all good things are worth the wait. There are plenty of bars around to have drinks at in the time being. In the summer, the al fresco seating can't be beat. Get a couple friends, pick up a couple bottles of wine (BYO) and head over to Tango Sur.
2.5 hour wait.  Service was atrocious.  Very loud.  Was told that I incorrectly ordered my steak, and that I dont know my meat temps. Was really looking forward to this place, but severely let down.
Best steak in the city, hands down. We had to pre-eat before we went here, which was a great idea because we had a 2 hour wait, but it was worth it.

Wow!! Bring a nice bottle of wine enjoy the lakeview neighborhood and enjoy the best steak I have ever eaten! I'm not much a steak eater despite being from texas because I am usually let down by rubber meat and lack of flavor. Tango sur is quite the opposite!! My dinner was delicious (ribs) and huge portions which you can defintely share with even the biggest appetite. They do charge for sharing but the prices are very reasonable.

First of all I have been to Buenos Aires several times and this place has nothing to do with true Argentinian steakhouses. Went on a date on saturday night. Parking was a nightmare. Got there at 730pm, this place is packed. The guy on the door says 2 hour wait, maybe less. My date insisted in staying so we did. They throw you in an overcrowded "waiting room" in the back where you get to drink your own wine, nowhere to sit. Some argentino jackass comes in and calls out names with the worst attitude to sit people. We waited literally 2:20 min. The food sucked. All the servers are a bunch of latino trash who can barely speak english. Their "salad" was literally three dry leafs of lettuce with two slices of tomato and some dirty onions. Disgusting. Empanadas taste like nothing, they served them with Chimichurri sauce so you can add some taste to them. The Bife de Chorizo was overcooked and tasted nothing special. If you have the money and want a great steak, do yourself a favor and go to any american steakhouse in the city where you pay for top notch service, you can valet, and you can get sitted promptly with a reservation.

I really liked Tengo Sur.  Great food for cheap- and its BYOB!  The only really issue is that you WILL wait (even if you call ahead- they don't take official reservations).  We waited for 2 hours with calling ahead.  But the key is - just plan on waiting and hit up the near by bars.  They also sort of rush you  (probably because of the masses of people that they need to move through).  The food especially the steaks are really good and the portions are large. Overall-great intimate atmosphere for a date or close friends, good food, and great prices.

Almost 600 reviews already... need more be said? My steak was ginormous and around 12 bucks. Service very good. Liquor store close by for BYOB. Dark place, get cozy. It's Lakeview - take public tansportation. RECOMMEND!!

BYOB.  No corkage fee.  Customers seemed to all be between 20 and 40, good looking, trendy, and positive.  I have never had a better steak in my life.  Ever.  The only thing that sucks about this place is the host is a bit of a stress-ball or something.  He is not friendly.  Something initially annoying, but no big deal, is that the waiting room is in the back so you have to walk over some people when the place is packed.  But they'll bring you wine glasses in the waiting room and open up your bottle for you, no problem.  After all, you don't need to be sitting at a table to drink.  Plus it's an opportunity to chat with friendly people.  I'll be going back to this place a lot!

HUGE FAN! The empanadas are the best I have ever had with out any reservation!  I feel like if this place wasn't so darn busy I could go drink a couple bottles of wine and just eat these little delights all night long...  Only 2 dollars each really?  Yes really! The atmosphere is great! No corking fee! Juicy flavorful amazing cuts of wonderful beef, we split a bone in ribeye and filet... Note to self bring bottle and smuggle out as much chimichurri as possible, this sauce is just amazing!  I really want a jar of it on my counter!  Drizzle this on everything, pour it on the floor and roll around in it and find yourself lost in an aromatic flavor boosted nirvana! The dessert was good too!  we split three of course! I will be back! Tango Sur just found its way onto my list!

Pros: EXCELLENT STEAKS!!! Cons: Cramped dining room. Not good for large groups. What you should know: Make reservations/call ahead! or you will be waiting 2 hours or more during dinner hours.  Its a BYOB establishment.  If you show up and there is a wait, you can give them your name and cell phone number and they will call you when your up. The restaurant has a nice warm feeling to it, however seating is pretty cramped.  Candle lit dining which is nice. It could be romantic when its not that busy.  They have excellent steaks that are priced around $20-30.,

Saturday night approximately 7:45 p.m. I called about the wait time for a table for 2.  The man over the phone said it would be 20 mins, but they do not take reservations over the phone.  So, we figured a 20 min wasn't that bad considering a Saturday night prime time.  And off we went, and we got there literally 5 minutes later.  We got there, and the place was packed.  We signed in and the guy told us the wait was going to be 45 mins.  I was shocked, and I told him I had just called and they said 20 mins tops, so what gives.  He said that a whole crowd of ppl just came in within the last 5 minutes, and it was a take it or leave it situation.  My husband figured it must be real good for all these ppl to come here, and we should just wait.  So, 45 minutes go by and still no table.  I leave the tiny back waiting room to ask about how much longer, and the guys says any minute now.  So I head back to the tiny waiting room, and waited another 40 minutes.  When we finally got seated we saw a few friends at another table.  They were a party of 6, and we asked how long did they have to wait.  They told us they waited about 5 minutes for their table to get set-up when they walked in.  I didn't know what to say to that.  I was starving and pissed.  We ordered right away because it was like 10 p.m. already.  The only thing that could save the night would be amazing food.  Unfortunately, that didn't happen.  The only thing that was really good was my own bottle of Ruffino Chianti Reserve ($32 at Costco, worth every penny). Heres what we ordered: Appetizers:   Empanadas - 1 chicken, 1 beef - both were very salty Jamon Crudo Con Melon prosciutto served with melon - just okay, I've had much better prosciutto from the deli  Entree: Costoletta bone in rib-eye cooked on the grill then topped with an olive oil, garlic, parsley sauce, served with mashed potatoes - tough, not high quality cut of meat, and the seasoning was nothing special Bife Vesuvio grilled prime steak slice and filled with spinach, mar del plata cheese and garlic in a white wine sauce, accompanied with argentine style potatoes - this was the worst steak I've ever eaten.  It was tough, over-cooked, and the plata cheese was an over-kill.  I couldn't even finish half. My server came by to check on our food, and I told him the steak wasn't that great.  He was kind enough to offer me a free flan for our dessert.  Unfortunately, the flan was also the worst flan I've ever had as well.  It was so sweet that my tooth was aching.  I can honestly make a better one myself.  My husband and I each had a bite and gave up. The place is so over-rated that can't even begin to count the ways.  Needless to say, I will never be back, even if the meal was free.

Not impressed. Not even slightly.  After a 2.5 hour wait (which I would never normally stand for, but we were there with a larger group that was willing to wait, and we snacked on appetizers at a pub several storefronts down to kill the hunger), we were seated at a tight, tight table, in a very loud (and very dark) room - so loud, I had a hard time hearing what my closely seated dining companions were saying.  Not the ambience I was hoping for... Service wasn't the greatest, either. Part of it was the fact that our waiter kept pressuring us away from our entree choices in favor of the specials (man, was he pushy!), but what killed me, and I mean KILLED me, is that he straight lied to me about the empanadas. Granted, I'm a bit of an empanada slob having lived in Buenos Aires, but when I ask you whether the empanadas are fried or baked, just tell me the truth! I was assured by our waiter that they were baked, or "al orno", but when these crisped up, greasy suckers were delivered to our table, I was less than thrilled. Further, the beef empanadas didn't have the traditional raisins mixed in, and they served them with a chimichurri sauce - what?! Blasphemy!  Get those fried pockets of grossness off my table! While the grilled meat entrees were satisfactory, the beef ravioli we ordered were sub-par. Tough, chewy outer pasta, and tasteless beef filling left us pretty disappointed. The only thing this place has going for it is that it's BYOB.

We came here a couple Saturday's ago for a group dinner with friends and had a great time. Our reservations were at 9 pm and the place was crazy busy. Tables are close together and candlelit but gave it an interesting ambiance. We ordered appetizers and they came out immediately. We ordered the Provoleta, Empanadas, and Antipasto - so good! The Provolenta is like saganaki - the sliced red pepper on the top gave it an interestingly pleasant flavor. Now for the meats - everything was seasoned deliciously! The cooking times could have been a tad better - i.e. not even throughout and even though the middle was medium rare, the outer parts were a bit overcooked. But like I said, the seasoning on the meats made up for that. Everything was so flavorful! We had the Filet and Lomo Relleno. The chimichurri was amazing - I could dip anything in that all time time. For dessert we all shared various desserts - they were ok, nothing to rave about but they did their job at the end of the meal. But what's the best part of the night? Tango Sur is BYOB and they have no corking fee. There were 12 of us and each brought (and successfully finished) 2 bottles of wine each. At the end of the night, after apps, dinner, dessert, and tons of wine the price came out to about $65 / couple. Amazing! I really enjoyed Tango Sur and we'll definitely be going back.

Steaks.  Cheap Steaks.  Cheap Flavorful Steaks.  Cheap Juicy Flavorful Steaks.  Cheap Juicy Flavorful Argentinian Steaks.  I could keep going.  Recommendations:  Come early and bring hella wine!  Very nice candlelit ambiance, which can get noisy....but there's just something about a small noisy restaurant that I love.  I have yet to kill an entire steak here, mostly because I save room for the wine.  But those are some killer ass steak and eggs in the morning!  As others have mentioned, it is BYOB with no fee.  So don't be offended if the waiter throws a wine tool at your table and leaves.  If you don't care to wait for the waiter to bring a wine tool (since it does happen to get busy on occassion) or if you simply are not crafted in the art of opening wine, go with a nice screw top.  Hell, show some real class and bring in a boxed wine!  Anywho, if you like enjoying steak with your favorite booze, come here.  PERIOD.

I went here for a recent birthday party and after thinking about the food for a little bit, I decided to give it a 3. There were all sorts of things in play here that led me to the 3 star overall rating... We had a somewhat early reservation since it was a large party. We were rewarded with no wait when we arrived. Woohoo! The place was lit with candelight and the atmosphere was loud and fun. Definitely a romantic, have fun while you're here type of place. We brought a bunch of wine with us as this place is BYOB. The appetizers: Jamon Crudo Con Melon - prosciutto served with melon. To me it sounded like a strange combination, but they went well together. Pretty simple, but good. You can easily make this at home. Chicken empanada - A pretty tasty empanada. Wasn't so impressed with their Lengua a La Vinagreta - poached tongue marinated with vinegar, garlic and pepper. It was rubbery and not very flavorful. I've heard that if done properly, it is supposed to be tender and moist. Right after this, they served salads for everyone. To be honest, I'm not sure why they even bother with this. It was the cheapest looking salad I've ever seen. Lettuce, two slices of tomato, and a few rings of onion. Splash vinegar and oil over it and some pepper and enjoy! Seriously? My main course was the Bife Vesuvio - grilled prime steak slice and filled with spinach, mar del plata cheese and garlic in a white wine sauce, accompanied with argentine style potatoes - supposedly their second most popular dish behind the "El Filet". Ok. This thing was a huge portion. The marinade was very tasty. The spinach and cheese filling was very tasty. The downside was the steak itself. Not very tender, and even rubbery in some areas. The marinade and the filling definitely saved it from being disappointing to me. The steak was served with Argentinean style potatoes that were really awesome (I wish I could have eaten more of them). We tried some dessert as well. I tried a little bit of their flan and German chocolate cake. Both were pretty run of the mill. Not great but not bad either. As a side note, a few friends who had the El Filet said they really liked it. One friend that tried their salmon dish said it was decent. Another friend that tried a chicken dish was pretty disappointed with it. For the price, it is worth coming back. It is a fun atmosphere and the food is decent enough. Service was ok.

Had dinner there for the first time last night and it was delicious.  It's BYOB and the wait was about 2  hours (but it was a busy Sat night).  We started out with a variety of empanadas with chimichuri sauce on the side.  They were really tasty and the sauce was to die for.  I got the breaded steak topped with 2 fried eggs and mashed potatoes.  The potatoes were so thick and buttery and delicous.  Desert was flan topped with fresh caramel.  Everything tasted sooooo good.  All the tables had candlelight and it gets pretty loud in the dining area.  I love this place.

Definitley a must try !! This place is adorable, the atmosphere is hard to pinpoint, its all lit by candle light which I love, the tables are packed in and there are quite a few groups with pretty much unlimited wine since its BYOB, so it did get pretty loud in there and as people walk by its seems to get a ltitle croweded even while your at your table, aka the waiters walking by kept knocking our menu off our table ! It says they take reservations, but I called to put my name on the list for a table for 2 and he said they don't take reservatiosn over the phone just to come in. When I got there the host met us at the door, he picked up the phone in his hand making us wait outside, it is winter, not the most chivalrious thing I've expereienced, and he took down someones name on his sheet for a table for 2, when I confronted him about this since he wouldn't take my name he said it wasn't him I spoke to and that this person was his friend and he does that for them every week. okay.  We got offered the option to wait in the 'holding room' it has 3 tables and is quite small, when we got there at 7:45 on a Friday there were a few chairs left, but by the time we finally got seated 30min after the 30 min they quoted us it was sooo packed you couldn't move. annoying. but glad we had a table so we weren't getting shoved around. Tables do not move becuase everyone has to finish their 4 bottles of wine !! We finally got seated, our server was a hunky Argentianan man, he was super sweet, and definitley understood little of what I said, everytime I would try and make a joke he would laugh uncomfortably and say thank you. They let you drink your wine in the holding room so after drinkig more than half our bottle and an hour wait we got to the table and devoured the baby baugettes they gave us... which are unlimed... though I guess you should save room for the meat since this is a steak house right. There are a few options on the menu that say perfect to share between 2, they are not kidding they are huge cuts of beef. My friend and I shared one that came with sweet potatoes, I thought it was good she loved it. Though I do love the chimichurri, atleast thats what I think its called, its a garlic herby sauce they give you with everything... yum !!

I wish I could give this place 100 stars!!! I LOVE it! all you need to know is "El Filet"  it is like butter and don't read anything that says other wise and the empanadas are good too... There are other things on the menu, my boyfriend tried the t-bone the last time... he ended up picking off my Filet. He's lucky I didn't stab his hand for that. B.Y.O.B and no Corking fee!!!! Did I mention "El Filet"? Make reservations and prepare to wait.. but soooo well worth the wait.

Demonstrating a true act of love, my Vegetarian girlfriend took me to Tango Sur for my birthday!   I ordered steak stuffued with spinach, mar del plata cheese and garlic in a white wine sauce.  I ordered it medium and it was one of the best steaks I have ever had.  It was a  perfect cut of meat and it lacked fat. My girlfriend ordered  the oven baked eggplant with spinach, provolone, parmesan and ricotta, covered with tomato cream sauce.  I tried it and it was almost as filling as my steak.  It was very rich and hearty. The atmosphere at Tango Sur is unique and intimate.  It was a great escape from the North Side and it resembled the types of dinning experiences that I have had in Europe. I look forward to returning to Tango Sur with my Carnivore friends in the future and trying some of the different meats on the menu. And yes its BYOB, no corkage fee....

If you are an impatient person, Tango Sur is not the restaurant for you. The wait is pretty heinous, especially in the summer and on weekends, so in order to fully enjoy this place you have to be willing to stick around for an hour, possibly two before even sitting down. That being said, the food isn't bad.  Since this place is BYOB (with no corkage fee, which is nice), make sure you have some good stuff on hand. We had an excellent Pinot Noir that paired nicely with most everything we ordered. If you do have to wait for a table, you may be lucky enough to score a seat in their waiting room (essentially a tiny, very dark enclave with a few tables) where you can enjoy said BYOB while hoping a table opens soon. When I went, I started with the scrumptious chicken empanadas. I then partook in the Pechuga De Pollo - chicken grilled with chimichurri and veggies. It was a bit bland, but not awful. A serving of German Chocolate Cake certainly highlighted the evening (actually, just looking at the tray of delectable desserts was memorable enough - they ALL looked so good).  A lot of people heart this place - and those people are typically of the beef-loving variety. As I am not, my interest is a bit more subdued.

Two words... Friggin amazing. I came here with my boy toy (yes I called him that- sowy andre =() a couple weeks ago. He picked some wine up at a whole foods and away we went. I'm new to chitown and I'm kickin myself as to why I haven't come here earlier! OMG. candlelight.... Im a sucker for candlelight. I mean REAL candlelight- like the only light in there hahah. We shared a steak between the two of us (a huge slab of meat). It was phenom. Didn't break the bank either.  Try the jamon con melon. Best ap ever. Simple, refreshing....  The flan was great too. Good meal from start to finish, great, non annoying service. Oh did I mention there was a dude playing flamenco guitar too? nuff sed

I came here on Saturday with a group of 12 friends and it was a lot of fun, a very enjoyable dinner and experience! Not only was the food very good, but the service was outstanding. It is so busy in there, I can only imagine the stress of the waiters. Our waiter was really good to us. There were two other larger parties there at the same time as us and he told us upfront that if we ordered our food within 5 minutes, we wouldn't have to wait so long. That was really nice of him, he didn't have to do that! Everyone enjoyed their dinner. I do not eat red meat, but I highly recommend the lemon chicken, it was outstanding as well as the empanadas, the best I have had so far! Lastly, you can't go wrong with BYOB! I will definitely go back!

We went on a Saturday night to Tango Sur for dinner. We arrived by 6pm, and the door man took our name and number down. They said they would call in about 45 minutes..They called as promised and were seated promptly. As we sat down, I gave a bottle of wine to the waiter and he opened it. We thought that was perfect. Once settled, we began overlooking the menu while in awe with the romantic atmosphere. Our waiter came back in a reasonable time (5 minutes later) and ordered. We asked for the Lomo (for two) as our entree. OMG the dish is made for at least 3. You definitely get what you pay for and some. Attention meat lover's, this place is calling. Anyway we enjoyed the atmosphere and the food. I recommend going in small groups (4 people -- give or take) or with a significant other. Depending on your timing, if you go in groups, you risk waiting longer than expected. (It's really hard getting people cycled out of there when they are having such a fantastic time.) Hence, this place is pretty popular. If you are someone who hates waiting don't waste your time. Or, if you don't like loud and crowded areas, then that could dissapoint. For me, I could care less. I think if you love the Argentinian theme...then you will absolutely love it. Be open minded, and enjoy!!! Cheers!!! T

Um... I don't get it. One Friday night over the summer, my bf and I were looking for a BYOB place and he mentioned Tango Sur. We picked up a bottle of wine, biked over... and found the wait was over 3 hours. I thought to myself, "This place must be awesome!" and couldn't wait to go back. Fast forward a few months. My bf and I decide it would be a good idea to to try again, this time right after work. We get in no problem and I immediately love the ambiance. The service was good, and the overall vibe was really cool. The important part - the food - was not so great. We ordered a mozarella, red pepper and spinach salad to start. It was mostly mozarella, and though the menu said "fresh," it tasted like it was off the grocery store shelf. I ordered the filet, cooked medium, with mashed potatoes. My bf ordered lemon chicken with Argentine-style potatoes.  My steak was NOT GOOD. The seasoning was good, but the steak was not cooked properly and was incredibly stringy and chewey. I ate half and could not eat any more- my mouth was tired from chewing. I had to saw at it with my knife in order to eat it. I probably should have just eaten it with my hands. My bf said his chicken was good, and I liked my mash potatoes, but overall this place did not leave a good taste in my mouth (har har). I don't get it. Nice ambiance, but the food is not worth the wait nor the hype. I think there are far better BYOB places in Lakeview than Tango Sur.  Maybe I'm missing something...

Yes, it is as good as you've heard.  Yes, you will have to wait for awhile.  I suggest heading over to Blue Bayou for some drinks.  They will call you when your table is ready.  Que Syrah is a fine wine store that is very close.  They will set you up with some nice wine to enjoy at this BYOB.  Or you can just walk down the the CVS if you're feeling less fancy. :)  I think at this point I have gotten pretty much everything on the menu and have not been disappointed.  My advice is to order the beef that is imported from Argentina.  It is a lot better - a bit more expensive, but so worth it.  Also...come hungry.  SO so hungry.  You will leave full.  So so full.  The downside about TS is that you do end up sitting on top of the neighboring tables.  This is by far one of my fav places and I always bring out of town guests here.  They are always amazed.  TS does not disappoint.

Several cows died in vain. I hadn't had Argentinean food and was on a date, so we giddy-upped for some good eats and ambiance.  Unfortunately, our excitement ran away with us. It's BYOB and we didn't know what would be a good pairing; so brought a bottle of red, a bottle of white (Billy Joel advised as such and I'm an Uptown Girl; so why not?). The candlelight and live tango music were sooo romantic. The vibe was less so, more of a party atmosphere; boisterous and loud. Which doesn't underwrite romance, but is however fun, as one feels like they are at a boisterous, loud party. 2+2 folks. My date was a restaurateur and wanted to try everything on the menu, so, accordingly, we ordered the menu. Even the server charmingly advised one or two entrees, not 6 plus items. I wish the menu was online so I can bullet point each tasting, and unfortunately my photographic memory is cluttered with literature, history, and film references, so I apologize.  What I do recall is the hot cheese appetizer- sweet Argentina makes saganaki?! But it was unremarkable and kinda greasy (yes, most hot or warm cheese is duhviously) and bland. The veggie and olives plate appetizer was good. As for the meat, I ate a lot of meat that night. And threw out over 15 pounds of beef leftovers. The potato and veggie sides were good.   Inspite of the evening escaping the lasso of my expectations. . . I like to be satisfied and won't let the cattle stand in my way, so I will return. Moo!

I've been here over five times and it has become one of my fave places if I'm craving meat...I mean really flavorful succulent meat *drool.* Here are the pluses: 1. It's low key, lively, but still romantic, great for a date or to come as a group, 2. Food hands down awesome... 3. Service great 4. BYOB.  Only downside is they don't take reservations so the wait is usually long unless you come really early. I've waited anywhere between half an hr to 2 hrs. Yes 2hrs for food! But by the time we for got our food we forgot about how TS made wait so long as we stuffed ourselves with meaty happiness.

Tango Sur is a solid establishment.  The wait can be a little daunting so come early to get seated quickly.  Overall I enjoy this place but the meat can be a little overrated.  Nevertheless, the restaurant offers great value.  Check it out!

Yes - SUR - e! This popular BYOB dining spot lived up to the hype and the two hour table wait.  As a group we ordered two of each of the empanadas to start out. Very tasty little buggers but our waiter did tell us the wrong order and I ended up with a beef empanada parading as a spinach and cheese delight. I'm not a picky eater so this was a non issue.  For my entrée I went with the El Filet and the hubs had the Churrasco sirloin. My eyes about popped out when our food arrived, there were not one but TWO filets sitting on my plate staring back at me accompanied by the scrumptious spinach mashed potatoes. Hubs had been drinking a few rounds of whiskey cokes by the time we ordered and ordered his sirloin rare. Needless to say, it mooed when the server set the plate down!  Other people in our party ordered meals for two and it should say two households because I have never seen such a huge chunk of meat at a dinner table. Rave reviews though.  I loved the ambiance of the restaurant, so dark and cozy with the candle light. The byob aspect is fantastic but also a double edge sword - I put back a whole filet and potatoes and also an entire bottle of wine over our two hour meal. Good but good for you? I think not. Not a traditional steakhouse and definitely a trendy establishment judging by the long waits - try it at least once, it's a fun dining experience.

Churrasqueria! ...Fairly 3.5 stars. If you eat a meat lover, then go for the "parrillada para dos", it was very good, though  a bit salty for my palate. It's a BYOB place, so that's plus! Cons: it's usually crowded and is a relative small place. Parking is a nightmare. Suggestion: try to go early so you'll get a quick table and easy parking of course.

As an omnivore, I thought steaks grew on trees until Kimberly L. set me straight.  Thankfully there are former vegetarians in the world to teach us all The Way of the Meat.  Also thankfully it isn't always the case that only ignorance is bliss, as even knowing these bits of muscle come from lovely cows who gave their life to be "meat-tastic," I was able to thoroughly enjoy my meal. All was going well until a fellow diner pointed out I had meat juice running down my chin like some sort of ravenous neanderthal devouring his former neighbor.  At that point I realized I had to actually be mindful of my table manners despite being made ravenous by the nearly hour-long wait for a table on a Wednesday night. The food is very good.  The wait is excessive but likely unavoidable for most people, although making reservations and going in a group of six or more seems to greatly reduce the chance of a long wait.  Once you're seated, the food does come at a reasonable pace.  Not speedy, but not super-slow.  It would be more romantic if it wasn't Friday-night-bar-noisy in the dining room. Overall, I am a fan.  The staff, the food and the general environment are all very nice.  The only two things they could improve in my mind are to replace forks like a fine dining restaurant would do instead of putting dirty forks onto the table and install some sort of sound-absorbing material to keep the noise level to conversation-capable levels. The wait time is more a function of their immense popularity than it is anything else.  All the other restaurants on Southport last Wednesday night were practically empty - none were over half full, while Tango Sur packed them in all night.  That alone should tell you the experience and food is worth the wait.

Me and Tango Sur have a long and storied history together...not really, I've been there 3 times.  I am happy to report that each visit seems to have been a little better than the last. I should start out by saying that I have no issue with the staff (friendly, attentive), or the atmosphere (loud, but not too loud), and I like the menu focus (meat).
