Our first visit to Tango Sur was with friends.  My fiancee had the eggplant parmesan, which is an an entree sized appetizer...she said it was good.  I had the bife vesuvio at the behest of one of our dining companions, and to this day I cannot understand why so many people rave about this dish.  Sure, the steak is big, but it is super fatty/grissly, and is heavily saturated with oily cheese...not my idea of fine dining The next time back, I had the El Filet...better, but the butchery of the steak was cockeyed, and the meat was not tender at all.  At that point it was strike 2, and I didn't think we would be coming back.  Lo and behold, a few months later, the same friends want to go back, I begrudgingly agreed to a return trip. This time, my fiancee got the crap dish, and I finally found one worth coming back for.  I split the tabletop grill (para dos) with one of our guests, and it was awesome.  Blood Sausage, awesome.  Sweetbreads, way awesome. Skirt steak, awesome.  I will be returning for the Para Dos, perhaps even the Para Uno, if my adventures were to bring me here alone. P.S.  The bread is lights out delicious.  Oh, and the salad is humorous (its always funny when someone orders one on the side for $5 then realizes that they only get 2 pieces of undressed romaine lettuce, a ring of onion, and a slice of tomato).

I came here last friday night, and I thought the food was excellent. I had a outter skirt steak, and it was excellent. I had a side of mashed potatoes which were excellent. But I thought the appetizers were even better. We had the dish with melted provelone cheese with red peppers and the empanadas, whcih were both out of this world!

As a former vegetarian, I'm always very conscious that a steak comes from a beautiful living creature. So I want to respect that lovely cow by making sure I'm really thankful for the meal that I am eating. Nothing is more heartbreaking to me than to bite into a mediocre steak knowing that an animal gave up its life (albeit unwillingly) for no good reason. So imagine my delight upon dining at Tango Sur. This place is meat-tastic! Now I know someone's going to be all "it's not free-range, grass fed blah, blah, blah" and I get that this is probably a more important factor in respecting the cow than just the oh-my-god-it's-delicious part. But then feel free to write your own review. I will now proceed with mine... I came here on a Thursday evening around 6-ish. I was meeting a group of 5 and we were seated immediately, though not everyone was present. I'd have to say that if we tried this about 30-45 minutes later, we'd have been met with resistance. The joint was packed within a half-hour of our arrival. The atmosphere was charming and fun and I loved that we were going to be dining by candlelight! It felt very festive. We brought our own wine (yay for the BYOB policy) and we were brought glasses immediately. The waiter opened and poured the wine for us as we perused the menu. Bonus points to the waiter for being peppy, nice, and kinda hunky. We ordered an extremely tasty and cheesy-rific appetizer. Most of us then ordered El Filet, which comes with a salad (meh) and spinach mashed potatoes (also just okay). The beef, however, was totally worth the guilt trip I always feel when I partake in meat eating. Super mega carnivores will not think twice, I'm sure. This was one delicious feast! And you will (you will!) have leftovers. This serving was ginormous. So a very reasonable and incredibly delicious BYO experience means that I will be back, Tango Sur! I will be back!

Went for dinner thurs the 29th. 7:30pm This place is so loud you have to yell at each other to be heard. My hubby and I shared the Costoletta-bone in rib eye.  ordered it medium. came more rare than anything, but not a nice juicy rare.  I have never had a rib eye that has stringy tendon bits that you cannot chew  or cut through.  The flavors of the sauce were good though, but this seemed like an "impostor" cut of beef disguised by a flavorful sauce. Our friends shared the Vacio. Order this only if you have strong jaws, because you will chew and chew and chew.  This meat would have been better tossed in a slow cooker and left for 8-10 hours. For $35 bucks this was robbery and rubbery.  The 'silverskin' was still left on the meat, which is a culinary mistake! again, an impostor cut or low grade beef, disguised by a decent sauce. I guess my definition of romantic is different.  I would rather be somewhere quite, where i can hear my hubby talk to me, rather than  scream at me.  awk...maybe i'm getting old :(

I went there Friday night with the bf. Needed a romantic night out. Tango Sur won the vote... Ok, we were quoted 40 minutes. Great. Not bad, right? So the door guy wouldn't let us go in the back "drinking room" because he said it was full. The bf wanted to check it out himself and found seats available so came back up to get me. The doorman again was hesitant to let us go back there. What gives? So we sit in the back and share a six pack. Meanwhile, they shove an 11 top of dudes in the room for their meal. WHAT? 11 dudes sharing a 3 top table. They couldnt move and were shoved in there like sardines. I felt bad for them. Another group of 6 came in after us, and were sat almost immediately. The one dude in the group said, wow, we only waited 10 minutes... hmmm... Finally TWO hours later we get a table. Only after the bf went to check to see how much longer...  Then we get our food. YUM! It made the wait worth it. Our server was amazing. We both ordered steaks. They were freakin' amazing. He even gave us dessert on the house. YUM! It was sooo good. :)

If you like busy atmosphere with GREAT food.  This is the place for you.  The first time I went here I could believe how great the food was.  I also couldn't believe that there was no corkage fee.  If you are looking for a very reasonably priced steakhouse with wonderful food, this is the place!

Really like Tango Sur.  It is a great restaurant, and a great value.  BYOB, lots of meat/food for the price (have had both the El Filet and Bife Visuvio...yummmm--always take home leftovers), and a real contribution to the area.  Meat is usually cooked perfectly and sides are good too.  Empenadas are delicious as well as the eggplant appetizer.  It is dimly lit, and the wait can be long, esp on the weekends, but I highly recommend it!  There's a wine store almost across the street if you forget your libations, and a wonderful dessert place a few doors down (if you have any room for dessert after dinner!).

We had heard really great things about this restaurant from friends and ended up taking some friends visiting from out of town. Unfortunately, our experience was not the greatest. We had made a reservation about a week prior to our visit, but when we arrived, they didn't have a record of it. Fortunately, they were still able to seat us because it wasn't too busy (it was a Sunday evening). We started with an order of empanadas (one of each flavor) which were not bad and came to the table pretty quickly. The dinner salad was basically just a plate of lettuce and tomato--nothing special. I will say that the chimichurri sauce that came with the bread was REALLY good. Very garlicky but addictive. Our table ordered two of the steak dishes for two people and all shared. After receiving our starters, the service was extremely slow and we ended up waiting an hour before getting our main course. The steak dishes were not impressive. The meat was really tough and the sauce didn't have much flavor. The best thing we had was the sweet potato side dish--those were great. We ended the meal with a flan dessert which was ok, but nothing to brag about. I really wanted to like this place, but it just didn't work out .
Love the Filet Mignon you get 2,spinach mash to die for.Spinach empanadas awesome.And the flan is the best I have ever had.Went for my B-day,byob.Good times.

Reading the wide-ranging reviews of this place and weighing them against my own consistent experiences, I think it's safe to say this place is not only "not for everyone," but it also seems to have some kind of learning curve. If you know what to order and are willing to follow other rules of thumb when dining at Tango Sur, you're going to have an amazing experience. If not, you're probably going to be miserable! So, since my experiences have been positive and getting better each time I visit, try this: BYO: Don't forget the red wine! GO EARLY: 5pm. 5:15 at the latest especially if it's a weekend. Don't bother with reservations as they seem to get backed up whether you make a reservation or not. I remember at one point being told they only take reservations for large parties. DON'T GO IN A HUGE GROUP: 4 max. 2 is ideal. The huge groups are always waiting and it takes an enormous amount of planning and luck to have your evening at Tango Sur go off without a hitch, so don't bother. They have tons of 2 tops so you have the best chance of a smooth evening as a duo. APPETIZERS: Get a couple of chicken or spinach and cheese empanadas, but you will be plenty full and taking home leftovers so take it easy. STICK WITH WHAT THEY DO BEST: Argentinian Steak. That means the center  "Chef's Special" menu ONLY for entrees. Ignore the domestic beef on the right. Fish and Chicken eaters? Go somewhere else. Seriously. My favorite dish is the Vacio for two. It's a HUGE hunk of "flap meat" (i don't know what that is and i don't care) in 2 layers. Between the layers is some nice chimichurri plus more on the side. It's served in a grill with melt in your mouth sweet potato. It's not a steak house steak. It's going to take a moment to accept visually, but just try a bite and let your taste buds show you the way. Get it cooked Medium. Safe and consistent. The Vacio comes with a boring salad. Enjoy if you're hungry, but if you're not, then tread lightly. You have no idea the amount of meat you are about to experience. If this is too many hoops to jump through and you feel that you shouldn't need a secret code to enjoy a restaurant, I hear you and you may be right. If you're willing to follow these directions, I promise your reward will be great and your belly full and satisfied.

Great steaks and sauces.  Be aware you probably have to tip the host to get sat on the weekends.  I had friends in town and raved about the place and we never got sat(4 hour wait before we left).  People that showed up after us got sat before us(with the same number of people).  Now, I only go during the week.  P.S. My last experience last week was great.  The waiter was very attentive and the steaks were cooked perfectly.

This was my 2nd experience with Argentinian food in the same month, and I have to say I liked it better than my local venue (which shall remain nameless until I appraise it once again).   But I LOVE the atmosphere here. The tango music and paintings on the wall are fun and exotic, and it smells delicious throughout the restaurant.  I also liked the waiters' shirts.  Very snazzy. Everything was deliciously flavorful EXCEPT 3 things:  1. A few of us got the fillets, and one of my mom's was literally a rubber tire on a plate.  I thought I recognized it from Petsmart, the same place I got my Rottweiler a toy tire to play with 6 months ago, and she hasn't even made a dent in it yet.  TOUGH. 2.  A "potato tortilla" appetizer.  It was a potato omelet.  With eggs.  Not tortilla. 3.  The bread was weird.  Some kind of bland, cheap rolls.  MEH. However!  The other fillets, the half-chicken limon, the empanadas, and the BYOB service was fantastic.  I would love to go back; it's very romantic and delicious. And easy to do low-carb, which I could always benefit from anyway. Just make sure you instruct them on how exactly to cook your steak.  If possible, specify that they are not to use an old shoe or a piece of a tire. Kidding... kind of.   One other thing was that it was FREEZING in the whole front room because of Arctic Blast Winds coming through the front door.  They need one of those door cover thingies, STAT, for the winter months.

Why are you so deeeelicious?!!! We came on a Wednesday and the place was still packed! The atmosphere was really laid back with only candles at each table to set the mood. Very intimate setting so it was great for a romantic dinner for us. (Hit this place us for Valentine's Day people!) I ordered the El Filet (medium rare) while Jason ordered the Bife Vesuvio, medium because our waiter told us the chef suggests it cooked at least medium. We also ordered Guarana (Brazilian fruit soda) and it was yummy! I'm a sucker for exotic-ish sodas.  The food took maybe 10-15 minutes to come out but we were nibbling on warm bread and sippin' our sodas so I didn't notice the wait at all. When the food arrived, my mouth watered instantly. The spinach mashed potato caught me a bit off guard since it's bright green (I have posted a picture of the food) My El Filet was FANTASTIC; large chunk of well cooked meat, the spinach mashed potato was a great  compliment, and the Guarana quenched my thirst and tickled my taste buds. I had a bite of Jason's Bife Vesuvio and it's a rush of flavors - I believe the Bife has cheese in it. Not my cup of tea but still good nonetheless. I made it through 3/4 of my plate before I was stuffed. Good size portions. Moving on to the best part, dessert. Our waiter brought out a bunch of desserts but I went with flan (my obsession). It was perfect, not too watery, not too hard. The carmel on top just made the flan that more irresistible. *drool*  I give Tango Sur 5 stars because the food is a solid 4 but for the value and how affordable each dish is, I give it a 5. I need to go back and get more of this deliciousness and try the much buzzed about empanadas!  Note: BYOB and no corkage fee - great!

Yeah, blah blah Tango Sur blah blah "OMG!" blah blah, etc. They overcooked my medium rare ribeye--easy to demonstrate, as one of my dining companions ordered the exact same steak and hers was perfect. The side-by-side comparison shut the waiter up pretty quick, and sent him scurrying back to the kitchen. Whereupon about 15 minutes later he brought me a new steak... now UNDERcooked. Sorry guys, but you're supposed to know how to cook these things--that's the point, right? But apart from fucking up the primary reason for me being there, everything else was as others have described; nice atmosphere (albeit a little loud at times), no corkage fee for BYOB, delicious potatoes and exceptional empanadas. The side salad was a bit of a disappointment (soggy tomato slices on a bed of very uninspired lettuce), but the eggplant salad appetizer we ordered was simply phenomenal. It reignited my taste for eggplant, actually, and for that I applaud you, Tango Sur. Oh, and at 6:30pm on a Wednesday, we had no wait. So there's that.

Went back again - 6 for dinner.  I just overall felt like they had an attitude... like the host and waiters were too good for us.  The best part of the meal was the empanadas by far!  Don't miss those.  In fact if and when I go back, that is all I may order.  Bread - not as good as it was a year ago.  Meat, pretty fatty.  Atmosphere and sharing with the table was really nice though.  I will let some time go by before going back- fo sho.

Dining here was a real pleasure.  I loved both the food and the atmosphere.  They only use candle lighting, which makes the place feel cozy and warm.  The place was packed and everyone was full of smiles and laughs--no doubt fueled by the ability to bring your own bottles of wine!  The food was FANTASTIC, especially the spinach mashed potatoes for some reason. If the wait is long, I recommend leaving your cell number and getting a drink at the Mexican place next door!

I think this is my favorite restaurant in Chicago. It's one of the best values on the north side - beautiful setting (candlelit and bustling), good food and BYOB (no corkage fee).  It's no Morton's or David Burke's, but you can bring a decent bottle of wine and have an elegant meal for under $30 per person.  You get a basic salad and bread with your entree, and though the appetizers are good, you can skip that and save room for your enormous plate of meat and potatoes.  I order El Filet almost every time I go - you get 2 fillets mignons for $24.  I bring the 2nd home and eat it for breakfast. Great for groups - I think they take reservations for parties of 8 or more, just make sure you're all there on time.  It gets incredibly busy on weekend nights - put your name in and wait an hour.  Luckily there are a lot of bars and cafes on Southport.  This is the perfect place for a date - impressive but not stuffy.  Not great for vegetarians, they offer a couple pasta plates, but it's a carnivore's paradise, I think a vegetarian might be a little grossed out. They have a patio but I prefer to sit inside - I just love a dark and loud restaurant!  The staff is great, too.  Young Argentine men... one night we sat on the patio (in front on sidewalk) and after the place closed the 2 musicians that sometimes play inside sat with us and we had a great time. I wish they would sell the t-shirts that the staff wears!  I tried to buy one a few years ago and they weren't for sale.

I finally made it to Tango Sur and am happy to report that it lived up to the hype.  We went early on a Thursday night and did not have to wait for a table at all.  The atmosphere was cozy (although I could see how it could get crowded/noisy later in the night).   Prices were good, and the fact that it was BYOB definitely kept the cost down. I had the Berenjena, an eggplant parmesan dish, and it was DELICIOUS.

I've been to this place three times now and feel confident giving it a solid "meh".  Really, I have no idea why people enjoy waiting 2 hours for mediocre-quality meat and subpar service.  Each visit here is worse than the last one, which leads me to believe this place is somehow getting rewarded for bad restaurant behavior.   The last visit was the final straw.  We arrived at 8pm on a Thursday night, thinking the wait would be around an hour or so.  This is precisely what the host told us - hour and fifteen, he said - and fools that we were, we believed him.  We wound up waiting 2.5 hours.  The restaurant was supposed to be closed by the time they sat us.  We were starving and they were quick to take our order (plus), but the food they brought was pretty much crap (minus).  Very tough cuts of meat, well seasoned, but not high quality and not cooked well in order to facilitate eating.  It was like gnawing on stew meat.  Actually, I wound up taking our portion home and using it as stew meat later.  Just a couple of adults getting their stew on. Honestly, I wouldn't have such a problem with the place if it weren't for the wait.  I recall there are some tasty empenadas on the menu.  BYOB is always nice.  My problem with the restaurant lies in the staff's inability to gauge wait time, move tables, and control their customers. Case in point, there was a party of 10 that arrived just ahead of us with one raving lunatic of a woman who was insisting she made a reservation, and was very clearly lying her Citizen jeans off.  They ran around and finally sat the party of 10.  That upped the wait time for everyone else by at least 1/2 an hour.  Those people should have never been seated.   Ok, I'm off my rant.  I'm never going there again, because I can get great beef stew meat at Paulina Meat Market cheaper and more efficiently.

My favorite thing about Tango Sur is the setting: a small, dimly lit room with delicious aromas and good tunes.  I had a very relaxing candle-lit dinner with a couple friends on a cold winter night.  We had to wait around an hour to be called for our table, but there was a bar a couple doors down...so the wait wasn't a problem.  The food and service was really good.  The cuisine is hearty Argentinian, so make sure you bring your appetite.  The prices were reasonable too, so you won't have to worry too much about overdrafting your bank account.

A group of friends and I had dinner here and really enjoyed it! What you read in reviews about the staff being cavalier and the wait for a table being long (but the food being extraordinary) is 100% true.  We made reservations and prepared ourselves for this going in, so our expectations were appropriately set.  I suggest you do the same :-) They are BYOB and don't charge a corkage fee, which keeps the cost super cheap - our bill came to about $45 per couple.  Definitely try the empanadas - the spinach and cheese were so good I ordered a second to eat with my meal.  I ordered Pechuga De Pollo, a grilled chicken breast with chimichurri and steamed veggies.  It was tender, juicy, and a plentiful helping!  I brought half of the butterflied chicken breast home.  The rest of our group ordered steaks and one friend got the breaded chicken with potatoes and loved them. Strap on a laid-back mood and bring a couple bottles of wine if you come to Tango Sur.  There's a great waiting room to chat and sip wine before your table is ready and the food is well worth the wait.
Tango Sur is just not for me. I thought the meat was plentiful, but very greasy and over done.

Went here before seeing a movie at the music box and im so glad we did! It was amazing. so delicious. when we first walked in around 6 there was a lot of space but by 7 its was full. The pricing is so good for the portions, food and atmosphere and being byob it great. I can not wait to go back because I want to try to much more. The salad we got wasn't really good at all, i forget what it was called exactly but its had lots of mozzarella cheese. Still it doesn't even matter because the other food was so good, we had the empanadas and the skirt steak with sweet potatoes. Thinking about it make my mouth water! The only bad thing i can say is that it was so romantic type setting, which isnt bad in any way but for a place that i loved so much a little awkward if I wanna bring all my friends for a good time!

The setting sucked... noisy and super crowded... but the food was BOMB!!!!!  It was my first time in chitown and my first time having Argentine food. My god, it was sooo scrumptious!! the steaks, salmon,empanadas were all delicious!!! i wished they had one in San Diego or LA!! Chicagoans... you gotta go if you have not... Out of towners... make this one of your dinner spots!!!! you won't regret it!!!!  PS: byob. no corkage fee! (=

Let's start by saying I really want to give it 4.5 stars.   Joe and I always walk by this crowded restaurant on our way to Dairy Queen and I've always said, "Let's go!  Look at that huge chunk of meat on the table!" (Sorry Trinidad!!)  So, we read some reviews and were warned of how busy it is on weekends, and we've seen the people crowding the sidewalk waiting to eat.   We went on a weeknight and were told we had to wait, which was also expected.  What wasn't expected was that they seated us within the time that they had told us we would be waiting - I can't remember exactly, but something like a half hour to 45-minute wait time or something.   The menu is beautiful, and by beautiful I mean full of different cuts of steak and all kinds of delicious meats and sides.  We also read the empanadas were great, so we tried a couple of those... I think a spinach one and a ham one... Both very delicious, especially with the sauces given to you.  Then, our meat came!  Both of ours came with a different kind of potato.  Joe's potatoes were very, very dry.  Mine were delicious.  So was my meat, I didn't care for Joe's because it was covered in a red sauce...  Also, the waiter didn't look at us funny when we told them we were good with just water.

Tango Sur, aka, heaven for meat-lovers, is an Argentinian stake house.  They are BYOB so be sure to bring a bottle or two of red wine.  You'll need it for the long wait to be seated, but you can drink in the waiting room, a room in the back of the dining area on the right. They have tasty empanadas and a fantastic selection of meat with some as large as your belly.  I like the churasco but I can't tell a difference between the American or the Argentinian beef versions aside from the price. The place is tightly packed and the host is impatient.  You might want to avoid sitting in front of the main door in the winter because you'll freeze while munching on your ice cold stake.

Allison E. and I had a lovely time here Sunday night!  I have read so many great reviews about this place, so I wanted to try it.  It was good, but I think it was too pricey for me (I'm cheap, but also extremely picky about steak and like my dad's the best). I can't decide if I liked dining by candle light or not.  In a way it makes the restaurant romantic, however it is also very dark.  I think candles are very romantic when it's just 2 people, however sitting a foot away from strangers in a crowded restaurant takes away some of the romance. The filet Allison had was incredible.  The green mashed potatoes were amazing!  I ordered the churrasco special.  It was tasty, and a lot of meat.  (I ate till I was full Sunday, and then had the leftovers for 2 more meals).  The vesuvio potatoes were nothing special, if you could substitute the spinach mashed potatoes for them you should! I think this would make for an excellent ladies night out.  Everyone would appreciate the romantic atmosphere.  It's byob.  And there is plenty of tasty food!

My friend and I had a lovely evening at Tango Sur. We went on a Sunday and it was still pretty crowded. The space is very tight. I can imagine that it's a zoo on Friday or Saturday.  For those reasons, I would not recommend it for a large group. There just isn't space.  We did decided, however, that Tango Sur would be an excellent and uber romantic date spot. Its dark and candle lit, quiet, with intimate little tables, which would invaribly result in brushed hands, deep gazing into one anothers eyes, and maybe a little footsying. Perhaps not every man would understand the appeal, but trust us lads, take your girl here. You will not regret it.  The service was fantastic. The waiters were attentive, polite, and helpful. My water glass never was less then 3/4 full. (1/4 empty?). We certainly felt well taken care of. It may have taken a while for our entrees to arrive, but I didn't really notice. We had already had salad and bread to take the edge off and were having a good conversation.  The food. Ah! The food. The food was delicious. My mashed potatos were green. I believe they included spinach. But there were so amazingly yummy that I didn't really care what was in them, or why they were green. I had the filet mignon. It was beautiful. Tender, melt in my mouth, and cooked just the way I like it with some pink on the inside.  My friend's meal was just as tasty. Both entree's were huge. I think between the two of us, we had the greater edible part of a cow. There are some items on the menu that are recommended for two people. But in my opinion, most of the menu can feed two people. We both had two entire steaks on our plates, and we certainly could have shared one entree and been plenty full. Not that I am complaining about having filet mingon again today for lunch. It is a little on the pricy side, at least for me. I am cheap. But, they certainly give you your moneys worth in amount of food.  Overall, I had a lovely dining experience and would not hesitate to come here again. Ah yes! did I mention that it is BYOB? Bring your own bottle of wine. Which we would have done had I not been driving. No corkage fee either. As far as I am concerned, BYOB is the most brilliant thing to happen to nice restaurants. And I will pretty much award an extra star on that fact alone. So, pick up your favorite bottle and enjoy!

It was well worth the wait. As we didn't have a reservation, we first got appropriately buzzed on Margaritas a few doors down and leapt up as though we'd been zapped by a cattle prod when the host called us on the cell. I was lucky enough to find myself in the company of three lovely women from Colorado, so we got extra special attention from our beefcake waiter - if you know what I mean. Despite the stellar service, the dude was making me feel very inadequate, so I compensated by ordering up the Costoletta (ah shoot! I just drooled all over my keyboard thinking about that gorgeous slab of seared meat). By about halfway through the second bottle, I think we entered the "this is the best dinner ever" zone. We were all thoroughly happy that we'd trekked up north from our hotel. I will go back someday for sure. Five stars!

yeah, this place is just flat out great... The service is always really accomodating, and the lighting is really romantic (really dark and barely lit by tapers at each table). BYOB, no corking fee.  We always get the Vacio. It's a huge flap steak rolled and stuffed with fresh herbs and garlic, served for 2 and along side moist sweet potato wedges that taste like they've been basted in butter.  There's always plenty to take home for dinner the next night.  It's terrific, and a great place to take your partner or a great friend.  note: if there's a long wait, walk down to Toons and have some drinks and they'll call you when your table is ready.  How's THAT?!

My friend and I settled on Tango Sur for our somewhat regular dinner out and I was excited to cross this place off my list of restaurants I'd been wanting to try. I'd previously picked La Gondola and Indie Cafe, and it was her turn to pick. Maybe I didn't order the right thing, because I didn't love my meal as much as my dining companion, who gushed about her hunk (of meat, that is). Admittedly, no one can hold a candle to Joe's Stone Crab for a bone-in ribeye, but when I saw it on the menu, I decided to go for it. Filets tend to be too bland for me, and the ribeye gets rave reviews so I figured it would be pretty good. It's near impossible to have a bland bone-in ribeye, but that's exactly what it was. I substituted roasted potatoes for the spinach mashed, and those were like something from a school cafeteria. I didn't even eat half my dinner, but I wrapped it to-go, and it ended up sitting in my fridge for 3 days. I knew I would never end up eating it, so I tossed it. Never before in my life have I thrown away half a steak. As my dining companion enjoyed her meal, I would likely give TS another chance, but I'm in no hurry.

While in Chicago my guy and I were looking for a reasonably priced steak place - yelp led us here.  The place was busy, but we only had a short 5 min wait on a Sunday night. We were crammed in to our table but no one was moving around much so it wasn't really a bother.  We ordered a scallop starter. The scallops were TINY, but tasted good. The warm crusty rolls sopped up the remaining liquid.  We both ordered the 12oz. sirloin, cooked medium rare. The meat was very tender and well prepared, but with out the chimichuri sauce, lacked flavor (sirloin isn't the tastiest cut, but even some salt/pepper on top would have done well). And the meat was BRIGHT RED, yet there was no sign of blood which leads me to believe the meat is pumped full of dye at tenderizers like the steaks I get from SuperTarget when I'm in a pinch.  The roasted potatoes that came along with it were very good and tasty. The salad left a ton to be desired though - just lettuce, tomato and onion with oil and vinegar dressing. Maybe this is traditional? I don't know.  For the price it was fantastic - we got out for under $50. And it's the type of place we usually wouldn't choose to eat at. If I went back, I'd maybe be a bit more adventurous and get one of the combo plates.

No reservations accepted by phone.  They have a very sophisticated system at their front door.  A guy with a pad of paper takes your name and number and promises to call you in 2 hours when your table is ready.  Not sure where he expected us to wait.

Haven't been back for a while, but several dinners here over the past few years have convinced me that perhaps the only place outside West Texas to get a fabulous, dreamy steak is Tango Sur (or Argentina if you have the budget).  I deduct one star (though I really shouldn't) because every single time I go here, early or late evening, weeknight or weekend, there is at least an hour wait. Sometimes an hour and a half. Of course we wait - who wouldn't? But sometimes it's painful - we just want that spectacular steak!  Other pluses, though, are the ambience: it's tiny, dim, and crowded, yet you can still hear everyone at your table ... and the fact that it's BYOB. So while you may be shelling out thirty or more for your DIVINE plate of cow, you can still rock the Two Buck Chuck and pat yourself on the back for escaping another overdraft fee.  Excellent for small celebrations, and whenever you are feeling flush.

This was probably the best steak I have ever had. Ever. I love that it's BYOB. It really saved some $ on the bill. Service was excellent and I'm amazed at how the wait staff zipped through the tiny spaces left between tables. They don't take reservations which caused some anxiety before hand but we got right in. Everything was delicious.

Decided to check out this quaint spot on southport since I've heard so many referrals from my buddies.  I went with a friend, who happens to be a chef, and really loves his meat :) Since he's been here couple times, he knew exactly what to order. We had a beef and veggie empanada and the sauce it came with was excellent!  I don't remember the names of our entrees, but we ordered 3 different meat dishes. They were hugeee, really tender, and flavorful.  I would recommend this place to anyone who has a hearty appetite and loves their meat :)  Next time, I'll def go back with a bottle of wine
Went on a Monday no wait, and loved the steak.  Got it as rare as humanely possible - great meat and the garlic sauce complemented the meal really well!

It's a BYOB Argentine Steakhouse. Need I say more? Well, I'm going to. I went with 4 other people and we split 2 beef, 2 chicken, and 1 spinach and cheese empanadas, all of which were good and worth the $1.75 or however much each one is. I especially liked the spinach and cheese ones. We also got the provoleta (provolone w/ roasted red pepper), which was good, but nothing special. My friend and I split the the Vacio, which was a gigantic piece flap meat (that came w/ really good sweet potatoes!), and we could not finish even half of it. The rib-eye, which two of the guys ordered, was definitely the tastiest. But they'd been there before, so they knew what to order. And now I know what to order the next time I come. And I've learned not to order so much food here also, cause we left with lots of leftovers. And I've also learned that maybe 5 bottles of wine for 5 people is too much... In total, our meal was about $130, which I think is so reasonable considering the massive amounts of food served.

Yum yum give me some!  I had the pleasure of FINALLY dining here this past weekend when my friend chose it as the place to celebrate her birthday.  I was so excited and had heard such great things that I was really hoping I wasn't going to be disappointed - and I wasn't. First and foremost it's BYOB - need I say more?  We came each equipped with 2 bottles each and they were in no rush to kick us out, despite the fact that there was a LOOOOONNNGGG line of people outside waiting to be seated. We started with the empanadas, as recommended by my friends and they were amazing.  The beef and the ham ones were my favorite, but what really made it delish was the chimichurri sauce.....just don't plan on making the move on anyone after eating it.  It's enough to keep Edward Cullen away. Luckily one of my friends warned me ahead of time that the portions would be humongous so I split the filet dish with my friend.  Let me tell you this meal could have fed a family of 4, no joke.  The portion came with 2 pieces of steak what looked to be about 10oz each (if not more) and a VERY generous helping of the spinach mashed potatoes.  It was so big that I couldn't even finish half of one piece of steak...but was it oh so good.  Since everyone seemed to have order different things I was able to try some other items and let me tell you, it usually isn't my first recommendation, but the sweet breads were delish.  So good and tasty. In fact I liked this place so much that I've asked my hubby to take me there again this weekend.  The only thing to be worried about when dining here is the meat sweats you'll get shortly after, but that definitely should not keep you away!

As a person who works in the restaurant industry I know that service is just as important as the food.   First time I went here, I had no issues and the food was good. This past time (11/20/09) is the last time I will ever go.   I knew they only took reservations for parties of 6 or more, so as a party of 3, I went an hour earlier than the rest of my guests...7:35pm. The host told me it was a 2 hour wait, I agreed because I lived a block away so I didn't mind waiting. My guests and I check in at 8:25pm....host tells me it should be another half hour....we agree to wait. 9:00pm-Host tells us another 20minutes.  No issue yet because he did say 2 hour wait. 9:30pm-My aunt checks in and the host tells her that he quoted a 2 1/2 hour wait not a 2 hour wait.  This is when I got angry b/c this guy actually has the nerve to say I was wrong. Did I mention his reservation list was a pocket notebook? 10:00pm- By this time my guests and I are standing in front of the host glowering  at him.  Host tells us guests are paying and if we would like to wait in the waiting area....guessing he couldn't take the evil eye anymore. 10:15pm-still no table. 10:30pm-This is when I lost it.   As soon as the host saw me coming he had some guy who looked like an overdressed busboy to talk to me.  Both times I've been here I have never seen a manager walking around nor are there any women.  This guy says it will be a couple of minutes and he's sorry tables are taking longer than expected.   10:45pm- We are finally seated.  Now lets talk about the food. I ordered the filet-not great lacked flavor.  My aunt ordered her steak well done it came out medium.  So after waiting 3 hours to sit down, you can't even cook a steak correctly! WTF! Oh and to compensate for the 3 hour wait, we received a complimentary flan and that wasn't great.  I honestly believe that because this place is run solely by men, they were unable to correctly manage the flow of the restaurant. At the first sign of long wait times, a manager should of been fixing things with customers and sending a lousy dessert wont do anything.  As a hostess that has worked at nice restaurants, my managers would have been sending in complimentary appetizers to guests sitting in the waiting room. NEVER EVER WILL GO BACK AGAIN!!!!

Tango Sur has been one of my favorite restaurants for years. It's great for dates, for group celebrations, and I've even taken out-of-town family there.   Consistently amazing and reasonably priced food, coupled with BYO.  I love the patio in the summer and the cozy atmosphere inside during the chilly chi winters. No reservations means strategic timing is necessary, but always worth the visit!

Ever eat so much meat that you feel like you're sweating the oil out? Yeah, that's me right now.  I rate restaurants in proportion of taste to price. My entire meal including tax & tip was $24. I got empanadas and the sampler of meats shared between two people. I would have liked a little less oil, but otherwise the meats were all savory and delicious. The meat was surprisingly tender. The portions are huuuuge. I'm talking The Flintstones huge. But I was a trooper and managed to eat most of my food. I even ate those two little slices of tomato, just for variety. Also, it's BYOB with no corkage fee! Pick out a nice red, prepare to wait quite a while for a table, and enjoy your evening. (fyi, it's expect a long wait after 7 every night.)

Pre-meal:  I went here with a group of 8 people on a Friday night. We had reservations thankfully (accepted for 6+ people). The expected wait time here sans reservation will likely be 45 min - 1.5 hrs.  We finally got seated 30 minutes after our reservation. But I was with mostly guys who didn't care that much. So if you don't like to wait, you won't like this part. But apparently there is a back room inside where you can wait that lots of people don't know about - so go inside and don't freeze. Or there is a bar 3 stores down. Go have a beer.... Ambiance: Very dark. Very cozy. I loved it. There are also a bunch of international diners here. The people are very eclectic and it feels like a small European restaurant (even though the place is pretty big). Food: Ridiculous. I love steak. I ordered the prime rib rare. They give you a ton of food here. It was mouth-watering. My friends ordered the filet with the red wine sauce - unbelievable. The best steak I've had in a long time. The sides are so-so. But we didn't come here for veggies. So I would recommend ordering the steak and just a small side rather than the pre-made combinations. Drinks: BYOB - enough said. Amazing Service: This is the only bad part of this place. The service staff here rushes you and you feel like you need to clear the table for the next group. But it's understandable. They are packed and they need to clear space.  The waiter screwed up on the rare-ness of 1 of our orders and brought out a completely different order for another guy. But this is anecdotal - so whatever.  Price: It's a steakhouse in Chicago...a GOOD steakhouse. We all paid around 25-30 bucks. This is insane. You will pay $70-80 for a similar quality place.  Summary: All in all, I will definitely be back here - most likely on a weekday and I'll make sure I go with less than 3-4 people. and I'll definitely order the Filet.

There are too many good things to write about this place. First, its cheap for what you get.  A gigantic plate with two filets and spinach mashed potatoes ran me 24 bucks.  Second, its BYOB with a bevy of decent wine shops nearby.  Third, we had the empanadas and the antipasto appetizers and both were amazing. The only downside for this place is the tight quarters and the wait time, but I think it adds to the experience (re: hot doug's). Its really dark inside, but the decor is perfect for a nice date night.

Tango Sur is delicious! If you go anytime on a weekend night without a reservation, be prepared to wait for a long time. The nice thing is that they take your cell phone number and call you when the table's ready. When we go we stop by Tango Sur to put our names on the list, then head over to one of several nearby bars to have a drink and relax for an hour or so. Once they call, we head over and our table is ready right away. It makes for a nice, long evening. Just don't expect to be done with the whole experience in an hour! The food is amazing. We usually get one of the meals Para Dos, the one with the sweet potatoes. The steak is wonderfully flavorful, in a way that is unique from other steak restaurants. And the sweet potatoes absolutely melt in your mouth, yum! I've also tried some of their chicken dishes and been equally impressed. There is always plenty of food to take home.  Probably the best thing about Tango Sur is the excellent value. This is a rare steak dinner that won't empty your wallet! Add in the fact that it's BYOB with no corkage fee, and this place is really a steal. The ambiance is dark, lit by candlelight. However, I would not call this a terribly romantic dining experience. Tango Sur gets very, very crowded on weekends, and they pack a lot of people around tiny tables! I imagine this would be an excellent place to go with a large group. However, the food is so good that I don't mind being crowded!

I am not a fan of their no reservation policy but I would wait for their delicious piece of meat. It's probably the best steakhouse that give you the best value for your food. My friend and I waited for an hour at a nearby coffee shop and another 40 minutes in the waiting room inside when we were finally seated. I realized that it was BYOB when I saw people started drinking while waiting. I was like, "Dang it!" before my friend went to the nearby CVS to get a bottle of Malbec. We ordered the pickled tongue for appetizer. I didn't expect them to give us so many of them. It could very well be an entire meal! We both ordered the mixed grill for two people and it came with sweetbreads, short ribs, steak and sausages - enough to keep us both happy. They were perfectly done but a little on the oily side because of the sausages. I would come back and just order the short ribs because it was SUPER THICK and juicy. Delicious! My only advice is to come early, before 6.30pm because it starts to be crowded after that. There is also not a lot of room to walk around on the inside and the tables are very close to one another. I would suggest to come with friends. If you want to come with families, Folklore would be a better place in my opinion. They have essentially the same menu but the ambience at Folklore is more comfortable.

I was looking forward to having dinner at Tango Sur after a long week at work.  We rushed from our parking spot 4 blocks away in order to be there on time for our reservations.  The guy at the door (who appeared to be more of a bouncer kind of guy, than a host) was snobby and short with me.   After a 45 minutes wait, we were seated at our table.  The quick water refills, patient wait staff and ambiance made me feel like I was in for a wonderful meal.  Sadly, that was about the only thing Tango Sur had going for it and is why they received 2 stars from me.   We got the meal "Para Dos" which is a variety of different meats for two people.  When I cut into the steak I quickly realized why the only lighting provided is candlelight-so you can't see the HUGE amounts of fat on the meat.  Every piece I tried to eat had large sections of fat.  There were 7 of us and no one took anything home with them because of it.   Needless to say, we won't be back anytime soon.

I AM OFFICIALLY A FAN OF TANGO SUR!   Meat lovers, here is your destined haven.  I love steak, and for those avid steak worshipers, best believe that good steak that is cooked to perfection is hard to come across. Here at Tango Sur, they marinade their steak just the right amount of flavor--not too bland and not toooverwhelming.  I asked for the steak to be cooked medium-rare, and if I went to most of other places, that would have meant medium-well done which angers the living soul in me. Not here! They did as I said, and my $36 steak that they recommended splitting with my boyfriend was just the perfect size for two people with huge appetites.  The small portion of pesto sauce most definitely completed the taste. For appetizers, I was not disappointed one bit;  the empanadas surely exceeded my expectations. I've only had the chance to try the beef ones, but so far so good. Dessert was delightful. Don't contemplate about it. You'll regret not getting it. Two people for an enjoyable, romantic, delicious, satisfying, fulfilling meal = $50   (Note: Excluding drinks) If you've heard nothing but good things about this place, chances are that those people know what they are talking about, so do not hesitate to check it out. I was skeptic due to the hype at first, but now I'm a firm believer.  Love you, Tango Sur. Wish I could eat you every day. xoxo
Tango Sur is simple and delicious.  Great quality steaks in an unpretentious atmosphere.  I happily spend my time waiting for a table in the small and cozy waiting room with a bottle of wine.

Ordering steak at a restaurant is a rarity for me, but I knew I would if I went here and it got me really excited. We arrived on a Wednesday at 7:30pm and were seated right away (there were 5 of us). We brought three bottles of wine because they are BYOB with no corkage fee. Ordering off their specials menu was the easiest and I got the filet with salad and potatoes. My serving was HUGE and could definitely be split with two people. I ended up taking my one of two fitets home with me. The salads that came with the meal were pretty bland and I probably would not get them again.  My wife, a vegetarian, actually recommended we go to this place because she loves the eggplant appetizer as a meal. So she got that and I tried it and it was so good. Another couple that was with one ordered the dinner for two with sweet potatoes and they said their meat was delicious and I tasted their sweet potatoes and they were so good! They ended up taking a bunch of it to go also. As for the prices. My meal was about $25, the appetizer was about $10 and the 2-person meal was $36, so a little pricey, but worth it.

Maybe it was the place being mainly lit by candles, the lively tango music playng, or the room filled to the brim with laughter and jubilant conversation. It all was meant to give the patron the feeling of an intoxicating dining experience. But, when the pixie dust cloud fades away a few days later, you think back and angrily say "Hey!" I believe the cloud completely faded when I was eating my leftovers from dinner there and I was reminded of how much I didn't like it. I ordered the El Filet which is two filet mignon pieces in a red onion wine sauce and a side heap of spinach mashed potatoes. Let me make you aware that I mainly got this dish because of the raves about the spinach mashed potatoes when I was reading reviews on this place. This was the only dish that came with them. Ok, now that we have that established, let me then tell you the mashed potatoes came cold at first. My whole plate had to be taken back so I could get a hot heap of mashed potatoes. It comes back, I try them, and they are ridiculously bland. B-L-A-N-D. Oh and then the meat? I've always been used to a filet mignon being a very good cut of meat. Usually great texture, firm, and easy to cut. The two pieces of meat I had on my plate masquerading as filet mignon were mangy, rather soft with being cooked to med-well, riddled with grizzle, and rather difficult to cut. It took me dipping my pieces I worked hard to separate from the rest of the meat in my chimichurro sauce to be able to chew it. At $24 for this dish, that is just theft! I went with my mother who had the shortribs which she felt were salty, but took the rest home feeling I may still like them. When I tried them, not only were they super salty, but had even more grizzle than my filet mignons. What's up with all the grizzle? Cheap meat or bad butchering?? Probably both. They sure have a good pixie dust cloud floating about in there. Our waiter was nice, but the guy clearing our table seemed to be rushing us. Just as I don't expect anyone to hurry up with their eating so I can sit down to take my time, that shouldn't be expected of me to do for other people. As soon as we got up he pounced on the table clearing it off and taking up the paper while I was trying to put on my coat. I had to snatch my to-go bag before it ended up on the floor, or in his bin. So rude! I'd have to say the best part of my meal was the bread and my Inca Kola pop I had. How sad is that? When I was leaving I felt I would definitely be back. Now that their magic has worn off, I know I most definitely will not.

My boyfriend and I decided to try this place for my bday. We always get steak for each of our bdays and while this place wasn't your typical steak house, it was BYOB and I got to pick since it was my night. We went on a Monday night so it wasn't too busy and we didn't have to wait. I was a little nervous about how dark it was but once we sat down and got use to it, I found the ambiance perfect...especially when our food came out! We decided to do something different and experiment with the dishes that were reccommended for two people. I kinda zeroed in on the "Vacio" mainly because I had never heard of a "flap steak"....yes people..."flap". We asked the server to describe what exactly this was. For the next 3 minutes, he described with excited eyes, this dish. By the end of it, my beau and I were sold and decided to get it. I was a little nervous, cause while I am pretty much game for all kinds of foods and flavors, my boyfriend is not. Plus he wanted STEAK and we got something that sounded like the part of an animals nose and was stuffed. We had absolutley nothing to worry about. This sucker showed up on what looked like a miniature picnic table. It was huge and surrounded by a lake of herbed marinade and perfectly cooked yams. We were given two little plates, two knives, two forks, and ate away. It was perfectly cooked and the marinade was delicious. That combined with our great server made this a delightful dining experience.

Can't wait to go back to this place! The hubs and I did not have a reservation, but got seated right away.  Very nice cozy romantic table (despite the kid at the next table trying to pull down the curtains).    We ordered the filet to share, and I thought there was no way that would be enough food for two of us.  Well, I was wrong.   They brought out this ridiculous huge slab of meat on a metal tray.  The meat was covered in delicious spices and a mushroomy juice.  We just cut off chunks as we went and couldn't stop talking about how delicious it was.    We didn't get dessert because we were in a meat coma.   The service was great- very attentive.   And we couldn't believe how cheap it was!  $50 for two people, awesome! Can't wait to come back to you, Tango Sur!

Wonderful, quaint place with great food, and the waiter even laughed at my jokes. Top it off... you can bring your own wine. What more can a yelper ask! Tango Sur is a steak place. I had the filet stuffed with spinach and cheese. Even typing it triggers an immediate Pavlovian response. Holly had a regular filet, which was great but easily bested by my (drool drool) spinach-stuff steak menagerie. Our appetizer was some meat-filled pastry concoction. Sorry, I don't remember the name. They had 4 flavors: beef, chicken, spinach, and ham. Try them all. Oh, and they're bigger than you'd think. So, bring someone to share all the goodness with. In fact, all the portions were large. Holly had a whole 'nother filet, it seemed, to take home to her skillet. Prices for a Chicago restaurant were very reasonable. Tango Sur is a 4+/5- experience. The place's nice vibe put me over the edge into 5-star territory. Check it out. drool again... yow, bill

Was here for my birthday and finally saved a wee bit of room for dessert - caramel flan - OMG.  Heaven in my mouth!  Staff was great with our party of 8 - our reservations were delayed slightly but they were very apologetic and set us up as soon as they could.  Meat coma lasted 2 days thanks to the leftovers.  Can't wait to return!

Other than the wait (which is totally ridiculous in a city with so many great steak restaurants), the service once seated is great and the food is very good (3 1/2 out of 5 stars).  It's definitely a place to go with a group (since I hear you can make reservations for 6 or more) and if you want to over-indulge in a carnivourous mess.  And, everyone probably thinks this place is better than it really is because you wait for 2 hours to sit down, so you hit the bar next door (Cullens or Blue Bayou), drink a ton, and then go back and have BYOB at Tango Sur and are drunk by the time dinner is over.  We went with another couple and had a great time though, although 2 1/2 hours is too insane to have me wanting to come back.  It's a good "experience" but I'd much rather hit a better steakhouse somewhere in River North of near the loop.   And yes, everyone is right when they say it's inexpensive ($60 per couple, including two appetizers, a ton of meat, 2 espressos, and tip)...but we spent $50 per couple at the bar next door during our wait, plus another $30 on bottles of wine, so it's a wash. Believe what everyone says on the wait...we got there at 7pm on Saturday night and were seated at 9:30pm.

This is one of my top places in Chicago. It was my first thought when I had my meat and potatoes loving brother coming to Chicago to spend his birthday with me. My sister and her boyfriend who flew in for the occasion would love it as well. Two hour quoted wait? Fine. We had drinks to get to while we caught up with each other and worked up an appetite. Three hours later, we figured we'd head to the door and see if we were near. This is probably where we made our mistake. Yes... ignorance is bliss. I wish we hadn't talked to the other waiting patrons that were eerily beginning to resemble an angry mob outside. I learned that our mistake was not slipping the door guy some cash. Even offering to break up our party, or squeeze into a smaller table produced no results. I watched as people that had been waiting less entered first. Sometimes I despise my naive trust in people. Four hours from the time we put our name in, we finally got the call. By this time we were gagging down fried appetizers from the late night menu at Blue Bayou. Yuck.  I hate that one of two nights my family's in town has been wasted in what could have been fixed with twenty bucks. So, if you want delicious food in under four hours? Bring cash money.

What a good good day with that El Filet.  Poppin' bottles of vino, housing empanadas/blood sausage/fancy cheese dish/eggplant apps followed by the main course with the spinach mashed potatoes. Truly an unbelievable experience, I'll be back for another round of El Filet.

Came here last night, did not have to wait for a table at all and received some of the best service I've had in a while!  The place is super small and we sat at one of the tiniest tables, but it fit the "romantic" setting perfectly! We brought two bottles of wine and was not bothered or rushed to move on as we finished both bottles. I let my dinner date choose what we were going to eat since it is one of their favorite restaurants so I don't know the names of the dishes but i'll describe what we ate below? We ordered: melon prosciutto appetizer and... a HEART ATTACK MEAT PLATTER hahahhaha the meat platter comes out on a grill with about six different cuts of meat on it.  Grilled and seasoned to perfection!  It was indeed tasty, but a bit too meat-astic for me. I was told that the desserts are also very delectable but did not have room for that in my stomach.  Definitely will be coming back to try more of their menu! PLUS the b.y.o.b. factor made our bill minuscule in comparison to our other dinners!
byob delicious argentinian food.   a great date spot.  a little loud and crowded for anything but.
Overrated.  Waited 2.5 hours and it was actually not that great.  I will give it another try, but I was disappointed.  Pasta was heinous

BYOB Meat Party.  Never fails.  Go early to avoid the crowds and you can always get seated.  Go even earlier if you want table on the patio in the summer.  2 ways to enjoy the Sur:  either a table for 4 good friends on the patio and a bottle of wine each OR a candlelight dinner table for 2 in a hot dark corner.  Please don't try to show up with a party of 8 at 7pm on a Friday.  Save that for the Wicker Park.... what happened to the expansion plan Sur?

I'm quite surprised with all of the 4 and 5 star ratings.  I don't think I've ever had a really good steak here; however, I've had some great experiences.  The intimate setting works a for a date or even a small group.  The empanadas and chimichurri are delicious; however, the steaks are not very good quality.  Since there's a good hour between the time you order and actually get your steak, I think most people have gone through a couple bottles of wine and are just hungry.

Don't say I didn't warn you...you WILL have to wait.  A very long time.  A very, very, very long time (up to 2 hours) if you come for dinner on a busy weekend night.  The downside: waiting is tough, especially if you are hungry.  The upside: you've been forewarned, so you will come earlier know, with the expectation of waiting.   Is the wait worth it?  Quite simply, yes, it is.  This authentic Argentinian steakhouse serves up amazing beef dishes (I recommend the filet mignon) for a very reasonable price.  Plus, it's BYOB, so you can bring whatever bottle (however fancy, or not) you'd like, and there is no corkage fee.  The portions are VERY generous...we ordered the filet mignon "for 2," and there was still at least a 1/2 pound of meat left when ordering.  Keep this in mind when ordering....you may even be able to split an entree meant for one, if you're not super hungry and you've had an appetizer or two (I recommend the chicken empanadas...crispy and delicious) The atmosphere is relaxed and romantic, everything a great BYOB should be.  The atmosphere is delightful, with low lighting (only candlelight on the tables), adding a warm glow to the place. Insider's tip:  If it's cold outside and you need to kill some time, there's a bar a few doors down.  You can put your name down as well as your number, and they will call you when they are ready for you.  Remember to keep your phone out, though, so you don't miss your chance!

Tango Sur was my first Chicago dining experience right after I got off the plane. It was 11PM, I was starving, most places were closed but Tango saved my stomach. This Argentinian restaurant had a great atmosphere: dimly lit with candles on each table, themed art and seating, Latin music in the back ground, groups of nicely dressed yuppies chatting the night away while enjoying the BYOB aspect. That's right peeps, BYOB and no corkage fee. A couple next to me definitely went hard and destroyed 2 bottles of wine, very impressive. Food was also quite excellent. Started with a couple empanadas which were freshly baked and piping hot. The ham and cheese one tasted like a Hot Pocket so I would go with the beef. It comes with this awesome garlic pesto-like sauce that's so off -the-hook good you would dip anything you can get your hands on in it. The main attraction was the Vacio, a cast iron baking dish loaded with like 5 pounds of flank stake smothered in a herb oil and capers and surrounded by wedges of sweet potatoes. The menu claims it serves 2 but I think it can easily satisfy an entire 3rd world country. Lets just say, I don't usually take doggy bags home but this monster owned me. Prices are great when you consider the portion, service, and ambiance. This was an awesome start to my vacation!

Everyone has pretty much covered most everything about this place, but I can't emphasize enough how awesome it is to get the bill here.  Having just enjoyed a super nice bottle of wine (that we brought ourselves, BYO obv) and enjoyed all the steak you can possibly eat, leaving for around $50 just makes you feel awesome. Oh yeah, delicious food and great ambiance too.  But the bill... great for cheapskates like me.

I would only come to this place if I was craving steak because that is the only thing I ate that I really liked. But as far as steak goes, it was delicious and very reasonably priced PLUS it's byob, doesn't get much better than that!

I like this place, where else can you get two filets for $20 dollar range?  I always get the filet so I can't comment on the other menu items.  The food is good, it's an Argentine steak house, although the food does not really taste as great as the food in Argentina does.  It is BYOB which is good and it's a great value.  I typically go early evening when there is no wait and have always been seated right away.  Keep in mind it's a small space and pretty cramped, so if you're looking for an intimate dinner spot this is not it!!
It was ok... B.Y.O.B, that was the high lite of this place.  its over rated .   ( thats my opin )

Can we all start chanting over-rated?  For starters we made a 7pm reservation and were called twice to make sure we showed up on time.  Apparently, there was a group with our table coming at 9pm and they wanted to make sure we would get in and out without inconveniencing the next group.  I'm cool with that.  But when we arrived at 6:55pm we were told our table wasn't ready yet.  We were seated at 7:35pm.  Good thing we showed up on time.  If you are going to have the guts to calls patrons and tell them to show up and then leave by the next reservation, you should also have the guts to kick out those who overstay.  Poor form and a bad welcome to this hot spot.  Doesn't help that you have a couple of guys standing and blocking the door like this is some trendy NY night club.  Repeatedly they blocked folks from going inside to sit at their table with friends that had arrived earlier.  This place has clearly gotten too big for its britches. The food...meh.  I ordered the bone in rib-eye thinking this is the only way to have a steak.  Instead, it was boring and fatty.  Lacked flavor.  I will say that the eggplant appetizer was good but everything else was sub par, especially for the street cred this place enjoys.   I think people get loaded on their wine and that is why they think this place is great.  Either that or they are all coming after Cubs games and bombed.  Could be that they are all Wrigleyville folks who dine on bar food and think this is a fine steak.  BYOB or not, my friends and I won't be returning.

So glad we didn't go to Wildfire (my brother's choice for his birthday).  But instead, I suggested that we try out Tango Sur, which I've been wanting to try for the longest time. Bottom line is that you get a lot of delicious meat for you what you pay, but you have to wait a really long time for it.  I ordered the churrasco, which was a 12-ounce juicy steak, my brother got the filet mignon, which he loved, and my mom and aunt shared the para dos sampler, which was interesting and huge!!  I was able to try blood sausage, which was alright.  But I loved the throat sweetbread.....so crunchy and tasty! We came at around noontime....great time to go since it wasn't crowded and we were seated right away!    Service is friendly and attentive.  I'll be returning, probably one evening with my husband.
At a great time. Best combination of steak and byob in the city.  Just  be prepared for the crowds.

Terrible service. I went on a Sunday night with a friend. They were just in a hurry to get us out of there. The staff looked like a bunch of high school kids. There was a lot of slamming as they frantically cleaned. The waiter even wanted to take my plate as I was still eating. I was very insulted. In all, it felt like it was being run by sloppy kids. I will say the food was quite good and the atmosphere would have been been better if I wasn't distracted by there terrible service. I even called the next day to ask for a manager to let him/her know the Sunday night staff is lacking. He barely seemed to care. I doubt I'll go back any time soon.

Yummy stuff. Atmosphere is great. Yes your table may be close to the next, but the warm atmosphere, candlelit tables and amazing smelling food will make you forget about it.  its BYOB heaven. Don't be in rush or impatient if you come for dinner. If you have impatient friends, leave em at home & make them jealous when you tell them about the great time you had.  Bring some wine, put your name on the list and relax or to to a bar next door until your table is ready. Its allll worth it, the food rocks.

Great prices, tasty meat and nice atmosphere PLUS it's BYO - what more could you ask for? Exposed brick walls, dim lighting and candles on the table make this a fun and inexpensive date place. There's outdoor seating, too, if the weather's nice. Service was good and unobtrusive.  For dinner my friend and I shared the vascio and the currasco. Both were cooked perfectly, though the cut on the vascio was kind of gristly. The salad that came with was uninteresting to the extreme - almost not even worth having at all - it consisted of one slice of tomato and a few onion rings on a bed of chopped lettuce and was undressed (though oil and vinegar were provided, I think). You also get rolls, but they, too, are unremarkable. Anyway the whole meal came to $40 for 2 including tax and tip, and we had more than enough to eat. At that price, you really can't complain...

This place is AMAZING. After reading tons of great reviews on Yelp, I was really excited about going to Tango Sur. My boyfriend had been there before and said the food was great. So we went on a Friday night. Yes there was a wait and yes it was crowded, but considering it was a full house, the service wasn't as slow as I expected.  The place is small and very dark. There are candles on the table and it's a BYOB. (Guys: This place will score you some points with the ladies.) The food is fairly priced for the large portions that they serve.  I had the Bife Vesuvio, which was a large prime steak stuffed with spinach and cheese. The cheese melted so nicely, it was almost creamy. The meat was served with a side of roasted potatoes and what I believe was a chimichurri sauce. That plate was more than enough food for me and it was delicious! I HIGHLY recommend this place.

Be hungry...be very hungry. This Argentine restaurant serves great grilled food.  Get there early or expect LONG waits.  The portions of the steaks were enormous...but very tasty.  And for those who like tongue...excellent choice for appetizer. On the other hand, the place is very small.  It was very tight in there!

I went on a Sunday evening with one guest and was seated immediately. The space was cramped and very loud, but comfortable. The service was good. I had the filet mignon and it was fantastic! Overall this was a very good experience and the quality of the food is high.

C and I went on a date to Tango Sur last night.  Actually, we ate a late lunch/early dinner there about a month ago.  C had the Berenjenas and I had the chicken with lemon.  Both really good; we ate outside, which was perfect; it was BYOB and there is a handy store about a half block south; and, the service was very good.  Four stars for that experience. Back to last night:  Our friends had brought us a bottle of 2006 Norton Malbec D.O.C from Buenos Aires recently and we were saving it for a dinner at Tango Sur.  It's a favorite when we're in BA, which is often. We arrived at about 7:30 pm and were immediately seated (a Wednesday night) at one of the last two tables that were open. Tall lit candles established a romantic atmosphere, but the main room (i.e. where you enter) was quite noisy.  Fortunately, the second, larger room was a bit quieter, but the sound level was still quite high. The sounds of merriment.  The decor and atmosphere is very convincingly equivalent to restaurants in Buenos Aires.  Once I tasted the Malbec, I was transported 5,000 miles to Buenos Aires, where restaurants like this are ubiquitous.  Of course, the prices printed on the menus there are almost the same, but they are in Argentine pesos, so the cost is at least third less (i.e. $1 USD = $3.7 pesos). In addition to being seating immediately, our waiter was at our table almost instantly with bread and butter and to open our wine.  We were impressed.  The place is crawling with wait staff.  Okay, let's get to assigning STARS: Ambiance:  As I said earlier, visually, the ambiance is totally Buenos Aires.  Whoever put this place together is a Porteño or has spent some serious time in BA. Although I give Tango Sur a point for ambiance, there were a couple of disappointments. First, the music could barely be heard over the ambient crowd noise.  The only thing we could hear, seated by the window, was the bass line, which is annoying.  Lousy speakers and not enough of them; what else can I say. However, the music was good and what we hear in Buenos Aires. I almost want to give them a point for that!  Second, the bread is served with little plastic packets of butter, rather than actual pats of butter. That's simply inelegant, for a restaurant of this caliber. Too bad. Third, and this is unfortunate, when they cleared the appetizer plates, they took the knife (good), but left my dirty fork (bad).  It was deposited exactly were I would naturally lean with my elbow.  A fresh fork is in order. Food:  The beef empanadas were good.  The papas espanola so-so. For an entree we shared the Lomo Relleno, which is a "half slab argentine filet sliced and filled with a chimichurri, ham sauce then cooked and served on a grill with portabella marsala."  ($36, serves 2).  The piece of meat was enormous; enough, in my opinion, for four, or there is no ordering desert. The gravy was simply divine. I mean absolutely divine.  The lomo (i.e. beef tenderloin), shockingly, was awful; the worst piece of beef tenderloin I have ever had in my life. C was in complete agreement.  It was stringy like you can't believe.  I literally could not chew 50% of what I put in my mouth.  When the waiter stopped to ask how we were enjoying our beef, we told him the truth. He looked stunned. We described the problem, which he could see as I was struggling to cut the meat with a steak knife.  He immediately said, "one moment," and fled.  The manager returned and offered to order something else.  We appreciated the gesture, but declined, because we had had enough meat for the evening anyway.  He and the waiter were both very apologetic.  Clearly, this was not the norm.  We simply got a bum piece; it happens.  I don't know what the couple at the next table was having (it also looked large), but they were enjoying it!  Based on our first experience, I give Tango Sur a star for food.  I am sure that the lomo experience was an anomaly.  (note:  the menu states "argentine fillet." however, the manager conceded that it is not technically Argentine.  That they get beef from Canada and Australia.  Minor point." Service:  I have seen other posts complaining about the service. There are lapses at all restaurants, but our two experiences here were positive.  The waiters were friendly, courteous and helpful. Certainly deserving a full point.  BTW, at the conclusion of our meal last night, the check arrived with a deep discount, which was very much appreciated.   BYOB:  another point! In summary, we'll be back for another try.

I took off of work early on a Sunday  so the GF and I could check out Tango Sur as word of mouth from the family who owns the place was extremely good. Usually I do not go this far east to eat but I made a exception for this encounter and I can say it was well worth it.  Parking was not really a issue, yes we had to park about 3 blocks away but I expected that from this neighborhood. We went around 6:30 PM so it was not crowded, the hostess was one of the people who I spoke to about the restaurant before hand so she greeted us with a huge smile and showed us to a very cozy seat inside as we did not want to sit outside. Something about heavy traffic did not appeal to us. We sat down and first thing we noticed was the lighting was very dim, a little too dim for my taste but it was perfect for a romantic setting along with the music which fit the name.  It is a BYOB so we stuck with just water as we do with most of the placed we visit unless they have margaritas for the GF. Our waiter was the hostess husband who I have spoken to many times, we looked at the menu and the prices are not bad for a nice evening out with your spouse or GF. We were thinking about trying the empanadas but before we knew it he brought us a complimentary appetizer which was freshly baked bread and a cheese spread covered in peppers which was fantastic. We both took his recommendations for entrees based on the meat we wanted to order. I order a Filet Mignon with Spinach Mash potatoes and she ordered garlic chicken since she is a big fan of garlic. The salads were comprised of fresh ingredients and while you had only the choice of oil and vinegar as a dressing it was not bad at all. Normally when a waiter comes to your table and splashes water every where you get upset but in the case of the countless waiters who came to our table splashing water as they poured I was not upset at all. As a matter of fact the GF and I found it funny and laughed about it for a while. The food came and my jaw dropped, I could not believe the portions they gave us! I had to perfectly cooked Filets and could barley get one down so I took the other one home. (Note: Do not bother taking the mash home, it does not hold up well) The GF barely made a dent in her meal and before we knew it we had to go containers right in front of us. We were stuffed and could not eat another bite. My GF read the reviews for Tango Sur before coming and was dying to try the Flan but just didn't have the room so when he asked us if we wanted desert we politely declined. As soon as he left the table she informed me of her desire to try the flan but the fact that she did not think she could fit it in. I laughed as he walked up to the table with a order of flan before she had a chance to finish her sentence. It was complimentary and I shared with him are talk and he insisted we should find the room to fit it in. We did, and let me tell you right now it was the highlight of the meal... I do not like flan but this made me like it and if nothing else was good about the entire meal we would come back for the flan. We left feeling really good about the experience and will be sure to go back. Thanks to Jenny & Edgar for making our experience GREAT...

You've got to love the reasonable prices for big platters, BYOB, and most especially the chimichurri sauce from heaven that goes with absolutely everything. The meat was juicy, cooked just right, and served in man-sized portions, I haven't had a more satisfying protein fix in town for the prices they were running at. The parrillada para dos was the best $31 bucks my friend and I ever collectively spent. The waiters bent over backwards for us, almost literally as we were seated at the FAAARRRR end of the long outdoor patio in a very tight space.  No corkage fee, A+ Tango Sur. As an aside: I learned something from this dining experience, restaurants have to open booze indoors before serving outside, so our waiters to walk indoors, uncork our wine, then bring it back. Another one to add to the list of confusing, pointless Chicago municipal regulations. Thanks Richie! The only knock against the place is where we were seated, looking into the local convenience shop with the flourescent lights on. Its just not worth the extra tables to take us away from the atmosphere of the place.

We decided to eat here after reading rave reviews on Yelp.  The wait was pretty decent for a Friday night (only an hour) however the only thing I remember was not the food - it was the astoundingly bad service.  Not only was it slow, it was just bad.  We asked 4 different waiters (ours was nowhere to be found) for some sauce to dip our dry bife vesuvius in and nobody came back.  The empenadas were good, the spinach mash was just OK and the bife vesuvius (stuffed meat) was dry as a bone and cringingly salty.  After a long day of flying in from Cali, we just wanted to get the hell out of there. The meat was way overdone and to be honest I'd write more although I'm just trying to forget I came here. You'd figure for Chicago, the meat reviews would be on point... totally not worth the wait. The highlight of the night was that the review we read pointed us a few doors down to Sensational Bites, a great dessert place.
