Cate M. is on to something.  We had almost the same experience except everyone was being sat before us.  When we finally got sat I asked what happened.  He showed me the wait list and said their names where before ours.  I pointed to my name at the top of the list.  They just did not give a crap.  We really felt we could not get a table being three brown people.  All the groups that got sat before us yet came after us where white.  I hate thinking this but It was really blatant.   ***********TANGO SUR IS RACIST.  YES REALLY THEY ARE********

Been meaning to go here for quite some time and was finally able to make it a couple weeks ago. Every time I pass, it's packed to the gills - no matter the season or the day of the week. I definitely know why now!  This place takes me back to sitting in Argentina, delicious steak, red wine and french bread...nothing more simple or more delicious of a meal. Start off with the simple salad and go for the steak -- you won't be disappointed.  Makes a great spot for not only a hot date, but a group evening as well. Added bonus is the BYOB factor, bring an extra bottle or two because the ambiance will suck you in most definitely.

Been meaning to go here for quite some time and was finally able to make it a couple weeks ago. Every time I pass, it's packed to the gills - no matter the season or the day of the week. I definitely know why now! This place takes me back to sitting in Argentina, delicious steak, red wine and french bread...nothing more simple or more delicious of a meal. Start off with the simple salad and go for the steak -- you won't be disappointed.  Makes a great spot for not only a hot date, but a group evening as well. Added bonus is the BYOB factor, bring an extra bottle or two because the ambiance will suck you in most definitely.

Im not a typical meat eater so I cannot say that I am an expert on steaks.  One of my favorite spots is David Burke.  I remember going to Tango Sur with my bf a year or two ago.  We were seated and the air condition was not working and this was in July.  It was very dark, loud and HOT (not in a good way) inside so we stood up and left immediately.  Some co workers decided to have dinner there friday night so I went.  We got there at 630 and was seated immediately which is a good thing considering that this place is notorious in making you wait for hours to be seated so I was happy about that.  The server was very accomodating and pleasant.  This place is BYOB so thats another plus.  We all ordered steaks,  I had the EL Filet I think which was a filet mignon, it was tasy tender and juicy, the spinach mashed potatos were so so.  We has chicken and beef empanadas and I like the chicken better than the beef.   The place is verrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrryy loud, one of those places where you have to talk on top of your lungs to be heard by someone across the table.  I didnt like that at all.  I mean, its good to go to a fun place but having to shout during dinner is quite annoying.  Towards the end of the evening around 9, the host came to our table and asked us to either go to the bar or move on.  When we left, there was a huge crowd outside waiting to be seated.  OMG, who eats heavy steak dinners after 930?  This place has good reasonable steaks.  The frontliners/maitre d/host need to take a crash course in customer service, maybe they think that because they have a huge influx of customers that they can talk to customers the way they do, no pleasantries just instructions and some frozen cold shoulders,  you stay there, go there, sit there, etc etc.  No no no huney this aint argentina or wherever continent you came from.  Here in america, service is key, that is why people  all over the world love this country because people here know what customer service is all about which is part of one's dining experience.   If it werent for those frontliners I would have given this place an overall rating of 3.5 Food - 4 Service - 3 Ambience - 2 Will I be rushing back to this place anytime soon?  If im broke and craving for good steaks maybe.

After reading all the reviews on Yelp, we went to Tango Sur on Saturday night for date night. I knew the wait would be crazy but we went anyway. After waiting 90 minutes they sat us right next to the door. So close to the door infact, that anyone who came in or out of the building knocked into our chair because we were so close. I thought, well, maybe the food's really good and I won't mind this.  The ambiance was fine. Candlelight... of course the wind was so strong and we were seated directly next to the door that our candle kept wafting smoke into my face, but I guess they can't control that... The tables were really close to one another. And it was very loud, which is to be expected on a Sat. night at a BYOB place but we spent most of the dinner having to listen to our neighbors who were seated a foot away...  I give them one star because the service was extremely prompt. Whenever we needed our water refilled the staff was there immediately.  The other star is for the food. It wasn't anything to write home about.  My fiance ordered the ribeye steak. He said it was okay, but that there were parts of it that just sucked. I had the Milanesa A Caballo, which was beef, breaded and topped with two fried eggs. Again, maybe we had really high expectations, but it wasn't amazing.  All in all, the food was decent, but not worth the 90 minute wait and the cramped surroundings.

So yes, I know that I'm not supposed to write a review if I didn't eat there, but as I have previously eaten there, I feel that I can still update it to say this. Last night my bf and I tried to go there for a nice dinner. I knew in advance that I wanted to go out, so I had him wear a nice shirt and pants to work. Then I got all gussied up myself so that we could go to Tango Sur. We were of course prepared for a wait as it was Friday night and having been there before/read many reviews, we knew what was coming. The problem was that when we got there, there weren't many people. We put our names down and were told 40 minutes to an hour. 40 minutes go by and still nothing. We go to the waiting area in the back which has zilch to do other than talk to the person you came with, which you can do just as easily outside. They don't seem to be too organized, so I insisted we go back outside so that they would actually see us. My bf spoke with the host not once, not twice, but THREE times and each of these times, the host had no clue who he was (I feel knowing your customer is part of being a good host and have never encountered that before). When we left the waiting room to go back outside, he thanked us for coming. We had to explain we hadn't even eaten yet, just moved back outside. While we were going back through the restaurant on our way outside, we noticed several large tables (by large tables I just mean lots of 2 person tables pushed together) being freed up. We thought we would soon be seated, but no. Rather than do what is right and separate the big tables for those couples who have been waiting a long time (there were 4 or 5 couples waiting just as long as we were), they chose to seat the groups of 6+ who arrived 30+ minutes after we did and put their names in. Not cool. After about an hour and 15 minutes, we left. We were super hungry at that point and I was getting crankier and crankier. We chose to go to Azha, another BYOB place (for we purchased wine to drink at Tango Sur) not too far away. They FINALLY called us to tell us our table was ready nearly 2 hours  after we arrived. It really made me angry that they so poorly underestimated how much time we'd be waiting. Frankly, we could've seen a movie at the Music Box down the street in the time that we were waiting for a table. It very much irked me that people who arrived later were given seats before us simply because they had more people and big tables were available first. It would be good business practice in that case to separate a freed up big table for the couples who've been waiting a long time. Needless to say, we were both completely disappointed. We took a chance with the Friday night (because they stupidly-in my opinion- still don't take reservations) and were fine with waiting 40 mins to an hour. No biggie. But the gross underestimation of time we actually had to wait was completely ridiculous. When they finally did call, we were already enjoying our appetizers at Azha. Maybe someday we'll go back, but never on a Friday night (or weekend night) again and not while we're actually pretty hungry. Totally disappointed I didn't get to have the wonderful food again, but frankly, when you're actually hungry it's just not worth the wait.

If you can avoid the crowds, give this place a try.  We got here on a Saturday around 4-5ish to avoid the crowd and were seated immediately. The restaurant is BYOB so drink up!  (Note, if you get there and there's a wait they'll give you wine glasses so you can drink while you wait.)   Portions are huge!  I got the El Fillet which looked like two 16 ounce fillets with some mashed potatoes. This dish could've been split between two people.  The sauce they used was super yummy.  You can't beat the price either, the El Fillet came out to $25 bucks and I promise you, you'll come home with 2 meals worth of leftovers.

Last week, we had a chance to visit our Argentinean friends over at Tango Sur, located in Lakeview off of Southport and Grace, for some real-deal, holy-field, South American cuisine (the fact that lots of Argentinians eat here really legitimized it for us). This place is fantastic and is one of the Southport corridor's better-known, long-standing establishments. If  you haven't had a chance to visit this restaurant yet, or if you have yet to try Argentinean food, make sure to put this on your list of things to do. First, let's talk about the fresh rolls - they start you with a basket of six with lots of pats of real butter. and they're warm and soft in the inside, crusty on the outside.  They're a great filler while you're waiting for your food, which can take some time at this place.  In fact, we tried to pace ourselves but ended up eating all of them before the food arrived. Lois ordered the "Milanesa De Pollo," seasoned breaded chicken breast, served with seasoned potatoes and a salad.  Delicious.  The chicken breading was crispy and flavorful (but don't ask her what flavors exactly -- she was really hungry and practically inhaled the thing) but the chicken itself was tender...the kind of tender you only need a fork to cut.  The salad was a perfect size with some nice onion and tomato and a do-it-yourself side of oil and vinegar.  The only thing that could have made the dinner better would have been more crispness to the potatoes. Clark ordered "Milanesa a Caballo," a giant slab of beef steak, breaded, fried, and topped with two fried sunny side up eggs and served with seasoned potatoes. The beef was of great quality, and I don't know exactly what they do to the meat, but I'm pretty sure they prepare it with a dry rub of spices and flavors, making this a great tasting meal, but a little on the dry side. The only thing that would make this dish better is if they served it with a side of some kind of pouring or dipping sauce. The sunny side up eggs were a nice touch to this dish. I guess the yolk could potentially be the dipping sauce, but it was not satisfying or what I was exactly looking for in a dip. The yolk was just too bland and not what this steak needed, but it did provide the moisture to take half of the steak down without choking. The potato "wedges" are quite excellent, seasoned with who knows what, but I detected a little bit of rosemary in them, and proportion wise, it was good, they didn't over do it with quantity. I didn't even get to finish my potatoes, due to such a big portion of steak. I figure next time, I won't go for the breaded steak but the big hunk of beef that the guests at the next table had. It was a giant roast of meat set on a constant burning flame, and it looked j-u-u-u-u-u-icey! It was also surrounded by constantly-sizzling vegetables.  Basically, the ultimate dinner for two, or three, maybe even four. A friend had told us that he and another friend ordered this dish before and these two burly meat loving men couldn't even finish it. The guests who ordered this at the table next to us, a man and a woman, looked defeated even after consuming about half of the chunk of meat. Other things to know....this place gets crowded fast and early (we were there at 5 and it was filling up), but it's a little better in the summer because they have some nice outdoor dining space in the front of the restaurant and the Argentinean grocery store next door. Tango Sur is also BYOB, but if you don't come prepared there are plenty of places to grab a bottle or a six-pack in the area. Finally, if you still have room for dessert afterward skip the selection at Tango and head a few doors south to Sensational Bites.  This dessert cafe has an overwhelming selection of sweets and a few choice coffees to go along with them.  Lois loves the peanut butter cupcake (chocolate cake, peanut butter-buttercream frosting) while I'm a fan of the Boston cream cupcake. Tango ended up costing a little over $40 with tip and Sensational Bites about $7 for the two cupcakes.  A little more extravagant than our usual, but worth the spend.

My 100th review is for a restaurant that smacked a grand slam out of the park. This place is fantastic. I'm just going to list everything that is great about this restaurant because I am a no talent ass clown that shouldn't be allowed to write reviews.  -BYOB  -The El Filet is softball sized and it melts in your mouth  -Gerado the singer of Rico Suave was our waiter  -Dinner by candle light so everyone can't see how hammered I am  -The empanadas are delicious(jamon con queso being my favorite) -BYOB -Very reasonable prices  -Spinach mashed potatoes are a funky green color and tasty -Did I mention BYOB?  This place is great, as you can tell from my list.  I'm disappointed it's taken me this long to try this place out.  Bring your appetite and a bottle of wine and be prepared to wipe the drool off your face. This place is a meat lovers dream. I will say it gets really loud in there, but who needs to talk when I have a juicy steak staring you in the face.  I can't wait to go back!

Tango Sur is one of my favorite Argentine Steakhouses in Chicago! The elegant and classy candle-lit atmosphere brings this storefront BYOB restaurant to every meat lover's dream! Grilling large cuts of Argentinian beef topped with chimichurri is my order of choice! They never fail to provide excellent service, both indoor and outdoor seating , exquisite fresh food. Ideal - for second date...
Love this place.   A lot of good food for a really resonable price.  You can eat inside or outside- okay ambience but if you like good food that is really the reason you go here.
What I liked best was the simplicity of the food - not overdone with seasoning, etc. Just natural flavor. Pretty large portions, almost burst my belly. Extra dark for the romanticos.

Yeah.  No.  I didn't like this place very much, I'm sad to say. I don't like writing bad reviews, so this is not an enjoyable thing to do, especially when so many people seem to like this place. WAITING It was Wednesday night at 8:30 and there were people waiting to get in, so I thought, "This place must be good."  Well, I think people wait there so long, not b/c of great fanfare, but because once you're in the restaurant, they keep you captive with the incredibly slow and unresponsive service. SERVICE Slow, so slow. Something as simple as bringing out the salad after the appetizers took a long time. We sat there staring at the crumbs on the empty table for a very long time (the crumbs from the crumbly, unsubstantive bread that is provided), of course all the while making sparkling conversation, not JUST staring at the dumb crumbs in silence...  We saw waiters with salads whizzing by and placing a ton of them on other tables, but not ours. We thought maybe our meals didn't come with the salads. No. It just took about a half hour to get after our appetizers.  And then it was another long wait for the food. My water glass stayed low throughout the night with our waiter no where in sight to ask for more. FOOD Not so great. Not impressed. At first, you're excited b/c it LOOKS great. The portions look HUGE and flavorful. But while the steaks are large, they were all tough (and we ordered ours medium-rare). We all needed to drown it in chimichurri sauce to try and compensate. The meats we had were: strip steak, sirloin, veal chop, bone-in ribeye. All tough. We also had the empanadas (beef and a spinach/cheese) and were disappointed. We drowned those in chimichurri sauce as well, to compensate. AMBIANCE: Nice, we were outside. I recommend it if you have the choice, weather permitting. Otherwise, it's VERY LOUD inside the restaurant.

So there's long lines, and no where to wait! bet trust me its worth it, byob and the only place to really get a true taste of what a CHE BOLUDO dreams for.  Dont fool around with any individual plates, get the Parillada (pronounced PAH-rri-SHA-da.. say it with me now), and dont bother asking what anything is. You may not wanna know you're are eating blood sausage or sweet breads.. but you'll miss out on a mouth-gasm if you do.  Snack on some empanadas and matambre if you are really hungry and even try the lengua if youre feelin' saucy.  OK.. one last thing, for desert, order the multy layer ojaldre cake made by Anita. Think flaky buttery filo dough intermixed with an even every-layer distribution of dulce de leche, topped with a homemade chanitlli whipped creamed and chocolate sauce (aka mouth-gasm #2). I'm biased however my gramma (born and raised in buenos aires) makes these cakes and sells them to this restaurant every week.. and they're so good it'll make you wanna slap yo' pappy.  Salud!

My parents are from Michigan so I was hoping to surprise them with a BYOB and a cheaper bill!  They love their wine.  I forgot to make reservations so I called on Saturday hoping to get in that night and they said we might be able to get in around 8:30. Well we got in BEFORE 8:30 with a ton of people waiting.  We sat outside and were pleasantly surprised by the fast, attentive service (aka - how fast they opened the next wine bottle). And then came the food.  We had the melted prosciutto with red peppers, which was amazing.  And I can't speak for everyone, but my entree was great.  The beef vesuvio was stuffed with spinach and cheese and was tender and cooked to a perfect medium.  It was absolutely delicious. Definitely will be back.

It was my first time--and I will likely return.  My boyfriend and I went on a Tuesday, and had no wait at 8pm. The service was fast and attentive. We dressed up a bit for our anniversary, though the table next to us was a group of guys in jeans drinking Corona--either approach seemed appropriate.  We had a cheese appetizer (literally: it was melted cheese) that was very good, followed by El Filet (we split it--seriously... split this thing).  The filets were underdone for medium, but pretty good , and certainly worth the price.  I think I'll try something else next time. the flan was heaven. Split that one too. In short: go on the week, bring wine, split it (for $5), have a fancy romantic dinner on the cheap.

I wish you could give 1/2 stars for this very reason.  4.5 stars!  How have I never been to this place.  It was outstanding.  We had a large group of 15, and they were great with us.  I had a veal t-bone that was as good as the one I had at MK.   The byo factor was fantastic, and kept dinner per person under $35... i'll be going back soon!

This place is amazing! Since you basically get two filets with one order, it's always an option to save money and split the meal (for a small fee). That's what the bf and I did and we got an appetizer (the melted cheese and bread, I forgot what it's called). So with splitting the meal and bringing our own booze we ended up leaving with a bill around $40. Not too bad for an appetizer and both of us getting steak filets and leaving with our stomach's full (a feat in and of itself for the bf).  We sat right down and didn't have to wait at all but we did make sure to get there early and we sat outside and noticed that the line did accumulate quickly.

I love El Filet and the spinach mashed potatoes. The chimichurri is delish also! And don't forget the flan, totally creamy and carmelly and amazing. The wait can be awhile (up to an hour and a half on friday and saturday nights), but you can wait at the bar, and the host will call your cell!  I think the wait is worth it, especially if I've been fantasizing about tender filets, tangy salads, peppers and cheese dip, and flan all week. One bonus is the BYOB: it's a great way to cut costs on a date (drinks are always a big chunk of our dinners). There's great little wine shop across the street too (que syrah) with bottles as low as $9 to go with your spicy argentinian meats. If you're daring and really into meat-experimentation, you can get the sampling of meat cuts that come on a little grill (warning: includes blood sausage!). If you don't feel like steak, there is also a delicious half a chicken with steak fries, or a eggplant stack like a lasagne that's filling yet guilt-free. I also had a great sea bass there one time, but always return to my El Filet.

They must be doing something right here...hard to get in even on a Sunday night?? Hmm...this was the choice restaurant for a girl we were celebrating her first marathon ran and she deserved to eat what she wanted. This was the place. BYOB, OK score a few points for that!  We didn't have to wait too long passed our "reservation" before we were finally sat. The waiter promptly opened our wine and took our orders and pretty much disappeared. After some long amount of time passed and us all apologizing for the stomach rumbles that were erupting under the tables, we finally got our empandada appetizers. I had a beef one and it was ok, a bit dry. We woofed them down in sheer hunger. Finally, oh finally, the meat I have heard about all night arrives and I was a bit scared at how big the portion was. Was this Medieval Times? It read "serves 2" and I swear it should have served a family of 5. It was known as Lomo Relleno...a half slab of Argentine meat covered in this amazing chimichurri sauce that I hope to find the recipe for, and a mushroom marsala type of sauce. It was delicious and my mouth was watering. There was so much of it that I had left overs for 2 more meals. Extremely reasonably priced too! After this we were so full there was no such room for dessert, sigh. Worth the wait...hmmm...maybe if I didn't arrive so hungry.
Yummy steaks!  It's a reasonably priced steak place that's BYOB so right there you save a lot of money.  If you're a steak person, which I definitely am, you'll love Tango Sur!

Oh Tango Sur, you're extremely overrated.  It's all about the BYOB and yuppie location.  For those who have been to Argentina for a fair amount of time, you know good meat...and you realize that their steaks are fatty and well overpriced (so much that you think you're paying in pesos once the bill arrives).  It's bad when I need to turn to dousing my 'bife' in chimichurri salsa to ignore the chewiness.  I will give it to them that the interior ambiance with live music under candlelight is very Porteno.  Oh and their outdoor patio is pleasant, and would have been even nicer if one of the four gas lamp heaters worked.  With that said, I hope their new Argentinean steakhouse Folklore in Wicker Park is of better quality and will have more grass-fed (slim), prime (less chewy) and free-range (always a plus) beef options as they promise.  For now, try El Nandu in Logan Square.

Not a lot of places can get away with both being byob and no reservations taken, especially the no reservations part. The servers are not going to check up on you as often as you are used to so keep in mind to order anything or ask any questions when you do get them at your table. Otherwise, if you are going to a restaurant for the good old fashion reason--good food--then this place is definitely worth checking out. Great steaks!

Wow.  I cant believe I have overlooked this place.. no longer! I went with three other people. I ordered my own bone in rib eye, which was great.  Two people split a large fillet mignon.  They were forced to pay $5 to split it, but they did get more salad as a result.  The 4th person ate the eggplant appetizer for their main meal, and loved it.   Combine the above meal with being BYOB, and our tab was only $66.  A great value!

went here a week ago. i live 2 min away and the food always looked/smelled good. we got their early and got a table outside. i know its outside furniture but it was all rusted bent wobbly tables and chairs. our waiter always ran off doing who knows what. its very annoying when EVERYBODY that goes their is drunk. im serious. i know its BYOB but everybody was wasted. very annoying. i got a steak and at first it was great. of course it was not how i asked it to be cooked. then when i came home i had serious stomach problems the rest of the night after eating there.... wont see me there again. also most of the ppl that do go there are rich yuppies who prob dont have a single original thought in their head.

I may be the only person in the city not impressed with this place. I recently got paid for a big job I worked, and we decided to try this place out. We walk by it all the time, and it always smells amazing. So, we got there around 7pm, early enough to only have to wait a couple of minutes for a table. A table that was very wably, and every move sent my glass moving across the able. It took about 15 minutes for our server to appear which wasnt so bad, but after we ordered, it took over an hour for our food to show up. I may have made a mistake by not getting steak, but the food I did order had little flavor. Our server seemed to care less, and was almost impossible to get a hold of. Its not so much that I think this is a bad restaurant, it was just def not one for me. Besides all the serving issues I just felt out of place. Oh well, at least I gave it a try.

Let me first start out by saying that I absolutely love this place but I only love it for one dish... Vacio.  I would give it 4 stars but because I only like one dish, it's not really worthy of 4 stars. If you go here and order the Vacio, it's very reasonable. The salad unfortunately looks unkempt (if that's even possible).  It's just a bunch of lettuce with a few onions on top.  The oil and vinegar is tasty but rather meh as far as creativity is concerned. I've ordered other steaks here but I always go back for the Vacio!!! It's the only dish that's worth any money.  It's that good. Don't order anything else.

Delicious grilled meat? BYO? Incredible eggplant thing appy (which I would definitely order - the 1st few times I came here I refused to order anything non-meat based which I now regret)?  What could be better?  Not waiting for it.  Alas, there's always a wait, but it's worth it.

Voted #1 date spot and being BYOB, what more could you want?! Well, maybe that the space was a little bigger, but that's why you need to keep in mind to go early, or else you'll be waiting for quite a while! But it's definitely worth the wait! After popping our bottle of wine (no corkage fee by the way!), we ordered the Provoleta, which is good, but just a little too much cheese for me! For our meal, we ordered the Bife Vesuvio, which is meant for two and even though I was with a guy, we still had leftovers! Oh, and the leftoveres tasted great the next day! Tango Sur is well worth your money for the food, atmosphere and it's BYOB!!

I didn't notice some of the problems people have had here with service and the wait.  Though I'm reluctant to tell my secret, I'm a good Yelper and will do just that:  Monday night at 5:15 it's pretty empty.  We came in and were seated and served immediately and treated well. The eternal praise I hold for all things BYOB remains the case here; steak and wine is awesome, but steak and wine that costs a third of what other restaurants might charge you for it is infinitely better. As for the food, here's my take: Empanadas - we split a ham & cheese one. extraordinary Chimichurri - glorious!!!!!!! Proveleta - It's a pile of melted cheese with roasted peppers and oregano.  What's not to like?!?! Steak- I had the filet and my bf had costelleta (bone in ribeye).  Mine was cooked perfectly, but his was a touch on the chewy side for medium rare. Both were an amazingly huge portion, but not really a "prime" steak.  Still, if you go in expecting this and are impressed with a huge and tasty pile of meat, then you will not be disappointed in any way, shape, or form. Dessert - just had the napoleon, and it was decent.  Not knock-me-on-the-floor awesome, but tasty. So that pretty much sums up my experience (and the beginning of a long love affair with chimicurri sauce), and chances are I'll be returning because, really,  BYOB + pile of meat is a thing of beauty.

I came here last night and didn't feel like my experience lived up to the hype. I figured that coming here on a Tuesday night would give better service because the wait staff has more time to spend on each patron. Who knew it would be that busy still. However, I think I saw my server a total of 3 times. And I had to ask for him 2 out of those 3 times. The quickest item that came out on my table was the check. I noticed that other tables were having issues with server attention too. I guess it just comes with the territory. The grilled cheese (not sandwich) was delicious. Beef empanada was really good with the chimi sauce. And our meat that was served on a grill was huge.  The food was good, but I prefer Las Tablas steakhouse. I would go back, but when I can go to Las Tablas...why should I?

i'll admit i was wowed by this place about 2-3 years ago when i first came here. we willingly waited for an hour or so for table, loved our dishes, loved the byob, ignored the insane volume levels and rude service ... however the past two times I have gone here this year..... the food has just been well...AVERAGE at best.  For a place that's tiny, cramped, and has a host who acts like getting seated at Tango Sur is equivalent to be seated at  Charlie Trotter's, I was annoyed. I'd be willing to overlook all those things if the food was great and it's BYOB. But, to me, the food quality here has totally depreciated over the past 2 years and I'm no longer willing to overlook those things. Too many good BYOB food places in the city for me to wait forever for an 'ok' steak.

I feel that I owe it to Chicagoans to expose the true Tango Sur,  or Tango Sucks, as my friends and I like to call it.  The place continues to get good reviews, but I wonder...do these reviewers ignore the service because they are dazzled by the food?   I've been to Tango Sucks three times and on each visit, I was offended by the poor service.  On my last (and final) visit, the waiters completely ignored us and refused to accept a $50 gift certificate despite the fact that we had called earlier that day to make sure it was accepted.  They were terribly rude to us (and I've heard from others that this has happened to them) and I think it's a chauvinistic problem.  My service was still bad, but better, when I went with a guy.   With my girlfriend, we were invisible.   I honestly think the wait staff is sexist and for this, I will never, ever go back.  The food was good, but I was also very sick the next day... bye bye Tango Sucks.

Ay, dios mio! This restaurant is magnifico! My friends and I gathered here for a girls' night of meat and wine. We were seated very promptly at a table inside. The four stars is for the fact that it took our server about 20 minutes to finally come over and interact with us. In the meantime, we'd had to flag down someone to open the wine, and we asked twice if we could put in our order (hungry ladies!) But, ah....the wait was worth it! Each of us had a different type of empanada, which all disappeared in a matter of seconds. My ham and cheese was QUITE sabrosa! And then we come to the steaks. I ordered a sirloin, medium rare, which arrived perfectly cooked. It was HUGE...easily three steaks in one! With a salad beforehand and potatoes on the side. The chimichurri on the side was so fantastic, I could have swam in it! So, having gorged ourselves on our steaks and guzzled back almost all of the MAGNUM of Yellow Tail shiraz we'd picked up at CVS (class!), our thoughts turned to dessert. Well, our waiter had assumed we were celebrating someone's birthday (I mean, four cute ladies feasting on steak?? Obviously it HAS to be a momentous occasion!) and he came out with a flan covered in fabulous dulce de leche. Simply.heaven. (And I lived off the leftovers for the rest of the weekend...)

Bring the wine. Bring the empty belly. Bring the friends to drink the wine and to enjoy the time as you fill the belly. Bring much patience, a cell phone and a plan b as the time to get to sit at your table will be long(especially during popular dining times). (they will phone you when table is ready so hope for good weathers to stroll the street of Southport)...or go up the block to the DQ and start with your dessert of the frozen creamy things. Bring the people who likes the flesh of the moooooo mooos. Moooooooo Cow;-) Bring the expectation of sitting in a crowded space surrounded by many others waiting to feed their hunger for tearing flesh apart with their incisors. yum yum big meat. empanadas, bread...all foreplay to diminish your meat consumption. f8ck that ish and just order 2 steaks...one for an app and the other as a main course.... hell order another steak for dessert. yay mooooooo!

I am writing this review after a horrendous experience at this ridiculous restaurant. Mind you, the food was okay, and might have even deserved a solid 4 stars, but the 45 min it took to take our order and the HOUR AND A HALF it took to cook our meat to medium and bring it to our table was absolutely inexcusable.  What's more infuriating was the less than attentive response we received after we finally complained, having completed our entire bottle of wine and finished our less than inspired or appetizing salads.  (Two slices of tomato, lettuce leaves, and some white onion does not a salad make in the culinary world of Chicago!)  Even though we asked to speak to a manager we never saw anybody except the host and we were told "desculpa" the delay, the Spanish equivalent of "let it go," which is not what you want to hear when you have waiting for over two hours to be fed. To add insult to injury, our meal was punctuated by an unedited and bloated bill, which we received with  a single complimentary dessert for our party of five...a dessert that was burned,  tasteless and thoroughly uneatable. It might have been easy to chew some of the meat served at our table this evening, but the experience as a whole proved too bitter and expensive to swallow.

Oh, Tango Sur, how I miss you.  Que lastima. After Tango Sur (and 10 days in Argentina), you'll never find yourself wanting to go to an American steakhouse again. Service and wait times can definitely bah-low, but its worth it. Haven't found anything as good in SF or LA but if gladly accepting recommendations.  Guacho Grill seems a bit too corporate.

Don't let my 2 stars mislead you.  This place truly does have excellent food.  However, my 2 stars are for the HORRIBLE service they give to their potentional customers.   My party of 13 arrived around 7:45pm and we were made to wait over and 1hr and 1/2!!!  Typically I don't mind the wait, but the host at this place was a total douche.  He might as well have said, "Um...go somewhere else because there's no chance we'll seat you", but instead gave us the most sarcastic and indifferent attitude.  I have no patience to wait for food...no matter how good the food is when they treat people like crap. It's a shame because they do have awesome food, but I can't stand the pretentious attitude.  My only guess is that our group didn't fit in with the "wrigleyville" type.  I used to go here when noooooooo one knew of this place...before the days of "Check Please"....I just hate to see how arrogant they've become. Instead, we left and went to an awesome Italian restaurant on Wilson Ave.....Cara Mio.  At 9:30pm they were quick to take our reservation and had us seated by 9:45.  Accomodated us in nice private room and gave us excellent service. Tango sur...can suck it.    They need to learn better customer service...

Very dark ambience (which I liked) which made it a whole lot more intimate. There was also a live guitarist playing music. It was nice that it is byob.  On top of that the meat came in a huge hunk and was cooked well.  I liked the idea of sharing a large piece of meat over ordering separate steaks.  But again I think the atmosphere is what really made it great, on top of the food!

I went to Tango Sur on Saturday evening and this was my best trip here yet.  Expecting a long wait, we arrived just before 7 and was told there was a 40 minute wait, only 20 minutes later we were seated. The only thing preventing this from being a 5 star review was that it took over 15 minutes once being seated for anyone to come to our table.  The food was fantastic, from the chicken and meat empanadas to the flank steak for two entree, everything was prepared perfect. The flan is the best I have had in Chicago, topped with a caramel sauce that was delicious. Dinner, appetizers and desert for two only $60 with tip!

Tango Sur is perfect for a romantic dinner for two or a large group of friends or family. The food is AMAZING and the dark relaxing ambiance is ideal. It is a BYOB so bring in as many bottles you want. Prepare to cork one or two bottles in their tiny waiting room while waiting for a table on the weekends. They don't take reservations but I found you can give the host your name and cell number and scroll down the street of Southport to kill some time. The tiny waiting room is uncomfortable if full but the wait HAS ALWAYS BEEN WORTH IT!!  If you enjoy flank steak and/or can appreciate a delicious chimichurri you won't find a better one in the city.  On a different note, the service is great too. All the servers are good looking men :) and all work together so you are never waiting for anything, very prompt and respectful. The dining experience is overall really enjoyable! Without a doubt one of my favorites and a Chicago MUST TRY!!

I've been here twice now, both times for birthdays, and both times were excellent.  The waiter and everyone on Yelp recommends the provoleta appetizer so we tried it, and it's really just a plate of melted cheese with red peppers - good, but nothing terribly special. The steaks, on the other hand - fantastic.  TWO, yes, TWO deliciously charred filets came with my $24 entree - could you even make that at home for $24?  The strip was a tad fatty, but was cooked perfectly, and the chimichurri which accompanied it was out of this world. Skip the spinach mashed potatoes and go for the Argentinian-style - like potatoes Vesuvio, but better! No corkage fee, no pretensions - definitely worth the wait!

Su-Su-Sussodium!  If high-blood pressure is what your shopping for well look no further.  If the insanely long wait times don't elevate your blood pressure, then the exorbitant amounts of sodium will surely do the trick.  I don't mind to wait for delicious food especially when the spot is byob.  But please don't tell me an hour and fifteen when it really ends up being two hours - give me the longer wait time and surprise me when the table is ready early.   The four of us were seated at a great table outside, the service was very attentive and I thought, we are on our way to an amazing meal.  Wrong.  I ordered one of the specials Bife Vesuvio it sounded like a delicious combination of prime steak stuffed with spinach and cheese in a white wine sauce. (Being from the south I grew up on country ham, so needless to say, I love me some salt!)  This dish was the saltiest meal I've ever tasted.  I managed to choke down about four bites of it and couldn't go any further.  My husband and a friend shared one of the meals for two served on a table top grill.  The meat should have never left the kitchen.  There was so much fat and gristle they couldn't even cut through it.  The waiter was apologetic and corrected the problem by serving them a different meal.  The fillets served second time around were cooked to perfection and were much better cuts of meat (that's what earned the restaurant the third star).  All in all I doubt we will ever venture back to Tango Sur.  If two meals out of the three ordered needed to be sent back then that's not saying a lot for the kitchen and I think this is a spot we can live without.

If you're new to Chicago, this is the best steak for your money. If you've been in Chicago and are yelping this restaurant, you've been wasting money at restaurants. Be prepared to wait to be seated. Don't worry, it's worth the time. With the amount of food you receive at the price it's given, you'll be more than happy! Order the Fillet and don't forget to bring at least two bottles of red wine. BEST RESTAURANT IN CHICAGO!

A few things to expect.  Long waits, especially on weekends, and its BYOB. Food was solid.  Ordered the steak that resembles a new york strip and my gf ordered lemon chicken.  Both were great, and had both as left overs and still delicous. Service - we had a great waiter.  Didn't catch his name because of the accent but everyone seemed to be kind tentative and had good recommendations.   What makes this place?  BYOB.  Cuts a normal steak dinner in half.  Bring your own wine, if white they will bring a small wine container to keep it chilled at the table.  Candle light set a relaxing mood and the meat will be cooked how you want it. About the long wait - if you expect it, won't be an issue.  Give them your name and number and they will call you once you are next.  My friends and I went a neighboring bar to have a couple of drinks then strolled over when they called.  Relaxing way to begin dinner. Four stars because the service/food were great, but 5 stars is top notch and only a few places earn that extra star.

PROS:  Cheap prices, 1 order of filet mignon comes with 2 steaks, BYOB CONS: Ridiculous wait, super loud inside, steak quality isn't that good, inconvenient location I'd say it's good if you're with a group of friends and want to BYOB.

Well I'm sad in a way that all the yuppies (sorry) have taken over one of my favorite restaurants. I used to go here with my old boyfriend years ago. I'm glad it has gotten the recognition is deserves, but now it is ALWAYS jam packed. Reservations are only taken for parties of 6 or more, which leaves a mob of people waiting on the sidewalk and street. I find this distracting when you are trying to eat. The food is AMAZING. Having been to Argentina, I find the food to be very authentic and it does live up to all the hype. The restaurant is BYOB which is nice, it's just a little tight on space, and if you sit inside you may leave smelling like steak....but hey maybe your guy might like that : )  Try going mid week, when the crowd and wait is not so big....and it will be great!!

Tengo Sur definitely has your taste buds dancing.  I've been to Southport's most popular Argentinian BYOB twice and would highly recommend the Vacio (definitely to be shared) and the Suprema (their unbelievable version of chicken parmesean).  However, the wait and the attitude of the matre'd left a bad taste in my mouth.  Granted, I could wait outside with a good number of other parties waiting their turn or head to Cullen's or Blue Bayou for a drink, but I wish they gave a more realistic wait time.  Too bad the food is too good to turn your back on the lack in host service.

An hour and a half wait  and for what? The wait here was rediculouly long so you get to stand on the sidewalk and breathe in the copious amounts cigarette smoke and we were lucky enough to have cigar smokers near us. (yes not the restaurant's fault just more of a commentary for those out there to quit this habit especially in an area where people are eating). Started with a delicious empinada, right choice. The steak i ordered for my entre was on the fatty side but not as bad as what my friends got. Their cut of steak which they shared seemed to be all fat. The restaurant did take care of it and brought them out filets instead. They did take care of the problem dish and correct the situation though I feel a cut like that should have never been served. I would give them 4 stars for taking care of the situation but still I don't feel the food was worth the initial hour and a half wait.

Andrés Calamaro said it best: mi Buenos Aires querido yo te quiero desde lejos y desde cerca te extraño por eso vuelvo y revuelvo ... I miss Argentina. Sometimes a lot, sometimes a little. But one of the few things that can always take me back is a good Argentinean steak. On a nostalgic whim, another BsAs aficionado and I got a group together for some porteño cuisine.  For starters, I was exceptionally impressed with how quickly we were seated. Score one for eating out on holiday weekends!! Our table of 5 was seated less than half an hour after putting our name in. We were expecting to wait at least an hour or two, so it was a very pleasant surprise. I liked that they took a cell number with the name so, had the wait been anything like we'd anticipated, we would have been able to wander freely until the table was ready. The menu options could not have been any more authentic if they'd copied it directly from La Chacra!  Empanadas, jamón crudo, ensalada rusa, milanesa (even a la Napolitana!), and endless cuts of delicious, delicious beef. The authenticity of the dishes, however, is the only reason I wouldn't call Tango Sur a 5-star choice.  Our group ordered empanadas to start ($2 each, sold individually so you can get any combo of flavors you like). They were tasty, but very deep fried and much smaller than what I expected for Argentinean empanadas. We also had some fresh-baked bread that was incredible! Because we couldn't stand to wait for the main course to taste a little chimichurri, we asked for some to go with our bread which they brought out in a soup bowl. Holy chimichurri!! It was delicious and ever-so-plentiful. We were also comped salads (perhaps because of ordering in Spanglish? who knows), which was a nice touch. For the main course I had the Bife de Chorizo, which was excellent but a far cry from the quality of beef I'd been dreaming of. Solo en BsAs se puede comer asi.... Diners of eggplant and chicken at our table all seemed very content with their dishes as well. Our waiter was very attentive and fun, playfully alternating between Spanish and English right along with us.  All this paired with Malbec from Mendoza (BYOB!), and this was the perfect trip down memory lane. And at what came out to under $25/each, I can dine here every day for the next month before I could afford a trip back to BsAs for the real thing. ¡A aprovechar!

Two Words: Steak Overdose For $24, I got the El Filet.  It was one of the most delicious filet mignons I've ever had.  Actually, it was *TWO* of the most delicious filet mignons I've ever had.  For some reason, all the portions here are reasonably priced and big enough to feed a small third world village. The steaks are huge, tasty, and inexpensive and BYOB is a nice way to save some coin during this recession.  The flan is unbelievable and the empanadas are good as well.  Heck even the bread is nice. I'm not sure what they use to make their potatoes a crazy shade of green but they taste normal and go well with the meat.

As if it requires repeating, the governor of South Carolina is an idiot. No need to leave the country in secrecy on a state-funded visit to Argentina. Just go to Chicago and visit Tango Sur. You could write it off as a legitimate travel expense...hey, you're just visiting the Illinois governor to gather legal advice for your inevitable impeachment.  I forgot how much I miss Tango Sur. I was here about 5 years ago, and yet the same host was still guarding the entrance, feigning interest in my reservation and my party of eight....pretending to record my name is his little notepad...telling me (with a smile) to chill out and go play in traffic on Southport for awhile. He'll give me a wink when my table is ready.  It's worth the wait. You get inside and you feel like Anthony Bourdain in a foreign country....a country where people sit very close together, talk very loud, and drink to the revolution. It's boisterous. It's extremely dark. Servers are not well-practiced at the queen's English. All this chaos amounts to a completely impractical place for entertaining my aging parents and in-laws...who hate noise and couldn't read the menu with the Hubble telescope. Call it the Father's Day Revenge dinner. They're annoyed and I'm ecstatic.  But their annoyances quick fade once the steaks arrive. The steaks are monsters. This grass-fed beef is way tastier than those corn-fed Kansas fatties, even if it's cooked a little more well done then you'd like. This is steak how god intended it.  I have to make fun of the salad, though. They must loathe salad in Argentina. It was the most basic, crude effort at a salad I've ever seen. One type of lettuce and some vinegar and oil. Maybe a tomato or onion on the side...I don't even remember. It was less like a salad and more like a spread of optional hamburger toppings at a backyard cookout. The Argentinians were clearly mocking the formality of serving a salad prior to the main event. They were making damned sure that you would have plenty of room for steak by delivering you the weakest-ass salad they could conceive that still could be technically referred to as 'salad'. I'm pretty sure it was intended as a joke. I got it.

I had actually not heard of Tango Sur until one of my friend's suggested for a Saturday night dinner with friends.  I enjoyed my dinner and think Tango Sur is great for a red-meat glut when you feel the desire.   First off, we got there at about 6:30 on a Saturday night and waited until around 8 (with a party of 6).  The nice thing is that they take down your cell phone number and call you when a table is open.  We chose to go down to Blue Bayou and have an Abita while we waited...definitely a good choice, especially on a 90 degree night.   The menu consists of reasonably priced, gigantic portions of well seasoned, red meat.  Sure, they have chicken options and maybe 2 vegetarian options, but I don't really think it'd be worth going if you didn't plan on consuming beef or pork.   I started off with an appetizer of prosciutto and melon.  It was simple and a good beginning of the meal.  The prosciutto was decent, but nothing to write home about.  I would go with empanada's next time.  For my meal I had the "Para Uno".  The "Para Uno" which consisted of flap steak, short ribs, beef sweetbreads, chorizo and black sausage.  The flap steak and short ribs were perfectly done, tender and seasoned well.  The beef sweetbreads were good, but nothing special.  The chorizo and black sausage were too seasoned for my taste.  This is not Tango Sur's fault, this is my fault...I'm just not a big sausage fan.  The chimichurri was awesome and leaves you with garlic breath for at least a day.   Unless you are a professional football player, I would definitely recommend sharing one dish between two people.  They are way too large for just one person.  I'm a big guy, and I had no chance at finishing my meal.  Two people at our table shared a dish and still took some home.

Sorry, but after last night, Tango Sur has lost 1 star. As I mentioned previously, I would gladly take any visiting friends to dinner at Tango Sur, and that is just what I did last night. However, we were all disappointed in last night's experience. I understand it's busy. We had a small party of 3, and waited an hour and a half for our food. Our server got our entrees a little mixed up --- the El Filet was ordered medium-rare and came back medium well (with VERY cold mashed potatoes), and the Lomo Relleno was ordered medium-well but came back medium-rare... I might just be imagining this but I think they also changed this entree since the last time I was there, as it is now a serving for two... anyway, we were so famished that we just ate it anyway, and our server never once came to check in on us until the check... I'm so torn because I can't ever break up with the food here... but service (or maybe just THIS server) needs to be more attentive!

A little celebratory get together calls for a lovely dinner on a beautiful and very humid evening. When my friend suggested this place for dinner, I was pretty psyched. Tango had been on my bookmark list for months. Our wait was almost 2 hours. We expected this and were prepared with some ideas. To rehydrate and kill some time, we went down the street for a drink. In no time, we were seated outside for an enjoyable dinner.  Big thumbs up to this BYOB establishment. Our waiter was quick to give us our water and wine glasses for our bottle as soon as we sat down. As busy as it was that night, we had such great service. We had one main waiter, but other guys kept stopping by asking us how we were doing. I think it was because we kept taking a "breather" between bites. I regret my attire choice that evening. It's definitely a wear-something-stretchy- kind of place. (Just kidding.) I would skip the bread and butter. I love the stuff but I cannot handle all that and save room for appetizer, salad, and main dish we ordered. We started with the eggplant in a vinegar / garlic sauce. It was a big appetizer and was easily divided up among three people. The sauce was spot on. It was creamy almost like alfredo sauce. I'm not very good at describing but hopefully you get the picture. The salad was a-ok, but at least we got some fresh veggies in with our meal. Next came the bife vesuvio. Holy hell. This was probably one of the best steaks I have eaten, and I don't eat steak often. It's stuffed with spinach and cheese (exact name escapes me) in a white wine sauce. The steak also comes with chimchurri (sp?) sauce, which I think I could have taken that as a shot because it was delicious. We asked for more chimchurri and were given a cup size of the stuff. See? Great service. Since I shared the steak dish, I don't think I would have made a dent with that had I ordered it on my own. Desserts...yes, desserts. As in more than one. As in, we couldn't decide on just one when he brought out a plate full of goodies. We went with the flan and this peaches and cream cake. I think I was in the early stages of a food coma because I can't remember the name of this one. It was made of some sort of yellow cake topped with a whipped cream and peaches filling. It melted in my mouth. The flan was good but really sugary sweet....well, I'm really particular about flan only because I judge every one I've had against my mom's. My mom makes some serious kick-ass leche flan. This one was good, but I've had better. ;-)  Good company, good food, and nice weather (minus the humidity)  makes for a fun dinner night out. I'm definitely coming back because I want to try other dishes I had my eye on. Thanks to them for us lingering a bit longer at our table. If you happen to sit outside near this hanging candle holder thingy, Watch out. I must have bumped my head on that a million times I thought I was going to knock it all the way onto the street.

I love this place for its food and ambiance. Have been to Tango Sur about 5 times now, and everything was perfect until my last visit this Sunday. Their food is really good(I like the steak with spinach/cheese in the middle) or el filet the most within their menu.  Here is the reason for only 1 star though... This Sunday we were there with a party of 7, seated inside. We had a reservation, or we thought we did, but when we got there they said they could not find the reservation. Just because we were lucky, another party was leaving at that time, so they were able to seat us. We brought our wines, and were enjoying the appetizers(I personally like the eggplant one), then I felt something crawling on my hand... When I looked down on my napkin, I saw a 3 inch black round cockroach type of bug on top of it, which was really unexpected. I like outdoors and camping etc, so I am used to bugs, but this is my first encounter within a restaurant. In order not to freak out the ladies on the table, I wrapped the thing with the napkin, and took it to the manager type outside(he's the one with the pony tail). Told him what happened, and went back to my table. On his way back, arrogant son of a gun(aka. the manager type pony tailed guy) stopped by at our table, and without even apologizing, said something like, "Oh this is the summer time, door's open, these small bugs come in, there is nothing we can do about it, etc.", which really pissed me off. 1- it's was not small by any means 2- he did NOT assume responsibility for something he should be controlling 3- I am pretty sure that leaving the door open for a restaurant, which is his argument, is not allowed exactly because of this within the health code. Therefore, even though I like their food a lot, I wont be able to go back there for quite some time, simply because of the way they handled this situation. There are a lot of good food places in Chicago, and many of those places still care about customer service, unlike Tango Sur...

I've been to Tango Sur numerous times, but it's been a while since I've been back. I remembered the steak to be one of the best steaks I've ever had, and well, while it was good, it wasn't the BEST I'VE EVER HAD.  It was good, but not phenomenal.  Service was pretty great and we didn't have to wait for an outdoor table, which was awesome.  Also, you have to know that the portions are huge. Split the El Filet if you are going to get it. It's 2 8 oz. filets, not one.  For the most part, we really enjoyed our dinner. Oh, and don't forget to get the empanadas! They were fantastic.

pretty amazing.  We waited about 45 minutes at prime dinner time on a Sunday, but it was totally worth it.  Definitely get a few appetizers as the packed house means relatively long wait times for food from the grill.  We tried all the empanadas and I think the jamon y queso and the spinach were the best.  The grilled provolone is a simple but delicious starter as well.  We got a large flap meat steak w/ roasted sweet potatoes which must have been almost 2 pounds, slathered with delicious garlicky chimichurri, and the beef vesuvio, steak rolled with spinach and cheese.  Both were drop dead amazing, although neither was cooked exactly to our specs (both were ordered MR, one was rare and the other came out medium) but I really could care less they were seasoned so well.  I will probably not be visiting another steakhouse in the city for a long time.

Just went here Friday night with a few friends in town for the weekend.  The wait was long (the full hour and a half predicted by the maitre d'), but he took a cell number from us so we could go to a bar down the street to wait. Always a great service. The steaks are huge, well-seasoned, and cooked beautifully. The chorizo was awesome, and for 3 bucks, worth adding to any smaller entree. Most entrees, though, you won't need it. Luckily, everything's cheap and it's a BYO. Prepare for a long wait on weekends and get a seat outside if you can!

BYOB with no corkage fee AND the best steak I've ever had. My husband and I chose to dine here for our 5th anniversary...we brought a few bottles of red, had an appetizer (the provolone with red peppers) and two amazing steaks that were more than we can finish for around $50 with tip!  The service left a little to be desired...we had to wait a very long time for our check, but that is really my only complaint.  I agree with the other reviewers that the decor is romantic, and we appreciated a great meal by candlelight. We made a reservation, and therefore had no wait at all. I'll be back for sure!

The husband and I treated some friends to dinner here.  I really like the BYOB, but wasn't too sold on the food.  When compared to El Nandu, their steaks were way tough and empanadas were really small.  My DH and I got a grill with stuffed steak and mushrooms and the friends got the El Filet.  They seemed really happy with their meal, but we weren't too pleased.  Prices ended up being about the same even with the BYOB, and I liked the outside patio, but I think I'll stick with El Nandu in the future.
Love this place. Pretty good food and great atmosphere. Waiters are super fast and helpful. I have a couple of favorite dishes there and every time I go there with my friends everything is perfect.
Great little restaurant. Good date spot. Candle lit rooms, good service, BYOB and glorious steak. Glooooorious. 'nuff said. Seriously, best steak I've had in Chicago so far.

Whoever told you the happiest place on earth was Disney World has never seen my stomach after Tango Sur.  Do the math yourself: + No corkage fee + Meat, meat, and more meat (and other delicious food) + nice atmosphere + friendly staff  = awesome The only drawback is that there is always an hour wait if not slightly longer ( which should be enough to tell you how awesome the place is)... the upside to the wait is that they take your cell phone number and you can wander the block and grab a drink at one of the many bars around while you wait.

The food is great, the prices are acceptable, the atmosphere is not my cup of tea, and the long wait is a bummer. A friend and I tried the Parillada Para Dos (Thanks for the tip Yelpers!), and I was blown away. It was my first taste of sweetbread (beef throat meat), and I don't think I'll ever have enough. The flap meat steak was as good as any I have ever had. I could go without the black sausage next time, but it was an interesting experience, as I had never tried it before. As for appetizers, I only got a bite of a chicken empanada and it was predictably delicious, though nothing extraordinary. The Provoleta (fried provolone with roasted peppers) tasted more like Mozzarella, but it made for a great combo with those peppers.  We did not have any trouble finishing our huge meal, though that was partly due to the fact that our 7 o'clock reservations were moved to 9. Of course, by Tango Sur time, we were not seated until a little after 9:30. Needless to say, my already-huge appetite was on a whole other level that night. I prefer to enjoy my food in a quiet, well-lit room. Tango Sur is basically the opposite, as our lighting consisted of one puny candle, while the packed house provided quite a bit of noise. Luckily, the food, especially the beef sweetbread, was so good that it offset any problems I may have with the place. If this was purely a food review, it would be a sure-fire five stars. Next time I go, and there will certainly be many "next times", I'll make sure to avoid the Saturday night crowds.

Tango Sur is a meat lover's paradise.  The Parillada, a table-top mixed grill stocked with short ribs, chorizo, blood sausage and sweetbreads, will leave you reeling in its decadence.  The portion size is huge with enough meat for multiple meals. The wait at this restaurant can be very long.  My favorite ways to pass the time are:  1) savoring a delicious cup of coffee at Julius Meinl a couple of blocks away. 2) enjoying my favorite wine while making friends in the cozy waiting room.  Tango Sur is BYOB and the shared long wait seems to build a sense of camaraderie. This Argentinean restaurant is worth visiting for its well prepared meat at a reasonable price.  If you don't mind the long wait, Tango Sur is sure to please.

Are you a meat lover? romantic? adventurer? and a dining out aficionado? Then put Tango Sur on your "must" list. Tango Sur is definitely one of Chicago's food gems. I recommend planning ahead so that a) you build your appetite, b) buy your favorite bottle of wine, and c) go at a descent time so that you don't experience a long wait.  Only come here if you're in the mood to eat a LOT. I would start off with the cheese and chicken empanadas. Then, if you're feeling adventurous, order the Parrillada (different assortments of meat) or the flank steak with chimichurri. Caution, the portions are enormous, so you might want to share. My brother and I are always guaranteed to come out with a very satisfying food coma. The ambiance is dark and cozy. The aesthetics and decorations are old and rustic. Each table is lit with a candle which sets the mood perfectly. This is a great date place, so men take note. Finally, make sure to come at a reasonable hour- if not be prepared to wait. I've waited up to 2 hours for a table- in which case bring extra bottles of wine and be ready to squeeze yourself into the waiting room with a lot of people who've probably already downed a bottle of wine or two- so it gets rowdy!

This place is amazing. I have been about a dozen times now, and can't wait to go again. The food is fantastic (I always get steak), and they are a BYOB with no corkage fee. The service is good, and the servers sexy! There is always a wait, but well worth it!

I have been wanting to go to Tango Sur for a long time, so I finally got Mike and Scott to agree to go there last night. The atmosphere is cozy and earthy, and totally unpretentious. We were greeted immediately at the door, and seated right away even though Mike and I were still waiting for Scott, at about 6:15 PM. The restaurant was not too busy, but by the time we left about 90 minutes later, it was packed. We started off with several appetizers... cold veal with olives and vegetables, empanadas of different varieties, and jamon with melon. All three were very tasty. I think I liked the empanadas the best. At $2 each they are not huge, but nicely sized for appetizers. We were served small salads with greens, tomatoes, and onions, with vinegar and oil dressing. There was nothing terribly fancy about the salads, but that did not bother me a bit, I was trying to save room for the steak.  We all ordered the same dinner, El Filet. Our dinner plates arrived and looked so amazing. They came with two rather large filets, at least ten ounces each, by my estimate, and some green (very green!) mashed potatoes. The potatoes were so good, whipped with spinach (hence the green), garlic and Parmesan cheese. The filets were tender, juicy and full of flavor. Au jus covered the plate, and added a little extra zing to the steaks. I loved it. Tango Sur is everything David Burke's Primehouse is not. I'm big on price/performance when it comes to restaurants, and Tango Sur scores big by this metric. It is unpretentious, and the food is so tasty. Did I mention it is BYOB with no corkage fee? How perfect can you get?

One of the most romantic dinners I've had in a long time. I was concerned that there would be no way for this restaurant to live up to the hype, but fortunately I was not disappointed.  The empanadas were flaky, moist, and generously portioned. There is something to be said for a fresh, crisp salad dressed with nothing more than oil and vinegar like the one at Tango Sur. My boyfriend and I split the parradilla for two with more leftovers than we could ever consume. And for a 45 dollar price tag, we still had plenty to catch a show and Improv Olympic.  The ambiance on the sidewalk was spectacular, and I loved the candle lit exuberance inside. The entire experience was well worth the wait. We will be back for sure.

I took my family here several months ago and they absolutely LOVED it! Not only was it reasonably priced for a steak place, but its BYOB - which saved us a ton of money on wine. I also love how while you are waiting on the table you can sit in the back room and open your wine and drink while you are waiting. The food was fantastic and we had enough leftovers for all of us to have lunch the next day. I can't wait to go again in the summer, when they have the patio open!

Hand down, one of my favorite steakhouse places of all time. First of all, anyone complaining about how small the place is needs to go to Denny's where you get all the space you want.  Everyone in the US is so obsessed with having their personal space everywhere.  If you want personal space, stay home! Now that my little anger is out of the way, let me tell you why I love this place. BYOB is usually a sushi place thing, but this is brilliant.  You're not stuck to only the drinks they have to offer.  Bring whatever the heck you want.  Not to mention how that keeps the meal price reasonable, as most restaurants mark up alcohol prices but at least 100%, if not more. Speaking of prices, this is one of the cheaper steakhouses you'll find, especially when compared to the quality of the meat.  Most of the meat, if not all of it, actually comes from Argentina.  It's very good quality meat, and it's prepared really well.  If you want to try different types of meats, go for the parillada.  Keep in mind though, the parillada for two, is enough for three or four people, especially if you get appetizers, which you should. The best of the appetizers has to be their empanadas.  All of them are delicious, but my favorite are the spinach and cheese empanadas.  Also, their spinach mashed potatoes are very good. This place is really good, so you will wait if you go there for dinner, especially on the weekend.  You can only get a reservation if you have a party of more than 6, otherwise, you'll wait.  If you go with the expectation and knowledge that the wait is an hour or two, then you'll have nothing to complain about.  There are a ton of places along Southport to chill at while you wait, and they will call you when your turn comes.  So you don't have to stand around and wait by the restaurant. Most of the time when we go there, we inadvertently start talking to someone at a table next to us, and they're always foreign, from a Spanish-speaking country, mostly South America.  To me, this says a lot about the place, where you always find "natives." The staff is super nice and friendly, and authentic.  There are plenty of servers, so you never have to wait around too long for them to pay attention to you.  Also, ladies, they're not too bad to look at for the most part.  Hey, I'm just saying :)

Two words: absolutely fantastic. BYOB? I wish more restaurants in San Francisco were BYOB. Anyway..... We ventured over to Lakeview for this gem of a restaurant from a recommendation of a friend that lived in Chicago for 6 years. Tango Sur is, hands down, the best restaurant that I've been to in Chicago so far. Granted, I've only been here for 24 hours.  We had the empanadas (my first time!) with spinach and cheese, and beef. The spinach and cheese empanadas came highly recommended by the waiter, but to my surprise, both me and the boy preferred the beef. Regardless, the empanadas = fabulous. They were fried, but the dough was light and perfectly crisp. The waiter took the time to walk us through the history of empanadas, which was appreciated. The name of the steak for 2 that we ordered escapes my mind, but it's safe to say that if you say, "I want the steak for 2 with all the yams around it," the waiter will understand. It's marinated and surrounded by a DELICIOUS chimichurri sauce that I repeatedly scooped on to my sweet potatoes. Warning -- the portions of this steak are HUGE. 22 ounces. Yowza! The only reason why I give Tango Sur 4 stars instead of 5 is because our silverware was repeatedly dirty. And by dirty, I mean that there was leftover spinach on our forks. Yuck. If it's warm in Chicago, take advantage of the outdoor seating - it's perfect for people watching. For out of towners, please do NOT miss Tango Sur. It's a must.
Delicious. Great food and good service. It's a little loud so you should go with people you aren't trying to get to know (a.k.a. a date) because you won't be able to hear them. At all. Haha.
I'm just here to co-sign all of the other reviews... big steaks, low prices, great service. I even tried the blood sausage... not bad.

I think this place is great! The portions are huge and the cuts of meat are terrific! It is BYOB with no corking fee! It is always packed so a bit of a pain to get a table on the weekends. I also find it a bit dark, but truly worth the wait!

As you arrive to Tango Sur do not be afraid of the line, it's always there (or so I'm told). We put our names in and were told it would be an hour and a half. Not a problem, we just went down to a bar and had a few drinks. They take your cellphone number to call you, which I first thought was great, but discovered a flaw in the plan. We were under my friend's name and they called it at some point and either a) someone else had this name or b) said they were my friend and go seated. When we left the bar to check on our name, they said they had already seated us. We then waited another hour until we were seated. The dining room is packed with people and you will probably sit very close to another group. The walls are decorated with nice posters, albums, and murals of Argentinian culture. Our waiter had a very thick accent and it was difficult at times to not only understand him but just hear him in all the noise. We didn't peruse the menu long b/c we were starving, but luckily we all found something right away. I had the bife visuvio, which was a piece of butterflied steak filled with cheese and spinach. I will admit the steak was good and Tango Sur is BYOB so we had some good wine too. Unfortunately, I found the service to be so-so, the plating is very rustic and can come off sloppy, and our desserts weren't anything to write home about. If you can somehow avoid a long wait, I would recommend, but not sure it was worth over two hours.

Date number 3 rolls around and you want to make it romantic, but you are unsure of where to go...well, good thing you are reading this review. Tango Sur is a fantastic place to light that romantic fire. Warning: the following is going to sound cheesy: dimly-lit candlelight dinner. Not many places pull this aspect of a romantic dinner off as well as Tango Sur. But what's romance without a little cheese? And what's the next need to a romantic dinner: tasty food. Well, Tango Sur is definitely not lacking in the food department. Tango Sur is a meat-lover's dream (do not bring a vegetarian to this restaurant!) - a restaurant which does not shy away from cooking a rare steak! In this day and age - what, are they crazy? Plus, it's a BYOB restaurant...which I hear makes it even more romantic!  What's this place missing, you wonder? Seating. You will probably wait for a table on a weekend. If at all possible, dine at Tango Sur on a weekday. Unfortunately, the sign of a good restaurant is the fact it is always busy.

I was very disappointed with this place.  We called at 7 during the week and asked if there  was any wait.  They said no, and by the time we got there at 7:20 it was an hour wait.  We were able to run across the street and pick up a couple bottles of wine.  It's nice that Tengo Sur offers a waiting area with  glasses and corkscrews for BYOB.  The highlight of the meal was definitely the meat empanadas we started with.  My buddy and I split the Vacio that was simply OK.  There was a TON of food, but it wasn't all that good.  The potatoes were OK and flavors were decent.  We definitely had a lot of leftovers and the meal was reasonably priced- overall though i have to say i was unimpressed.

This spot was recommended to me by a friend who doesn't even live in Chicago. 8 months after living there in the city I finally make it. It's definitely worth all the hype, for the main course at least. Plus, there was no wait on a Thursday, 7PM. I got the spinach and cheese stuffed filet = delicious. Salad leaves MUCH to be desired (iceberg + tomatoes+onions+oil and vinegar). Come on, try a little harder. Please. I can whip up something in my kitchen in 5 minutes thats 50 times better.  It's a great date place. I can't wait to come back in the summer and sit on the patio!

Wow, this place is good!!!  The steaks here are cooked to perfection, I have been three times and have always gone for the fillet which tastes  AMAZING!!  On top of that it is BYOB and their is no corkage fee, what more could you want?!!

I have been coming here even before I lived in the city. It was worth the drive from the north burbs. We almost always come with a big group and take advantage of the large platters meant to share. Its incredible how much you can get for the price if you know how to order. The salmon is my absolute favorite. Some friends swear by the roasted chicken, I've actually seen them devour it with their bare hands, (not recommended). There also aren't many places you can get blood sausage it seems, so if thats your style, dig in. This is a great place for a date. Hopefully your date is as charming as the atmosphere!

YUMMY! We sat down right away around 8:30 on a Monday and had a lovely candlelit dinner. Try the Pechuga del pollo, it was so good! The servers were quick and attentive, I think every time I set my water glass down someone came up and filled it. I wish I had known it was BYOB, I had a nice bottle of wine that would have been amazing with the chicken. I will definitely be back!

I was starving when I sat down. I mean, seriously, eat two rolls and load on the butter starving. There was no silverware on the table, so I got creative. I dipped the bread in butter. We got service pretty much right away, but were only given water and menus. Once they found out we were waiting for two others, the service dropped. But they were crazy busy. It was a nice night, about 60 degrees, and the patio was packed, as well as the inside of the place. It had a great ambiance, darkly lit inside and very cozy.  Once our other friends got back, we got service right away. Finally some silverware! And, an appetizer. The baked cheese with red peppers. Oh, yum. Did I say that I love baked cheese? The entire table was in love with it. I mean, you can't go wrong with cheesy goodness. The salad that comes with your meal is basic. Lettuce, tomato and onion, and they give you oil and vinegar to dress it. It was lame. I love an oil and vinegar dressing, but I don't like raw white onions, and the tomatoes were gritty. Ew. We had a nice break before the main course, which was awesome. I don't like rushed service.  The entrees were all delicious. I had the bone-in rib eye, my friends had the lomo, the beef vesuvio and the filet entrees. We shared all of ours, and there wasn't a single thing that tasted bad. The spinach mashed potatoes were so so good, and my friends beef vesuvio was probably the best out of the table. My rib eye was cooked perfectly, and our portions were so huge that we all had enough for a big lunch the next day. A great experience. I can't wait to come back and try other things. Plus, $24 for a salad, rib-eye steak and mashed potatoes, and NO corkage! Hands down a winner.

It took me a year of living down the street from here before I finally made it inside.  I am ashamed of myself, it's like having a Ferrari in your garage and driving a Yugo instead.
