Con's: 1.  Place filled considerably after 7:00, mostly with an under-35, wine-toting, I-can-talk-louder-than-you, female crowd.   2.  Extremely noisy; romantic atmosphere went down the tubes quickly. 3.  Rib-eye was too fatty and somewhat gristly, although cooked nicely to medium-rare.  Felt I was "tackling" my food. 4.  Spinach mashed potatoes are truly green, as in mint ice cream green, as opposed to having spinach mixed into the potatoes as with chives; the color is simply hard to view.  The Darling didn't care for the taste, either. 5.  First bread basket held stale rolls.  Second bread basket held fresh rolls. 6.  No additional butter packets were offered, although we had bread and potatoes. 7.  Salads were - meh.  Lettuce, pale tomato slices, white onion slices, some flavored vinegar on the table. 8.  Cheese appetizer was beautiful, but once in the mouth became instantly rubbery and hard to swallow.   9.  Tea was weak. 10. White napkins often leave flecks of white linen on black pants and dresses; black napkins would be a most considerate offering. We might try it again next year, but all in all, our experience was not up to the hype.  Hope your's is better!

It goes by many names. Meat coma. Meat-cation. Meat-o-rama. MEEEEAAAT. Vaca del oro.  But here's the thing, folks: you have to ask yourself exactly what IS worth a two, three hour wait? And really, how amazing can grilled meat actually be to merit such torture? The answer is, I don't know because I was lucky enough to be part of a party of 10 so there was no waiting because they took a reservation for us. HA! Ohhhh I'm a jerk. Yes, the steaks were really, really delicious. The chimichurri sauce was delicious. The baked sweet potato I poached from my friend's platter was also right up there. The flan, I hear, is also good but the texture of flan inspires my gag reflex so I took their word for it.  Where I think Tango Sur nails it, is the minimal service. They really only pop up to fill your water, take your order, then bring you your food and check. The place is perfect for groups despite the volume, and the BYO element rounds it out perfectly. My four stars are mainly for service, their willingness to take a reservation for six or more (and seat you on time), no corkage fee and the perfect temperature for my steak. Is it worth that long of a wait? Not really, not if you have already had a well-cooked steak in this town or anywhere else.  (Little tip from me to you: arrive after 8 on a cold Monday night. Lots of parking. No waiting)

I recently vacationed in Chicago, staying with my best friend (awwwwwww). One thing we discussed was going to a dinner somewhere that might be worthy of a review. Without hesitation he picked Tango Sur. I have experienced American steakhouses where dark wood and dim lights create ambiance for big steaks; and Brazilian steakhouses where meats (on swords!) are brought to the table in waves; and Japanese steakhouses where I get cranky if my Teppen chef does not transition the onion volcano into a choo-choo train. Tango Sur was my first Argentinian steakhouse.  No gimmicks, just good food. We started with what my friend told me was basically an appetizer ritual when he goes to Tango Sur: Spinach & Cheese Empanadas. Not to detract from the rest of the meal, details still forthcoming below, but the empanadas we heavenly. The entire meal was delicious, but the appetizers stole the show.  Luckily we ordered the appetizers and our entrees at once, so I did get something else to write about. I had the Bife Vesuvio - steak stuffed with spinach, cheese and garlic. It may seem slightly redundant to get something stuffed with spinach and cheese after the empanada, but I was tantalized by the garlic (I believe it was the only item on the menu that specifically listed garlic. What was a guy to do?). Ultimately it was the right order; it was delicious. The steak, actually, was fine. I feel like it was a hunk of flank steak or something similar -- tough and plain. It was seasoned perfectly so that I almost forgot how dangerously close it came to being dry. The stuffing was out of this world. I feel like garlic and cheese on anything is almost cheating, but I won't complain. I loved it.  We both ate an incredible amount of food, but it is hard to pass on dessert so we decided to split a slice of carrot cake. Even the dessert was great. It was slightly more dense than what I consider a traditional carrot cake, which was right up my alley.  We bought wine from the over-priced wine store across the street from the restaurant. Tango Sur is b.y.o.b. and they charged (I believe) no corking fee. As a practical matter, the over-priced wine from the store was still less expensive than it would have been off a restaurant menu, so take that into consideration if you go to the same store.  This was a great restaurant and without his suggestion, I never would have found it on my own.  Tango Sur is located at 3763 N Southport Ave, between Grace and Waveland.  773.477.5466

Tango Sur was my first Argentine dining experience... it blew me away.   You've got to try the steak--I preferred it over both the Chophouse and Gene&Georgetti's... sure, it's a totally different atmosphere, but they do an EXCELLENT JOB and the prices are definitely reasonable.  Also, it's BYOB so you can grab your fav. Shiraz for half of what you'd pay for it at a restaurant. Who can say no to that? I was there with a sizable group (10 or 12 maybe?) for a late dinner, and service was not lightening-fast.  I was informed that this is normal, though--especially when you factor in the authentic Argentine cultural influence that is present throughout this establishment's service.  Slow is just the way to go--savor your meal, spend lots of time with friends, drink an extra bit of wine... and life is good.  Tango Sur!

okay, so i REALLY enjoyed this restaurant the only time i was able to get a table. love a BYOB, portions are huge, food is tasty and outdoor seating in the summer is very nice. highly recommended for serious, hungry carnivores. it's not the best steak you will ever have, but it's very flavorful and you get more than your money's worthl.  i would advise if you are going on a friday or saturday, go at LEAST an hour before you want to eat, the wait can be pretty brutal. luckily, there are plenty of bars in the area, the host will take your phone number and call you when your table's ready. we've gone to cullen's to wait, if you brought white wine they'll even put it in their fridge for you. we tried to go this weekend, but were quoted a two hour wait, and after two hours, they said there were still five tables ahead of us and they were close to closing. disappointing, but just make sure you get there early on weekends.

Very good!  I had a steack and it was great.  This place is also BYOB which is a plus.    The only drawback was the wait-- they apparently don't take reservations for less than 6.  We got there, they said it would be 45 minutes, 95 minutes later we finally got sat.

I finally went to Tango Sur. I agree with most of the reviews - the food was great, the portions were huge, service was quick and helpful. And of course, prices are reasonable and it's BYOB.  I would recommend you make a reservation, as many others have mentioned and we forgot. We had to wait 45 minutes for a table for two on a Tuesday, which wasn't a problem because we just walked around Southport and waited for the call.

Fantastic restaurant and BYOB is part of the appeal. You will not walk away hungry. I'm not sure that the filet mignon I ordered was a tranditaionl cut for filet mignon, but it was yummy nonetheless. The spinach mashed potatoes were a perfect compliment. The appetizer I had, sort of like an eggplant lasagna was amazing. I could have eaten an entire pan of it! And I could not get over the prices! We ordered 6 entrees, 2 appetizers and 8 empanades and it was only $240 including tip. Really a good deal.  The only drawback is that it can get loud, so just know what you are getting into. They only take reservations for large parties.

I live in the neighborhood, and I've been wanting to check this place out for awhile.  This place is definitely above-average, but I wasn't astounded. My quick recap: Service: 5/5  - Very attentive staff, and no charge for corking the wine.  And even though they don't take reservations, the hostess (who is VERY kind) will take your number and call you when your table is ready. Atmosphere: 4/5 - Great location on Southport.  Nice outdoor seating area.  My mom commented that there was only one unisex toilet, though. Food:  3.5/5 - The general consensus was that our food was great.  The portions were generous, and everyone's steak was cooked as they ordered it.  My dad commented that his steak (strip) was fattier than he expected.  Also, he was dismayed that his meal didn't come with potatoes (which can be ordered for a small price)

I can't believe it has taken me THIS long to get to Tango Sur - I've sure been missing out on an excellent restaurant!  I've tried making reservations in the past for this place, but they have never been accepted, so we finally lucked out, got their early, and got seated last night without having to wait. We ordered the melted provolone ("provoleta" on the menu, I think) to start, which reminded me of the queso fundido I track down at every Mexican restaurant I eat at.  I then was at an impasse between myself and the menu when deciding on an entree.  I was stuck between the filet and the sirloin, but ultimately decided on the sirloin (since I eat my steak medium-well, I was told it'd be a CRIME to get a filet cooked that way).  The date got the paradilla for one. Instead of getting a measley-sized meal, our meals could have easily fed 4 people instead of 2.  I ended up taking leftovers from the restaurant because it was just too much.  My steak was excellent and the garlic butter parsley or whatever it was sauce that came with it was a nice added touch.  I noticed there were some chicken and seafood dishes also, and next time I have my eye on the roasted chicken. Factoring in the bottle of wine with no corkage fee, all this came under $50.  I can't believe it took this long to get there, but I have a feeling it won't be nearly as long for a return trip.

Tango Sur has some amazing dishes on their menu, I really enjoyed the food.  Portions are enormous for the price.  Ambiance is nice inside, though we went on a Friday night and it was rather crowded and noisy inside.  We brought our own bottle of wine which was a great way to save some money as well (and no corkage fee!). The one big downside to this restaurant was the service.  Our waiter was not at all friendly or attentive, and never bothered to explain much of the menu to us.  He was frequently gone, and after we finished our entrees merely asked "Anything else?".  We had to ask him to see a dessert menu.  He also never refilled our wine glasses.   I would still definitely recommend it, though it may be better for a weekday night! Also, they don't take reservations for less than 6 so keep that in mind!

I see that most of the reviews here are great, but I can't agree.  I came here at the recommendation of some friends.  The only good thing this restaurant has going for it is that it's a BYOB.  I thought the wait staff was rude and not attentive enough.  The empanadas were okay, but low on filling.  My date and I ordered the filet for 2--it came in this tray of oil and fat.  It was awkward to cut as the table was way too small!  Chicken was really dry.  I could never eat here again and never feel like I'm missing anything.

Yep not much more to say besides what has already been said.  Great intamate place, great prices, BYOB with no corkage fee.  Can be a long wait and no reservations.  Order the combo meat platter.  Everything you are not likely to order for yourself.  Blood sausage, head cheese, sweet breads, and some great marinated extras.  Anthony Bourdain and Andrew Zimmerman would approve!

It's pretty clear that I'm not the only one who ADORES this place!  The fiance and I went here for the first time Friday night, and it took all of our will power not to return Saturday and Sunday.  Amazingly scrumptous food and dark, romantic atmosphere for dirt cheap!  (Plus no corkage fee - yay!)  I won't go on and on cuz there are so many reviews here, but if you want to avoid the wait, go early-bird-special-style: head over there right after work; the wait doesn't seem to start until 7-ish.

best deal in the city $20 bucks for two 12oz filet steaks and it's BYOB!! It's a great date place.  The only problem is there is always a wait and they don't take reservations.  They will call you when your table is ready if you ask and you can go to the bar across the street.  It's really yummy you should try it:)
I loved this place.  the wait was well woth it.   The spinach mashed patatoes were so good.

The best bang for your  buck in the city! You get 2 steaks with your order for the price of one very reasonably priced steak.  The staff is very friendly and attentive, and best of all it's BYOB!  Being able to get an excellent steak (the filet is fantastic) and a bottle of wine for the price of just one steak is amazing. The waits are very long, but there is plenty to do on Southport while you wait - so just go prepared to explore the neighborhood.  It is very small and crowded and gets pretty loud, but it is a fun atmosphere and excellent food.

You get the idea by now: meat, meat, cheap wine because it's BYOB, huge portions of meat, meat meat, waddle out, go home, and dream about meat.  I was there with a group of 9 to celebrate a friend's birthday. We split a set of the empanadas, which were amazing, along with a few other appetizers. For our entrees, we ordered six of the steaks served with salad and roasted potatoes, which were split among 8 of us (the other guy ordered salmon, the translated word for which is 'pez', which continues to make laughter well up inside of me still 48 hours later. Despite sharing six entrees among eight people, two of which were another guy and I who typically count for 2-3 people each when estimating portion sizes, and we still had a decent amount of leftovers. And the chimichurri sauce! Nectar of the gods. This place can be tremendously romantic, which was obvious to me, who has the eye for romance of an ogre. It can also do a dang fine job of accommodating a large group celebrating a birthday, which it did ably on Saturday night. Can't wait to return!

i LOVE tango sur! but that's probably because i'm as carnivorous as a girl can get! It's true the wait is long but it all depends.  I just went on sunday and we were able to make a reservation because we had 6 people. Even so, there was no need for one because we came in at 6:30pm.  Don't get me wrong though, when we left at 8ish, there was a LONG line to be seated! (so don't be surprised if they start itching to get you out!) The service was actually very quick and attentive. Of course that's because it wasn't completely packed when we came in.  We brought our own wines to drink so we were set for that!  We also brought in a cake to celebrate a birthday so BEWARE, there's a dessert charge!!  they didn't warn us of that so that was lame considering all they did was grab some plates/spoons and handed us one regular knife. I love the short ribs there.  it looks like giant kalbi (korean) but a LOT thicker.  unfortunately, one was extremely salty but the others were absolutely delicious!  if you're VERY picky about that, maybe you should mention "not too salty" when you order, but in my opinion...  i wouldn't risk it.  I'd rather get 1 salty one and 2 good ones....  then 1 good one and 2 plain ones!!  but that's just me! =P

Went on a Saturday night and got there early (5ish).  We had our pick of tables.  Within an hour the place was packed and there was a waiting list.  I ordered the Bife Vesuvio, which I thought was too salty and the meat was undercooked.  I asked for medium and the bottom of the beef was pretty much raw.  There was more than enough food, so I didn't walk away hungry.  My friends really enjoyed their dishes (filet, and an appetizer of eggplant with cheeses).  Once the restaurant was crowded, the waiter was a little inattentive, but yet still seemed to push us out the door.  I'd go back, but I'd probably ask for the meat to be cooked medium-well.

It started off a little bumpy but overall it was a positive experience.  The wait is incredibly long, and it's a popular place for birthdays and large parties so be prepared to wait about 1.5 hours for a table.  There is a great Tapas place down the street that serves a tasty mojito to keep you busy.   The food is delicious, and the portions are beyond generous.  You'll definitely have leftovers.  Our server was attentive and helpful, as was the host.   Not recommended to bring your family......but definitely for dinner with friends, or boy/girl friends.

The wait here is extremely long, but honestly, who cares. Tango Sur will take down your number and let you wander off to the numerous bars down the street on Southport. Plan for an hour+ wait to get a table, and at least 2 hrs for the meal. I got the filet at the recommendation of the server and was not disappointed. It was one of the juiciest steaks I've had. The meat wasn't the highest quality in the world, but the price/performance ratio was up there. Our bill came out to exactly $100 for four people who ordered meat entrees with a pile of empanadas to start off the meal. BYOB makes it all possible. Can't beat that! When I visited, my group was fortunate enough to get a table outside, so I'd recommend that if you aren't on a date. The inside is dark and cozy, leading me to believe that it is probably not as suitable for a group.

Last time I went here was during a very awkward time in a relationship with a friend. The fact that I felt that awkwardness with every bite and sip of my dinner and am STILL giving Tango Sur a positive review speaks volumes. The atmosphere is wonderful - festive while still feeling intimate. Wonderful music and people having a good time, but you can still hear your dinner companions. I've never had a problem getting a table in a reasonable amount of time, but they'll take your cell number if you want to leave while you wait.  And then, of course, there are the steaks. Huge. Inexpensive. Delicious, melt in your mouth.  The salad that comes with meals is pretty disappointing, but let's face it: we don't come to Tango Sur for the salad. Did I mention the BYOB, thereby making your meal even more of a bargain?

Tango Sur was wonderful in so many ways it is hard to begin.  From the music, straight from the tango salons in Buenos Aires.  To the beef, which was massive and quite tasty.  The wonderful intimate atmosphere of the place was just great. For American standards the service was a little slow.  However I did not visit this restaurant for the American experience, so I'd have to say the service level was an part with much of the rest of the world.  If you're in a hurry, why not visit Applebees?  I found it quite refreshing that I could just enjoy an unhurried dinner, without the usual rushed American restaurant feeling. After enjoying the meal, I was quite pleasantly surprised at how little the bill was.  I don't think I've ever paid that little for so much great food.

To put it kindly, my father is  thrifty man. He was also raised on good old fashioned farm cookin', so he knows his food (jealous, locovores?).  When I decided to take my family here, I expected his usual "These prices are crazy!" and "Eh. I've had better."  Wow. I have never seen the man enjoy a meal so much. And who could blame him? Tango Sur is the real deal with grass fed beef that will melt in your mouth and will NOT give you mad cow disease due to stricter testing standards in, um, every country in the world besides the US? The empanadas are delicious and are available filled with spinach, ham, or beef (of course!). Vegetarian options are also available in beef dreamland, with pasta, veggie, and fish dishes available for non-carnivores. Make sure you get the potatoes, whether they are spinach mashed or fried. Save some of your bread for dipping in the to-die-for aioli sauce that comes with the steaks. Portions are HUGE as most meals come with two fillets. I will never forget when my Dad turned to look at me with the joy of a 10-year-old boy with illegal fireworks and said "You mean...I get TWO?" Dad's pleasure was further enhanced by the fact that this place is a BYOB beauty. We even got up in the middle of dinner to go restock at the CVS down the street. That NEVER happens. Tango Sure has definitely become a family tradition. Also, contrary to popular belief, Tango Sur does offer reservations, but only for parties of 6 or more. If you DO have to wait, the staff will take your cell phone number so you can go hang out in one of the numerous bars on Southport. Since Argentines eat later than most Americans, you will have better luck with seating if you go earlier, around 6 or 7PM. Weekend afternoons are also pleasantly vacant. And trust me, you will encounter lots of Argentines.  After this dinner of champions, my brothers and I took my parents for a drive down Sheridan Road to gawk at the houses, houses which I may be able to afford one day if I continue to indulge in Dad style/Tango Sur frugality. Maybe, if I'm lucky, one of the hot Tango Sur waiters will live there with me. Sigh....

I like this place... good food, nice atmosphere (dark with candle light & some good spanish rock or lounge music playing in the background) - I really like their empanadas.  I've gone here a number of times with friends and have had some fun times.  I've never had a problem with the service - so far the hot waiters with the sexy Argentinean accents have been nice.  Although this is definitely not a place to go if you are starving because everytime I've gone there's always been an annoyingly long wait. If you go make sure it's not during cold weather - the waiting line is outside - but as a courtesy they give you glasses to drink that bottle of wine you've brought with you.  By the time you get seated you're already buzzed and in the mood for munchies and you can order their food  - YAY! It is a bit small inside though - if you push your chair back you're sure to bump into someone or something.  So yeah... good food, hearty portions, sucky wait - nothing life-altering but not a place that you couldn't return to...  OH...and don't forget to take your leftovers... they're awesome the next day!

I was here last Friday while back in Chicago. The wait is usually horrible, but then again they take your number so you can go and have a drink somewhere. They call you when the table is ready. Last Friday they stated it would be an hour and fifteen to an hour and a half. Within 30 minuted they called! We had just had enough time to pick up some wine at a small store nearby (Que syrah).  3 out of the 4 had meat. One had salmon, and later stated you should not order fish at a Argentinian restaurant. There was too much sauce and it was not that good. The meat however was very good. I feel they give too much meat but I guess that is better than not enough. The potatoes the meat usually comes with are not good. Order a side of fries, they're tasty. On one of the specials they had spinach mashed potatoes and that was very nice. If I go back to Chicago, this is definitely a place I would like to go to again. It had not changed since I moved in October of 2006. If you have a smaller appetite you could also consider ordering some appetizers and sharing an entree (although most people I see there do not do so). Don't forget your bottle(s) of wine.

This place is good if you want to eat a whole lot of steak.  The quality is not the best but the price is right.  You have to remember that your steak is costing $20 instead of $50 at a nice steakhouse.  It is always busy here so make sure you go early if you want to get in without an unbearable wait.  I find the inside of the restaurant unimpressive so if you're lucky, you'll even get a table outside. Don't forget to bring some good wines for the BYOB or just run to the Jewel down the street.

I love this place!  I think Sunday night is the best day of the weekend to go.. it's not as crowded as a Friday or Saturday night even when reservations are made.   It's dark inside and the only light you get are from the candles on your table.  It's also very loud inside so don't expect to have any real conversations or you'll just have a lot of people nodding and pretending they understand. As a part-time vegetarian, meaning I order fish or vegetables whenever I can, even I have to get El Filet every time.  It's super tender even when you order it medium-well.  They give you a generous portion of meat with spinach mashed potatoes and I usually have leftovers for two more meals after my dinner there.  Don't forget the chimichurri sauce even though it gives you garlic breath.  It's delicious with the filet! Don't forget the red wine!  It's BYOB.

I was prepared for the large portion sizes (thanks yelpers) but I didn't understand that "large portions"  at tango sur means when you order a filet, you get two.  Two steaks.  Great for meat enthusiasts, but I was like "What the f--k am I going to do with two steaks?"   When leftovers aren't an option (we were going out right after dinner) this kind of excessive portioning can be frustrating, especially when the steak is good.  Which it was. I had high hopes for the empanadas.  While they were tasty, I don't see them as much more than glorified hot pockets.  But, maybe that's because I had the ham and cheese variety. The bathroom situation (persistent line, tight space) inspired two of my friends to venture outside in the adjacent alley.  The waiter was suspicious, angry even, but you know what? Nobody chooses to leave a restaurant to engage in public urination unless the bathroom situation is truly bad. The "can't be bothered" attitude of the servers made the European atmosphere all the more authentic, and actually was kind of endearing.

BYOB places are always a great find-they save you money and allow you to bring your favorite wine. I especially like Tango Sur for many reasons. They have lots of outdoor sidewalk seating which helps because the wait can sometimes be about an hour or so past 7 pm on any given night. If there is a wait, there are many bars nearby where you can go until they reach you by cell phone to let you know your table is available. The cheese appetizer dish is delicious and I always get great meat which I like medium. Definitely a place worth going. Plus, it's a great location!
Not the best steak, but they were pretty good. I had the filet and the seasoning was spot on, but the meat itself was lacking. Good price for what it is. BYOB and good appetizers.

Food is great; generous portion; BYOB makes it better. HOWEVER, be prepared to be kicked out once you're done with your meal. I went there a few weeks ago with a couple of friends and had such great time until our waiter came to our table and said he needed our table for other customers. We were about to order desserts and coffee but it didn't matter to him. You would think a manager would come by; politely explain the situation and try to make us understand. The waiter didn't even smile; he literally just told us he needed the table. This place is known for a not so good service but I have always try to pass it by saying, "well it's a busy place" or "their food is great!" But being kicked out is absolutely unacceptable. I don't know if I will ever go back after that.

I am a true carnivore.  I can't live w/o meat.  And I will go back.  Because Tango Sur delivers some really good meat, and it tastes sooo yummy. But the service is horrible.  Everyone knows it.  The entire city knows.  Hell, Tango Sur knows it, but apparently they could care less cuz they know they have tasty food and people will continue to come, whether or not they treat their guests with respect.  Which they totally don't.  And you can't get a straight answer out of anyone working there.   I worked in the industry for YEARS throughout college, and I know how stressful it can be.  Therefore I am usually more than understanding towards servers.  But I actually got into a verbal altercation with my server.  He ignored us and I called him out on it.   This happened a long time ago, and this is why I haven't been back. Again, what stinks is that they are completely aware that their high volume takes away from service.  But it's a different dining culture and I take that into consideration. Still not going back anytime soon though......

This restaurant has quickly become one of my favorite spots - and apparently I'm not the only one.  I live fairly close, and every time I walk by there is a huge line.  The food here is worth the wait!  The portions here are HUGE, and you can pretty much split most entrees between two people.  I prefer the chicken or beef Napolitana, and I can make about three meals out of it with left-overs.  It's BYOB, so grab a bottle of cheap wine at the Jewel just down the street while you're waiting.  The only thing stopping me from giving it the full five stars is the wait staff is a little slow.  Also know that they don't accept special requests or changes to the dishes.

Tango Sur is arguably the best BYOB restaurant in the city. The only thing that makes it lose one star is the wait -- no reservations so plan on being their a while. They don't really have the place well set up for the large number of people waiting for a table either.  The food, however, is excellent and the portions are large enough to feel a small family. Their empanadas are wonderful, and even those family members suspicious of the mildest forms of ethnic food will be satisfied here. It is essentially a wonderful steakhouse. The prices are very reasonable, so if you want to buy an amazing, somewhat fancy dinner for very little, this is the place to go!

I really wanted to like this place a lot more than I did, but I think I expected too much reading all of the previous reviews from fellow yelpers.  Let me paint the picture... I called on Monday to make a reservation for Tuesday and the dude on the phone told me to call back 1 hour before my arrival time on Tuesday and he would add me to the list.  So, I called back on Tuesday and did just that.  Well, by the time I arrived at Tango Sur, my name wasn't on the list.  I probably would have been pissed at that point, but the harem were all running late so, I added my name to the list and didn't fret.   Luckily once all of the harem arrived we were able to sit down immediately at a table for four outside.  As soon as I sit down, I begin to notice the guitar player return from his break and being to play his musica.  Yes, it's kind of loud and annoying and I didn't really appreciate his musica sitting right next to him.  I'm sure they could plug in an iPod and get the same effect.   Our server was .... pushy.  Yes, I think that's a nice way of putting it.  He was pushy because he asked us what we wanted to order three times before we even opened up the menu.  And when it came to paying for our meal, he came by eight times before we decided we should actually look at the bill and put down some credit.  Regardless of our waiter's eagerness to get us up and out, the bus boys were very attentive with our dirty plates and almost empty glasses. The meal itself was okay.  We decided to order the empanadas and they were very good... actually, the best part of the meal.  I suggest to order the chicken and the spinach & cheese variety.  As for dinner, Nic ordered the eggplant special appetizer thing (because she don't eat no read meat); Mon and Car ordered the Churrasco; and I ordered the Milanesa a La Napolitana which is beef breaded then topped with baked ham, mozzarella and tomato sauce.  I thought it sounded gross, ordered it anyway, and shockingly, found it ... edible.  But, again it was just okay.  I also had a bite of the girls' steak.  Mon ordered it med. rare and Car ordered it med. well.  Car's steak ended up being cooked well and was a little tough.  Mon's was a little too red for my liking, but she likes it red.    ...Irrelevant part of the review... Because we had a long dinner, I couldn't help but notice all of the Southporters making their walks home with Dairy Queen in hand.  I sat in my seat all night watching couple after couple after gay after couple after fat man with baby and skinny wife walk down the street with their DQs.  It made me want a DQ real bad.   ...Back to the review... So, even though I really wanted to love the Tango Sur, I just thought it was okay.  And it's not because I thought there was going to be all these hott Argentinean waiters around because it's an Argentinean restaurant.  I saw some cute male staff working, but am still giving it 3 stars.  3.5 if they had it, but they don't and I'm choosing not round up.
great place... can't really add too much more then what everyone else has already shared - beware the portion size though, when they say for one, they mean for two...

This place is only a couple blocks from where I live and I've walked by many a time and the tables are always full of people.  This past Friday night I was able to FINALLY able to try it- and what an amazing meal.   We had a variety of appetizers- the fresh Mozzarella and all the variety of Empenadas - WOW all of it was GREAT. Then the salmon in the sauce with the capers melted in my mouth, and I though I am not a big beef eater I did try it and it was fairly good:) The BYOB was a new experience and when we first sat down I didn't realize that was their policy.  Since this kindda meal defiantly requires a nice bottle of wine- I walked back to my house quick brought one back.  I recommend planning ahead if in case you don't live close by- but there is a nice wine store near by in case you forget. For the $$$- the servings are HUGH.  I will be back for more:)

Definitely one of the best restaurants I have ever been to in the city.  We started out the night outside at a table on the patio and it started pouring!  The wait staff was very helpful in getting us a table inside the restaurant; they quickly accommodated everyone who had been stuck in the rain. Our dinner service was a little slow, but there was some confusion because we had moved to a new table from the patio (we had a new waiter).  The service overall is just right, though, especially for a nice romantic dinner; the waiter isn't hovering but he doesn't disappear.   We ordered and appetizer for both of us and an entree each; I'd defintely recommend either a light appetizer or none at all - there was way too much food!  It was all delicious, but the appetizer was so good that it sort of ruined our entree appetite.  We got the melted queso platter which was amazing... I'd definitely recommend if you have a large party.  I got the blackened steak entree which was - hands down - the best steak I've ever had.  My boyfriend had the breaded veal chop and he really enjoyed it. The BOYB setting makes this place even more amazing.  Definitely recommended to everyone, especially steak lovers.

There's not much that can be said about this place that hasn't already been said.  The food is great and it's BYOB so you can leave stuffed full of great food with a pretty low tab.  It's usually pretty crowded.  I've encountered 2 hour waits on the weekend.  However, if you get there early on a slower weeknight you can get seated really quickly.

Tango Sur is my favorite South American steakhouse.  I;m not really big on the whole "all you can eat" bit; I'm much more of a believer in quality over quantity.  Did I also mention that I'm a pretty carnivorous chick!   From what people say, it seems as though there normally is a huge wait on the weekends to get a table.  I live right around the corner and frequent Tango Sur quite a bit and have never had a problem.  During the week, I've always walked in with no wait, but I do make reservations on the weekends. Apparently that is a wise thing to do. When you walk into the place, its dimly lit, very quaint, very tight.  I must say that there is not a lot of wiggle room, but I think that that just adds to the intimacy.  Just try not to get up and go the washroom a lot, as you may knock over the wine on the table next to you...oh yeah...its BYO.   When I eat here, I feel like I'm in a little place in Argentina or Spain...very rustic and simple.   As for the food...EXCELLENT!!!   I always love to start out with the procioutto and melon.  I love that combination and their prociutto is perfect.  On to the main course, I love to get the parillada for two.  I shre it with another hungry person, obviously.  :) They bring you a skillet thing with the flames a blaze below and the meat sizzling on top.  It comes with short ribs, flank steak, chorizo, blood sausage, sweetbreads, maybe something else too...not sure.  I go nuts for the stuff and drench everything in their chimichurri sauce.   Their chumichurri sauce is probably the best I've ever had.   They do it right here.

Tango sur............I had a BLAST!!!!!!!!!!!! The food- WONDERFUL, huge juicy cuts of meat(says my friend Howie), tender salmon(says Ginger), flavorful pastas(says ME the resident vegetarian). Unlimited rolls of bread warm from the oven!! The service- FANTASTIC! Although the restaurant is as busy as possible, my water glass was always kept full and the plates were cleared ASAP(but it didn't feel like they were breathing down your neck). The restaurant is filled with attractive Latin waiters(yes I'm being shallow I know) who speak to you in a sexy accent!! Now the bad...........    Yes the candles are nice, however for some it would be hard to read their menu. In pictures the restaurant SEEMS like it would be uber romantic, but its so loud its hard getting a word in edge wise. Further more there is ONE bathroom per gender, which leaves a few women standing in line during peak times. All in all I thought the place was WONDERFUL and would definitely go back. I was sooooooo stuffed I didn't even have room to TRY a dessert(which looked DELICIOUS). If you wish to go during peak hours, be prepared to wait, ladies don't wear uncomfy shoes(as the waiting area is the side walk) or better yet, give them your name/cell number and go pick up your BYOB while you are waiting for your table.

I am running behind in finally reviewing Tango Sur, but I wanted to sing the praises of my experience at this great restaurant. I was in Chicago for July 4th weekend, often eating on the fly with a few sit down options taken, most that were just disgusting. Finding Tango Sur was a great thing. My travel partner and I found the place when asking around in Lincoln Park, and headed there on the detail given by the random person on the street, and how they looked as they recanted eating there... almost like they went there a moment and left the sidewalk in front of me.  lol The advice was good. I was uncertain about the place, as we arrived RIGHT at the time before the place gets busy, finding a place to park very close by. The wait staff was very good, with questions and the patience with the indecision of my cohort. The expediters and bus-boys very on it. Waters filled, and others wine bottles opened and served what seemed to be efficiently.  Being the only ones there when we arrived, the place was full by the time we were half way into our meal, giving a great ambiance to what was initially too quiet a place. I had 12 oz steak(rare) with the roasted potatoes. The steak was PERFECT, as were the potatoes. I am glad that I opted for them, as I have not been eating starches as often as I once did, so I had been reserved. They were worth the indulgence of carbs for sure.   The Empanadas before the entree were really good, but I would say that the included salad(a few leaves of head lettuce, a few sliced tomatoes, and rings of onion, with oil and vinegar as the only dressing option) that was with the entree was a bit disappointing, though I really did not need more with such a HUGE steak that seemed well over the listed menu weight. It was excellent and the seasonings of the Argentine influence were a nice change from the midwest traditional steak. The lack of a star to make it 5 stars is effected by the fact that veggie choices seem to be the only think lacking at this establishment. I will be back here, hopefully with a date vs a friend next time. One of the best finds so far on my exploits of Chicago.... which have just begun!

Excellent Argentinian meats, though they tend to be a little salty. However, great value for money, and they were one of the pioneers of the whole BYOA thing back in 2005. The inside can get really loud - the acoustics magnify the sound of drunk buffoonery especially, so outside seating is recommended.

I have been to Tango Sur many times, and I will continue to go back! I have taken out of town guests, gone on dates, birthday parties...etc. Always a wonderful experience. I know that the wait is long, but it is one of the few places that I really think is worth it. The food is so delicious! The price is great for the amount! I always get two meals out of the filet. Can't beat the BYOB and never had a problem with the service!

My favorite place and it's BYOB. Atmosphere is wonderful and reminds me of a tiny place you'd see in Europe with the small tables, candle light, and people packed together. All men waiters and even though this place is always packed the service is always good. No corkage fee either if you have a party with more than 8 they'll let you make a reservation otherwise it's first come first serve.

Well, The service was perfectly fine and i got there around 5:40 on a Sat and was seated immediately.  The food was very good, but my partner who had the El Filet (and ATE THE WHOLE THING) said his two filets were both cooked differently.  I had the beef vesuvio and it was tasty and humongous.  Unfortunately I forgot the leftovers at the table.   I didn't find it all that cheap, I guess.  The appetizer (baked cheese) and dessert were just OK.  the dinners were very good.  I will go back.  I just wish my partner wasn't such a big eater that we can't share and save money!

I don't go on a whole lot of dates. I know, I know, this is a huge shock to everyone, but bear with me. It took this guy and I a whole effing year to decide that we should go out. And he was all, "Maggianos?!" And I was all, "It took us a year to go on an actual date and not put a frozen pizza in the oven. Fuck that, we are not going to a chain that I went to before Homecoming in high school." So I suggested Tango Sur, based on Jenny A's recommendation, and my own love of steak, and figured that, as a boy, my date would be psyched to hear about going to a meat-centric place. He was. He had gotten there before me, so he put our name in, and we walked down the street to go get some wine (since it's BYOB), and when we got back, they were ready to seat us on the patio. I have no idea what my date ordered, because I was SO FIXATED on my fillets. Both of them. They were perfectly cooked and perfectly flavored and each one was roughly the size of my face. It came with some mashed potatoes and this great sauce that played on the flavor of the meat. It was, in a word, amazing. I'm only giving it four stars because our server was hard to find (the busboys run their asses off, though) and we were seated directly behind the guy who plays random background music on his guitar and I could barely hear anything my date said to me.

If you don't mind waiting 2+ hours or more on the weekend,  and you're looking for a tasty and inexpensive steak dinner ( I believe for 2 steak dinners our bill was $40), this is the place! I've now gone there three times and each time I leave I'm satisfied.The fact that it's BYOB (no corkage fee) helps to seal the deal!

Very tasty meat dishes here, and decent pricing too.  (Latin people can really bang out some quality protein!)  The place is small, though, so expect to wait.  But hey, where's there's good eats, there's a crowd!
Can't find any juicy steak like the ones here in Chicago. And the price is very reasonable. I gave it 5 stars!

I stopped in for dinner this weekend. We had a big group and sat outside. It was perfect weather to sit outside and I'm glad we did because the inside was dark and noisy. The food would have been good, but the experience would not have been quite as nice inside. The waiter was extremely knowledgeable with the menu. All of the suggestions were great. I was to only person at our table that didn't get the El Filet. It is 2 full filets and the beef tastes awesome. I had the spinach and cheese stuffed steak with chimichurri sauce. This was wonderful as well. Everyone had an empanada for an appetizer and they were tasty too. It was also more food than any of us could eat. I would say overall it was a great dining experience and you can't beat the prices at this restaurant .

Good food, great prices.  The wait SUCKS!!  And they won't let you make a reservation unless you have at least 8 in your party.  AND, the two guys who work the front door are completely rude, devoid of courtesy, and basically, not customer service oriented at all.  They don't have to be b/c everyone wants to get in b/c of the food. So, go early, and be prepared to wait at least an hour if you are going on the weekend.  Once you're inside tho, it feels just like how it did in Buenos Aires -- tight spaces, loud conversations, good food.

We went to dinner here with another couple.  Since we were too late to snag reservations, we had to show up and put our names down on the list.  They said it was a 90 minute wait but it was closer to 2hr.   The dining room was a tad too loud for my taste.  It might have been because there were several large groups.  Once the food came (empanadas, steak), it was well worth the wait.  Although we brought 2  bottles of wine with us to drink, a group offered us their leftover wine.  Sweet! I was entirely too full to try the dessert.  The dinner was extremely reasonable considering the cost.  I will definitely come back when I'm in the area.

I went here for the first time last Wednesday.  It was 1/2 hour before they were about to close so I was kinda nervous that they would kick us out before we could finish our meal.  That WAS NOT the case at all.  They were sooo nice and said for me to take my time.  The food was really good, especially the empanadas.  My chicken limon was a tad bit dry but still flavorful.  Very affordable and has a great ambiance.  I will definitely return.

Great dining experience. Amazing bang for the buck...we spent 46.00 and had enough for lunch the next day.  It is a little bit loud, but not too bad and of course you can bring wine which is great (no corkage fee). It's a must! we are taking our friends there when they come to visit.

This place is so great.  It's not the best steak you'll ever have, but it's up there and for the value it can't be beat!  El Filet is actually two filets and you can take one home!  The juice at the bottom of the plate is just so tasty.  I recommend this place very often!

Ok, this place is a gem!   Where else can you eat good steak and have byob?   I love getting the filet mignon and drinking a good red wine with it.  I normally split the meal with a friend because it's actually two large pieces of steak and it's way too much to eat on it's own. If you live in Chicago and you haven't been there, you have to go!  GO NOW! Seriously, we had 4 people in our group, we all ate healthy portions and drank way too much wine and spent $88 with tax and tip.  AMAZING!

At Tango Sur you will not find your typical American styled USDA CHOICE! prime-rib with mashed potatoes and A1 sauce. Some people experience a bit of culture shock when it comes to how different it is from the expected "Steak/Meat Place". Argentine  beef is known as some of the BEST in the world, these people really take their meat seriously. The enviroment and ambiance of the place is darkly dim, with  small candles on tables and they usually have various types of soft spanish pop or tango music playing thus providing a very romantic ambiance, ideal for a date or just a special night out with the inlaws (great way to impress someone with showing them  your sophisticated tastes). Beer is available but WINE is more suitable being that it does increase the dinning experience and flavors of the beef, but also can provide an even deeper more romantic or fun experience. Again Great for dates. Not only because the ambiance is right and inviting but because the food is also adequete. Order one of the special meet dishes , which come in their own small portable grill, with potatoes, ready to serve. its like having a mini grill in the middle of your table with a chunk of world class beef, surrounded with candles zipping on wine with your  significant other, sharing delicious TAPAS which are great appetizers and perfect finger food get a mix variety so  you can try different ones, also the eggplant salad is delicious. Budget wise it is pretty economical considering the fact you are eating PREMIUM beef, not just any Bull****. You can also bring in your own liquour since it is a BYOB joint, Bring a bottle of WINE, A girl, and about 30 bucks and you can call it a night out. Plenty of parking around and on site, IF you bring your grandma make sure u have her hold on to you, as it is very dim and she could trip and bust her ass. Cheers and enjoy.. Try the Sangria if you bring no wine. Check out  tonsilcleaner.com  join our breath forum!
I had dinner here with someone I absolutely hate and still had a great time.  That's how damn good the steak is.  It makes all petty things go away.  At least for a little while.

One of my favorite restaurants in the city.  The atmosphere always has so much energy and the food is to die for.  As a BYOB, you would not expect the food to be as delicious as it is, but you can definitely head here with a bunch of girl friends, some red wine and not break the bank.

I'm really surprised that this place got such good reviews.  I really hope I was there on an "off" day or maybe I ordered the wrong thing.  We were with a group of 11 and had reservations.  I was15 minutes late and my friends were already seated, so no waiting.  The place was PACKED and when we walked in nobody greeted us.  We just walked into the back room to find our friends.  I didn't have a problem with this, I'm seeing that is more of a casual laid back place.  The ambiance was great, brick walls pillar candles on every table.  We had prosciutto for a starter, I've had better.  I was going to be "good" and order the grilled chicken and vegetables but changed my mind when my friend said their filet was "the best she's ever had".  So I order mine medium well and she ordered hers medium.  When the waiter delivered mine I said "Is this medium well?"  He said "Yes".  Come to find out half way through my pretty well done steak that I had her medium and she had my well.  We switched and now mine was REALLY well....burnt.  I didn't even finish it.  It came with (green) mashed potatoes which were okay.  I think they had spinach in them, nothing to write home about.  My bf had the T-Bone and said Outback was better.  I was pretty disappointed after all the hype, but again maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.  But I figured I couldn't go wrong with a filet in a place known for their meat.  I wouldn't go out of my way to go back to Tango Sur.  Instead, check out my review of Machu Picchu - it's way better!

IT's hard for me to like a place that just is sooo crazy! I mean the no reservations makes it difficult to plan, but not only that, I just feel like it is way too busy.  The food here is decent, the service is good, the desserts blow.

I went here with a super large group (16 to be exact). We had reservations and everything worked out pretty well. The no-corkage fee definitely was an added plus with the large group. I'm not a big steak person so we all kind of munched on different appetizers. They were all delicious. However, without the steak, it didn't really feel like a full meal. We were chatting and gossiping the entire time but I thought the service was pretty decent. If I was with a group and they wanted to go here, I would probably go again. However, probably not by my own first choice.

Oh Tango, how I love thee.  1. Cheap, good steak - if you've been to Argentina, you know that this restaurant does it up authentic. Their meat is very tender, and they have great chimichurri sauce. Their eggplant appetizer is sooo good. The portions are big. 2. It's BYOB - c'mon, that's major points right there! (Except when the over-eager waiters and busboys cleared away my very-sentimental bottle... I suggest you be careful if you bring a bottle that you want to keep) 3. It's dark and lit by candles. Cute in a dim, noir, semi-seedy way. Good for groups; they have a back room for private parties. Only con? The wait. Ohhhh the agony. Call in advance for reservations (they take it for small groups, not for huge groups). It helps if you show up 2 hours before you want to eat, deliver your name, and then go off somewhere to stave off your gnawing hunger. But at least they will call you when they've got your spot.

Cheap steak but huge opportunity cost in terms of wait.  I put my name down at 7:15pm and we weren't seated until 9:15pm.  They do take your cell phone number so you can wander around the area (though nothing is open past 7pm besides the CVS), but they then do this weird thing where they call you to tell you to come - then usher you into the "waiting room" where you have to wait for ANOTHER 40 minutes. The good thing about loitering at the CVS is that you have plenty of time to pick up a bottle of cheap wine or beer to go with your cheap dinner.  BYOB is always a plus. We started off with some tasty empanadas.  Though they were both good, I highly recommend the beef one (juicy and flavourful) over the spinach and cheese one.  Our steaks came with complimentary salads and potato wedges.  My 12 oz sirloin was barely ok - though decently seasoned, it was cooked into medium well territory even though I had specified medium rare.  My friend's strip steak was better - less well done, thicker, and juicier. Good and plenty big caramel flan dessert.  Service was decent considering how busy they were!  Bill including tax & tip was $60 for both of us.  Great price but probably would not come here again due to wait and mediocre quality of the steak.

Wow!   This place is amazing.  The chorizo is perfect and the steaks are a dream.  Make sure to pile on the chimichurri sauce because it is a winner.  Be careful because the portions are huge, so come willing to share.   The BEST empanadas I have had in Chicago! Also it is BYOB

245 Reviews?  Holy Crap-a-roo!  I have always wanted to try Tango Sur but did not do so until just recently. . . for brunch.  Odd brunch choice, right?  I will say that the wait was short and the place was empty - good news for a party of 15! I LOVE steak.  So meaty.  Of course when I came here I was going to order it. . . but not without trying the empanadas (mmmm tasty).  Thanks to BYOB (and with brunch and brunch beverages on the brain) I brought a bottle of Prosecco and a tiny pint of OJ.  No one noticed this tiny OJ until another diner stole my idea and dashed out for more mimosa materials.  Seriously, why did he have to buy TWO large cartons of OJ (everyone knows the best mimosas are made with just a *splash*).   Anyhooch, we had to order OJ since they serve it at the restaurant and tose big cartons ON the table drew a little bit of attention.  Still, this was OK (except for the guy with all that excess!).  I ordered the outer skirt steak and to be honest, I found it really fatty and tough. . .nothing like a skirt steak should be.  I will definitely opt for the filet next time.  And I will go near the evening and bring a good bottle-o-red.  Tango Sur?  Good concept, and lots of meat, but not the best place for brunch.

The ONLY thing I did not care for was the wait, it was 2 hours but it was a Friday night and I really think it was worth the wait.  Our party of four met here around 8pm Friday night and were told the wait time, so we went to a bar down the street and had cocktails.  When it came closer we walked to a nearby Jewel and bought 6 bottles of wine, this was my first BYOB experience (not offered in texas) and it worked out very well. We started with 2 apetizers, empanadas (one of each - beef, chicken, ham/cheese, spinach/cheese) and the tortilla de papas.  The servings were small but effective and the flavors were delicious, my favorite was the spinach & cheese empanada. Katie and Natalie split the Vacio steak, this portion was huge and plenty for both of them.  I did not try theirs but they both enjoyed it very much.  My buddy Aaron ordered another steak but I cannot remember the name.  I ordered the Bife de Chorizo medium rare.  I was wondering if I should have ordered sides to accompany it but when the serving came out I was surprised at the portion size, sadly I could not finish the entire steak.  The olive oil/garlic sauce that came with it was delicious and I thought the steak was cooked very well.   The total bill for the 4 of us was right around $95 including tip, well worth it and I'll definitely come back.

I love, love, love Tango Sur!!! I have been here many times and have never had a bad experience. Granted the decor and the cramped space are their weak points but their food makes up for that. I have tried various dishes and can say that the Bife Vesuvio is the greatest item on their menu along with their empanadas. I highly recommend this place but if you're very hungry or have no patience don't go here past 7PM when the wait for the table becomes very long.

My first trip to an Argetinian steak house and I loved it.  Giant sized portions of properly prepared steak in the low $20 range.  A nice atmosphere inside and, when the weather is nicer, outdoor seating as well.  Plus the whole BYOB thing really pushes it over the top.   I ordered veal here for the first time in...ever.  It was labeled free range which was the main selling point for me though I'm not sure how they managed to sell a T-bone (kind of- it was missing the tenderloin side) of free range veal for $21. Either way it was interesting and I loved it though without the fat content of an older cow I don't know how to order it.  I went with rare, as usual, but it was a little chewy.   All the other portions at the table were totally unfinishable and we only shared the empanadas (amazing) for apps and the burger topping salads.  My brother got some kind of giant platter with 2 kinds of sausage, short ribs, something else, and sweetbreads (I LOVE SWEETBREADS!) for $18.   The only reason Tango Sur doesn't get the 5th star is for their short ribs which are inexplicably not braised but grilled.  Like braising a tenderloin this just doesn't work.  Among our many doggy bags was a container of short ribs that I braised at home the next day (they were delicious) but that shouldn't really be part of going out to eat.

Walking into this restaurant shortly after it opened for dinner, I immediately found the smell permeating throughout to be highly revolting and nauseating...like the stench of old blood embedded permanently in the crevices of a slaughter house. The atmosphere is dark and gloomy, most befitting for a vampire. Illuminated by faint lighting and adorned by dark walls, white candlesticks centered on each table, and a cluster of old photos of Evita, Tango Sur offers up tender, juicy beef dishes in an atmosphere malodorous of death and creepiness. Even as the under-heated empanadas, and later the main course, were served and slowly filling the dining room with culinary aromas, the smell of old blood still lingered in the air. I did enjoy the filet mignon and spinach mashed potatoes, as well as the background Latin music, but everything else was mediocre, including the service, which was certainly nothing to boast about.  Despite the fact that I walked out feeling very full, the dining experience at Tango Sur left me feeling emotionally blue and melancholy. Another trip to Chicago will not be met by another trip to Tango Sur. One experience was way too many, I'm afraid. Of note, the white T shirt look worn by the not-so-friendly, pretentious waiters (a seemingly sexist establishment considering there were no women working) is a really cheap look. The staff would be better suited--no pun intended--(and look more professional) wearing white button-down shirts.

it always amazes me that places that are BYOB are so successful regardless of the slop they put on your plate. tango sur was gross the three times i went there, i didn't pay any of the times. the steak i asked for to be cook medium came back bleeding, and the octopus in the salad i swear were still moving. their side salad is a piece of lettuce with a tomato on top, i kid you not. the staff are attractive latino men, that was the only highlight, and since its BYOB there is always a crowd of waiting people who are already too drunk to even say excuse me and you try to navigate out. overrated.

I know, everyone will be amazed that I didn't give the big star rating but I have to say,  in this case, believe me I did.  And let me explain: Made an 8:00 reservation for 6, all of us arrived at 7:45, together, holding hands, making nice, with vino. 9:15, we're finally seated, on a Tuesday I might add.  I call Bullshit. We sit, the friends order some ridiculous grilled contraption for the table.  All the meat is over done and some of it is scary.  Some of it is grizzly.  Some of it is tough.  Some of it is repulsive.  I shut up and eat what is edible.  Some of it was decent. Server is invisible, busboy is amazing (he's a star and a half if that tells you anything.....) I try to order something ala carte because the group grill crap is nasty, yet I can't for lack of acknowlegement.  Another table sees my distress and send their waiter over...who at least makes an effort, but it goes no where.   Okay, I'm resigned to the bad, grizzly grub.  Just drink more wine.... We want to order dessert.   Send up flares, lighters, wave, pretend to be in a diabetic coma for lack of sugar, alas, nothing but a busboy saying "uno momento".  We order what we can from him while we have the chance.  Anal retentive waiter comes over with attitude and snippy insults in spanish not realizing 4 of 6 habla espanol.... Desserts blow and then check takes another half hour, at this point we are wagering on when condesending and worthless (this kills me to say this because I try to see the good in everyone......) waiter slaps down a check ...but does so with  not only corkage fees (not a problem) but an automatic gratuity.  So I basically took one up the ass for being with five friends and getting horrendous service.    Shame on him for being such a poor waiter when he could have doubled his grat since we all own or work at restaurants.  And shame on him for providing the worst service I've ever had and you know what, that is really a huge accomplishement because I've had some of the crappiest service in the world but he topped it, above and beyond.   While he may have thought he got away with something with the horrific service and auto grat, the bottom line is this: They lost a good customer base in all of us, He halfed his potential tip The busboy skated with an extra $30 for at least trying. The manager never bothered  The food was mediocre at best (I tried, I really did). I am embarassed to ever leave this kind of review, I really am,  but no one in that entire building seemed to care (except the table next to me) and isn't that what the service industry is all about?  Please bear in mind that the wait for the table did not bother me at all, that is not even remotely the issue here. I'm sorry Tango Sur, but you broke my heart!
nice place for a romantic dinner, the space is a bit cramped...but the food is well worth it. BYOB!

What's not to love? BYOB, great salads and warm bread, empanadas with garlic sauce, and sharing a big plate of meat and sweet potatoes over a grill. I've probably been to this restaurant more times than any other in the city, and it's because it's always consistently fantastic.   We love to take two bottles of red wine ('cause we inevitably end up drinking one while waiting for a table!) and order the Vacio to share.   In fact, when we were in Napa we actually bought a few bottles specifically for our next trip to Tango Sur.   Oh, and it's Southport, so you also get in some good people-watching, which is always a plus for nosy gals like me.

On weekends, the experience at Tango Sur is like a visit to the doctor.  It starts with an hour long wait and on your way home, you'll feel like you learned something about yourself...but unlike a visit to the doc, you get to drink wine.   On that note, bring plenty of wine because you won't find issues of Highlights in the waiting area. This being a steakhouse, you'll find meat preparation to be their obvious specialty.  Steaks for one should really mean two and a steak for two could mean six, but a meal of Tango Sur leftovers is just as good as the first.  Their salads are nothing more than a mere formality, but take a chance on their appetizers which range from extremely cheesy, to oily and garlic crazy.   The restaurant itself is cozy and charming with attentive waitstaff managing tables as a team.  Food is brought and taken away swiftly and you'll never find yourself with an empty wine or water glass.  Quarters may be close but that's just fine because you'll be too busy conquering your meal to eavesdrop on the diners next to you. Reservations are accepted for parties of 6 or more and there's a wine shop nearby should the need arise.

I've been to Tango Sur a couple of times with my old co-workers.  Every year my boss and I would take our Captains (I worked for a catering company) out to dinner to thank them for their service.  They almost unanimously chose Tango Sur time after time.   First of all its BYO- but when the boss is payin' you want to make sure you are getting his money worth and we definitely did.  I actually wasnt a meat eater at the time but I often lost bets that meant I would have to try meat at these get togethers and I got to say it was always delicious.   We always had good service and had never had any problems with our party of 10-15 people on a friday night.   It also seems fairly romantic....

Very impressed by my visit on Saturday night. We had a party of 6 and could not get a reservation (they were booked when I called two days in advance). So we arrived at 6:15 to put our name in, gave the host our cell #, and headed down the street to Take Five for some beers. Although we were told the wait would be at least two hours, our table was actually ready in an hour and a half. The atmosphere is great - dim lighting, candles on the tables, etc. It is quite loud, however - so not exactly romantic, but definitely an intimate spot for a group of friends! The food --- we started with the provoleta (awesome) and a sampling of each type of empanada - I enjoyed the spinach and cheese ones, but not sure if I'd order them again. The boyfriend and I split the el filet, which is TWO filets in a wine/onion sauce with a side of spinach mashed potatoes. My steak was great - cooked perfectly, not fatty. The mashed potatoes are average at best. The best part, though - was asking for a side of chimichurri sauce on the side for dipping the steak. The chimichurri is out of this world! Just be prepared to smell like garlic :) For dessert, we had a rolled pound cake topped with the most delicious whipped caramel I've ever had. And the best part - we walk out of there for $25/person! I love BYOB and I love Tango Sur and I'll definitely go back!!

I have been to tango sur several times and have loved it each time.   The food is great and the prices are very reasonable too!   Great steaks and even better empanadas :)    Be prepared to wait (approx 1 hr) for a table on a weekend though.   However, while you are waiting you can give them your cell # and you can head to a southport bar and they will call you as soon as your table is ready- GREAT idea!!  This is definately a fun place to go for a night out with the girls or on a date!

Yes there was a wait - Yes it was small - BUT THE BEST ARGENTINIAN FOOD I HAVE EVER HAD! This BYOB was a wonderful night out for me and my husband. After reading several reviews we decided to get down to Southport before we were too hungry. We got on the list, gave the front doorman our cell number and went for a stroll through the neighborhood. An hour and half later the host called us gave us another ten minutes to get back to Tango and our table was ready.  The food was wonderful and the atmosphere was perfect for a romantic evening together.  The next time we go to Tango we are bringing four friends so we can get reservations.  With the warmer weather around the corner, I can't to try the outdoor seating.

Bless you, Tango Sur! Steaks - win. Salad (even though it's a basic lettuce, tomato, onion) - win. Empanadas - double win (they also sell empanadas during the day at the Latin American market next door - same owners). Wine - BYOB - win. I love the outdoor seating too. I went to Tango Sur for my graduation dinner and, even though they don't take reservations for the outside tables, they accommodated my large party. Thanks!

For years I've been hearing about Tango Sur and last Friday I decided to buy a decent red wine, prepared the palate for red meat, and convinced the boyfriend to wait an hour for dinner.  (They don't take reservations for small parties, i.e. less than 6) We arrived around 7pm on a Friday night and waited a true hour for a table.  Just as everyone mentioned, the restaurant is dim (with candles), tables are close together and it was loud.  (But then again, I'm a loud person so I didn't mind this so much...I can complete with the best of them.)   For appetizers, the waiter suggested the Provoleta and I made sure to order the Empanadas by other's suggestions.  Empanadas, were awesome.  We could've done without the Provolenta, which was just a big plate of melted cheese that you had to race to eat with bread...otherwise it was going to turn into a block within minutes.  The salads came next- which like one reviewer said, were like burger toppings- dark, hearty greens they use on burgers with sliced onions & two large tomato slices.  Yep, that's it.  Not impressed. On to the main dish- I ordered the 12 oz which was cooked well, slightly fatty and heavily seasoned, but tasty.  My boyfriend went for the salmon and it was delicious.  I liked his better and made the switch at the half way point.  The portions were huge and they happily went home with us.   Really, I give it three stars for the portion to price ratio and the ambiance.  Great value but not sure if I'll go back again.

BYOB Argentinian Steak house with a youthful, latin-euro-style charm.  Light is dim, tables are close.  There is usaully a wait, bring a bottle of wine for the room in the back or hit a nearby bar.   They serve warm fresh bread soon after seated- off to a good start.  Most of the portions are massive- enough for lunch the next day.  I usually get the Churrasco- (steak frites).  The chimchurri (garlic, parsley, olive oil) sauce is the best version around- a difficult task.  The cuts of meat are not premium filets, but this is not a stately steak house- this is a glimpse into the cuisine of Argentina and we are blessed to have this establishment in Chicago. Carne asada at Nuevo Leon, 24-hr marinated steak at Ja'Grill and and even Uncle Julio's (I know it is a chain out of Texas- don't hold it against them) are also some of the best I've had.

After scouting this place out on Yelp, I decided to give it a try. The wait was an hour long, and my boyfriend did nothing but complain about it, so we(HE) decided to go to D'Agostino's instead. I was so disappointed. But, they had taken our names down and wrote down our phone number and were told they would call us when they were ready to seat us. Good thing! We had just ordered our drinks at D'Agostinos when they called. It was only about 10 minutes later! Needless to say, I made the BF leave his pizza place for some delicious Argentinian food (and a MUCH better atmosphere). We were put in a waiting room where wine glasses were provided with seats all along the wall. We were a little disappointed about that, because they acted like we were going to be seated right away, but we were only in the waiting room for about 10 minutes. I am so glad we waited. I had the 12 oz. Churrasco. It was way too big for me to eat, but it came with delicious dipping sauce with olive oil, garlic, and parsley. Sooo good! My boyfriend had fettuccine, booorrrring. Oh, well. We also had the Brazilian soda. We have had it before at a Brazilian friends' house, and we have never seen it anywhere else so we were SO excited that they had it because it is SOOO delicious. If you have never had it (it's called Guarana, which reminds me of something gross because it kind of sounds like guana, but it's NOT!), you should definitely try it. We didn't BYOB, but next time we definitely will. And their WILL be a next time. I'm giving this place 4 stars because we've only been here once and I was only able to try one plate. I'm sure I will be making it 5 stars some day.

Would like to give 3.5 stars. So, this place is really great for ambience: low lighting, small and cozy tables, lots of people enjoying food and wine and conversation, etc. Also love that it's BYOB with no corkage fee. The food was just OK. The salad was more like the toppings straight off a burger, but then again I'm not a huge salad eater. I got the beef vesuvio, and my date got the filet. The portions ARE huge. Like really, my whole plate was covered by the massive steak, besides a few potato wedges on the sides. And they actually give you 2 pieces of filet, which was kind of a surprise :) I really liked the cheese and spinach stuffing for my steak, but the meat itself was pretty tough, and there was also lots of oils on the plate, which were kind of unappetizing. My date really enjoyed his filet, so maybe that'd be a better choice. All in all, a fun night, but wasn't wowwed by the food.

A group of us just got back from Buenos Aires about two weeks ago and were craving BEEF. Thank God for Tango Sur... it really hit the spot and brought us back to Argentina !! Our server was dead on with every recommendation so we enjoyed alot .... Delicious empanadas - perfectly seasoned and you can tell they are handmade. Rockin chimichurri that I wanted to put on EVERYTHING.   And most importantly, great Argentine steaks that made your taste buds do a tango.  The filet is to die for (and I usually dont care for filet since its not as flavorful as other cuts).  The rib eye was just as good too.  And to add to its authenticity - I really loved the fact that alot of the meat was flown in from Argentina. We ended the evening with an alfajore topped with a little dulce de leche.  If I didnt look out the window, I wouldve sworn I was sitting in a parilla in Buenos Aires!

Wow, this place was really not worth it. We showed up at 10pm, hoping the line would be shorter. No luck - we weren't seated until 11:30. We all ordered steaks, and they were uniformly fatty and poorly seasoned. Even the filets were tough and super fatty. They weren't even cooked to the right degree of done-ness (is that a word?)  I'm giving it an extra star for the ambiance, which would have been great if not for the (literally) screaming group in the corner. Another plus was the BYO. Regardless, I won't be going back.

This place gets 3 stars for serving a plate full of tongues....yeah, they  did taste like I thought a tongue would taste....the texture in itself was pretty whicked....you can see the taste buds and feel the grainy bumps. With a bottle of wine (BYOB) and the outside seating....why not french kiss your plate? (Is there anything I won't try?...geez)

I went there after an afternoon cubs game with my out of town boyfriend at the time.  We cabbed it from Wrigley at it was not a far. I was impressed with the portions.  It was a little too much food for me but the prices and portions are hard to beat.  We had appetizers and entrees.  I hardly could finish my steak it covered almost the whole plate.  The restaurant is very small and intimate. Pros Romantic setting, BYOB, large portions, very affordable, close to Wrigley Cons: small Overall, I thought it was a great BYOB steak place

i had 3-4 empanadas as the appertizer and vacio for my meal (which is, as it  literally says, half slab of range grown flap meat sliced and filled with olive oil, garlic, parsley sauce, then cooked and served on a grill with mashed sweet potatoes) Well, in brief..even their tomatoes were delicious. I used to hate tomatoe since kindergarten era but after that day,, i've mentally changed... it must have been magical tomatoes that they fed me. And that's enough to earn my respect. The only thing I disliked was the waitstaff service. it could have been more very friendly. Out of five, there was one person who was truly friendly to us. But that's life I guess...you can never have them all..

I'll be brief.  I've been here twice.  Once for a bachelor party.  And the second time with a small group of friends.  First time was great.  We were all drunk so it would not have mattered if the food was terrible.  No cork fee so we brought our own wine which was great.  Lots and lots of cheap bottles of wine.   But the second time was when I was sober.  And boy was I wrong the first time.   First, it was too dark to see anything let alone distinguish what you're eating.  The hot plate meat dish we had was simply a pile of meat and I couldn't tell if I was eating cow's testicles for all I knew.   Whatever they call "Sweet Bread," do not try it.  It's tastless, I felt like chewing on a chunk of fat and I had to spit it out.   I would advise against going here. Update:  I found out that sweetbreads are the name of a dish made of the thymus gland or pancreas of a young animal, usually a lamb or calf.  It was a new experience for me but had they EXPLAINED what it was I would not have gotten it.

Went there with my friends recently, tried the eggplant appetizer(on special) and the short ribs. FANTASTIC eggplant, and the best ribs I've had from a restaurant in my life  - warm bread, BYOB, it's fantastic! The desserts also looked great, but we were all too full to try any.   Absolutely fantastic!

Great service: efficient and cordial. BYOB has got to be the best invention. Complimentary table bread comes warm and is actually quite good!  TORTILLA DE PAPAS! Ok, I loved this in Spain and it's kind of like quiche. It was very tasty with a nice dose of onion and potatoes--my favorite dish of the night. Was superexcited to eat its leftovers today.  Ensalada Tango Sur: very basic and actually quite plain. A few fat round slices of tomatoes and onion rings atop romaine greens. Came only with olive oil and vinegar.  El Filet: Two big pieces of filet with spinach mashed potatoes. Our medium rare was closer to a medium and charred on the surface. The mashed potatoes were too wet--would've preferred it more chunky.
